University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Whanne that Aprill . with his showris soote
The drought of Marche . hath ꝑper/parced the Roote
And bathed eủer/rey veyne . in suche licoure
Of which vertu . engendrid is the floure
Whan zephirus eke . with his swete breth
Enspired hath . in eủer/rey holt and heth
The tendre croppis . and the yong sonne
Hath in the Ram . half his cours Ironne
And smale fowlis . maken melodye
That alnyght sleepen . with open ye
So prikkith hem nature . in theyr corages
That longen folk . to gon on pilgrimages
And palmers to seeke . straunge strondes
To ferne halowes . in vnkouth londis
And specialy . from eủer/rey shyres end
Of Inglond . to Caunterbury they wend
The holy blisful martir . for to seeke
That hem hath holpen . whan they were seeke
Bifel in that season . vpon a day
In Southwerk at the tabbard as I lay
Redy to wenden on my pilgremage
To Caunterbury . withful deuout corage
At nyght was come . in to that hostelerie
Wele . xxix . in a companye
Of sundry folk . bi aduenture I falle
In felawship . and pilgrymes were they alle
That toward Cauntirbury wolden Ride
The chambres and the stables weren wide
And wele were . eased at the best
And shortly whan the sonne . was at Rest
So had I spoken . with theym eủer/reichon
That I was . of theyr felawship anon
And made forward . erly for to rise
To take oure wey . there as I yow devise
But natheles . while I have tyme and spase
Or that I further . in this tale pas
Me thynkith it were . accordaunt to reasoun
To telle yow . al the condicioun
Of eche of theym . as it seemyth me
And whiche they weren . and of what degre
And eeke in what array . that they were Inne
And at a knyght . than wil I first begynne
A knyght ther was . and that a worthy man
That from the tyme . that he first bigan
To Riden out . he loved cheualry
Trowth and honour . freedam and curtesy
Ful worthy was he . in his lordis werre
And therto had he Riden . noman ferre
As wele in Cristendom . as in hethennes
And eủer/ree honowred . for his worthynes
At Alisaunder he was . whan it was wonne
Ful oft tyme . had he the boorde bigonne .
Above al naciouns . that were in Pruse
In lettow had he reised . and in Ruse
No cristen man so oft . of his degre
In Garnade at the siege . eeke had he be
At Algazar had he be . and in Belmarye
At Leyes was he . and at Satellye
Whan they were wonne . and in the grete see
At many a noble armee . had he be
At mortal batailes . had he be fiftene
And foughten for oure feyth . at Tramyssene
In listes thryes . and ay slayn his foo .
This ilke worthy knyght . hadde bien also
Somtyme with the lord . of Palatie
Agayn another hethen . in Turquye
And eủer/remore he had . a soủer/reayne prise
And though he were worthy . he was wise
And of his port . as meke as is a mayde
He neủer/re yit . no vilanye sayde
In al his live . to nomaner wight
He was a verray . ꝑper/parfit gentil knyght
But for tellen yow . of his array
His hors was goode . but he was nat gay
Of fustian . he wered a gipioun
Albe smotered . with his habirgeoun
For he was late come . from his viage
And went for to do . his pilgremage
With hym ther was his sone . a yong squyer
A lovier . and a lusty bachiller
With lokkes crulle . as they were leyde in presse
Of . xx . yeere of age . he was as I gesse
Of his stature he was . of evyn length
And wounder delyủer/re . and of even strength
And he had be sumtyme . in Cheuache
In flaundris in Artays and in Pikarde
And born hym wele . as of so litel space
In hope to stand . in his Ladi grace
Embrowded was he . as it were a mede
Al ful of fressh flowris . white and Rede
Syngyng he was . or floityng al the day
He was as fressh . as the moneth of May
Short was his gowne . with slevis long and wide
Wele cowde he sitte on hors bak . and faire Ride
He cowde songes wele make . and endite
Iust and daunce . ⁊and eke wele portrey and write
So hoote he lovid . that be nyghter tale
He slept nomore . that doth the nyghtyngale
Curteys he was . lowly and ʆser/siruisable
And carf before his fadir . at the table
A yoman had he . and ʆser/siruauntis nomoo
For at that tyme . hym list to Ride soo
And he was clad . in cote and hoode of grene
A sheaf of pecok arwes . bright and kene
Vndir his belt he bare . ful thriftily
Wele cowde he dresse . his tacle yomanly
His arwis drowpid nat . with fethers lowe
And in his hand . he bare a myghti bowe
A not hed had he . with a browne visage
Of woode craft cowde he . al the vsage
Vpon his arm bare he . a gay brasere
And bi his side . a swerde and a bokelere
And onthat other side . a gay daggere
Harneysed wele . and sharp as poynt of spere
A Cristofre on his brest . of silủer/re sheene
A foster was he . soothly as I gesse
Ther was also . a Nonne a prioresse
That of hir smylyng . was ful symple and coy
Hir grettest ooth . was eủer/re be seynt loy
And she was clepid . madame Eglentyne
Ful wele she song . hir ʆser/siruice all divyne
Entuned in hir nose . ful semyly
And frenssh she spak . ful faire and fetisly
After the scole . of stratford at the bowe
For frenssh of parice . was to hir knowe
At the mete wele I taught . was she withal
She leete no morsel . from hir lippes falle
Ne with hir fyngres . in hir sawce depe
Wele cowde she carie a morsel . and wele kepe
That no droppe . fil on hir brest
In curtesie was set . moche of hir lest
Hir oủer/relip . wipped she so cleene
That in hir couppe . ther was no ferthyng seene
Of grece whan she hadde . dronk hir draught
Ful semely after . hir mete she raught
And sikirly she was of grete disport
And ful plesaunt . and amyable of port
And poyned hir . to countrefete chiere
Of court and to be . estatly of manere
And to be hold digne . of Reủer/reence
And for to speken . of hir conscience
She was so charitable . and so pitous
She wold weepe . if she sawe a mows
Caught in a trappe . if it were ded or bled
Of smale houndis had she . that she fed
With rost mete . mylk and wastilbrede
But sore wept she . if any of hem were dede
Or if men smote hem . with a yerd smerte
And al was but conscience . and tendir herte
Ful semely hir wympil . pynched was
Hir noise tretice . hir eyen gray as glas
Hir mowth ful smal . and therto soft and Rede
But sikirly she hadde . a faire forhede
It was almost . a spanbrode I trowe
For certainly she was nat . vndirgrowe
Ful fetice was hir clooke . as I was ware
Of smal coral . aboute hir arm she bare
Apeyre of bedis . gawded al with grene
And theron hyng a broche . of gold ful shene
On whiche was first writen . a Crowned . A .
And after that Amor vincit omia
Another Nonne . with hir had she
That was hir chapelayn . and pristes thre
A Monk ther was . for the maistrie
Anout Rider . that lovid venorie
A manly man . to bien an Abbot able
Ful many a deynte hors . had he in stable
And whan he Rode . men myght his bridel here
Gynglyng and whistlyng . in the wynd so clere
And eke as lowde . as doth the chapel belle
There as this lord . was keper of the selle
The Rule of seynt Mawry . or of seynt Benet
Bicause it was old . and sumdel straite
This ilk Monk . lete old thynges pas
And hield after the newe world . the trace
He yaf nought of that text . a pullid henne
That saith that hunters . be nat holy men
Ne that a monk . that is recheles
Is likened to a fish . that is watirles
This is to seyn . a monk out of his cloistre
But that text hield he . nat worth anoystee
And I say . his oppynioun was goode
What shuld he studye . and make hym self woode
Vpon a booke alwey . in cloister to powre
Or swynk with his handes . and do laboure
As Austyn biddith . how shal the world be ʆser/sirved
Late Austyn have his swynke . to hym reʆser/sirued
Therfor he was . a prikasour a Right
Greyhoundis had he . as any mylk white
Of prikyng and huntyng . for the hare
Was al his lust . for nothyng wold he spare
I sawe his slevis purfiled at the hond
With grys . and that the fynest in a lond
And for to fastene his hoode . vndir his chynne
He had of gold wrought . a curious pynne
A love knot in the gretter end was
His hed was ballid . and shoone as any glas
And eke his face . as it had bien enoynt
He was a lord fatte . and in goode poynt
His eyen steepe . and rolled in his hede
That stemed . as a furneys of lede
His bootes sowple . his hors in grete estate
Now certainly . he was a faire prelate
He was nat paale . as a forpyned gost
A fatt swan loved he . best of any Rost
His Palfray was browne . as any bery
A freere therwas . a wanton and a mery
A lymytour . a ful solempne man
In al the ordres foure . is non that can
So moche of daliaunce . and faire langage
He had maked . ful many a mariage
Of yong wymmen . at his owne cost
Vnto his ordre . he was a noble post
Ful wele beloved . and famulier was he
With franklayns oủer/real . in his cuntee
And eke with worthy wymmen . in the towne
For he had power . of confessioun
And saide hym self . more than a curat
For of his ordir . he was licenciat
Ful sweetely herd he . confessioun
And plesᵃunt was . his absolucioun
He was anesy man . to yeve penaunce
Ther as he wist . to have a goode pitaunce
For vnto a poore ordre . to yeve
Is a signe . a man is wele I shreve
For if he yaf . he durst make a vaunt
He wist that a man . was repentaunt
For many aman . so hard is of his hert
He may nat weepe . though he sore smert
Therfor in stiede of wepyng and prayers
Men must yeve siluer . to the poore freeris
His tipet was I farced . ful of knyves
And pynnes to yeve . vnto faire wyfes
And certainly he had . a myrry throte
Wele cowde he synge . and pley on a Rote
Of yeddynges he bare . vttirly the price
His nekke white was . as the floure delis
Therto he strong was . as a Champioun
He knew the taủer/renes . wele in eủer/rey towne
And eủer/rey hostiler and Tampster
Better than a lazer . or a bagster
For vnto suche a worthy man . as he
Accorded nat . as bi his faculte
To have with sike lazers . acqueyntaunce
It is nat honest . it may nat avaunce
For to dolen with . non suche poraile
But al with Riche . and sellers of vitaile
And oủer/re al there . as profite shuld arise
Curte ys he was . and lowly of servise
Ther was noman . nougher so vertuous
He was the best begger . that was in his hous
And yaf a certayn ferme . for the graunt
That non of his brethern . com in his haunt
For though a widew . had but a shoo
So plesaunt was . his Inprincipio
That he wold have a ferthyng . or that he went
His purchas was wele bettir . than his rent
And Rage he cowde . as it were a whelp
In lovedayes . ther cowde he moche help
For ther he was nat . like a cloystrere
With a thredbare cope . as a poore freere
But he was like . a Maister or a pope
Of double worstede . was his semy cope
Round as a belle . as it com out of presse
Somwhat he lipsed . for his wantounesse
To make his Inglissh sweete vpon his tung
And in his harpyng . what he had sung
His eyen twynkled . in his hede a Right
As don the sterris . in the frosty nyght
This worthy lymytour . was clepid hughberd
A Marchaunt was ther . wit a forked berd
In motley anhy . vpon his hors he sat
Vpon his hede . a flaundris bever hat
His bootes claspid . faire and fetisly
His reasons he spak . ful solempnely
Sownyng alwey . thencres of his wynnyng
He wold the see were kept . for anythyng
Betwixt Middilburgh . and Orewel
Wele cowde he in eschaunge . shieldis selle
This worthy man . ful wele his wit beset
There wist nowight . that he was in det
So estately was he . of his contenaunce
With his Bargaynes . and his chevisaunce
Forsoth he was . a worthy man with al
But sooth to seyn . I not how men hym cal
A Clerk therwas . of Oxenford also
That vnto logik . had long I go
As leene was his hors . as is a Raake
And he was nat Right fat I vndretake
He looked holow . and therto sobirly
Ful thredbare was . his oủer/reest courtepy
For he had goten hym . yit no benifice
Ne was so worthy . for to have anoffice
For hym was lever to have at his beddis hed
Twenty bookis . clad in white and Red
Of Aristotil and his philosophie
Than Robis Riche . or fithel or sawtry
But al be that . he was a philosofre
Yit had he . but litel gold in cofre
But al that he myght . of his friendis hente
On bookes and on liernyng . he it spente
And busily gan . for the soulis prey
Of hem that yaf hym . wherwith to scoley
Of study toke he . most cure and heede
Nought oo word spak he . more than was neede
And that was spoke . in forme and Reuerence
And short and quyke . and ful of hie sentence
Sownyng in moral vertu . was his speche
And gladly wold he lierne . and gladly teche
A ʆser/sirgeaunt of lawe . ware and wise
That often had bien . at the parvise
He was also . Riche of excelence
Discrete he was . and of grete reủer/reence
He semed suche . his wordis were so wise
Iustise he was . ful oft in assise
Bi patent . and bi playn commissioun
For his science . and for his hye Renoun
Of fees and Robis . had he manyon
So grete a purchasour . was ther nowher non
Al was fee symple . to hym in effecte
His purchase myght nat be . to hym suspecte
Noughwher so busy aman . as he ther nas
And yit semed he . busyer than he was
In termes had he . cases and domes alle
That from the tyme . of kyng Willᵃm were falle
Therto he cowde endite . and make athyng
Ther cowde no wight . pynche at his writyng
And eủer/rey statute cowde he . playn bi Rote
He Rode but homly in a Medle cote
Gird with a cors of silk . with barres smale
Of his array tel I no lengger tale
A frankelayn was . in his companye
White was his berd as is daisie
Of his complexioun . he was sangwyne
Wele loved he bi the morow . a soppe in wyne
To live in delite . was eủer/ree his wone
For he was Epicurus owne sone
That holdith oppynioun . that playn delite
Was verray felicite parfite
Anhouseholder . and that a grete was he
Seynt Iulyan he was callid . in his cuntre
His brede his ale . was alwey after oon
A better vyned man . was nowher non
Without bakemete . was neủer/re his house
Of fressh fissh and flessh . and that so plentivous
It snewed in his house . of mete and drynk
Of al deyntes . that men cowde thynk
After the sundry seasons . of the yeere
So chaunged he his mete . and his sowper
Ful many a fat ꝑper/partriche . hadde he in meowe
And many a breeme . and Luce in stiewe
Woo was his cooke . but his sauce were
Poignaunt and sharp . and redy al his gere
His table dormant . in his halle lay
Stoode redy coủer/reed . al the long day
At sessions ther was he . lord and sire
Ful oft hadde he be . knyght of the shire
A baselard harnaysed . and a gipser of silk
Hyng at his girdil . as white as any mylk
A shereve had he be . and coronoure
Was nowher suche . a worthy vauasour
Anhabirdassher . and a carpenter
A webbe a dyer and a Tapiser
Al they were clothed . in oo lyủer/reee
Of a solempne . and grete fraternite
Ful fressh and newe ther gere I piked was
Hir knyves and sethes . nat chapid with bras
But al with siluer wrought . ful clene and wele
Theyr girdils and powches . eủer/rey dele
Wele semed eche of theym . a faire burgeys
To sitte in the gild halle . on a deys
Eủer/reiche for the wisdam . that he can
Was likly to be . an Aldirman
For catel hadde they I nough and Rent
And eke theyr wifes . wold it wele assent
And ellis certayn . they were to blame
It is ful faire . to be clepid Madame
And go to vigiles . albe fore
And have a Mantel . Rially I bore
A Cooke had they with hem . for the nones
To boile the chekyns . with the mary bones
And powdre marchaunt . tart and galyngale
Wele cowde he knowe . a draught of london ale
He cowde Rost and seeth . boile and frye
Make mortrews . and wele bake a pie
But grete harm was it . as it thought me
That on his shyne . a mormal had he
For blancmanger . made he with the best
A shipman was there . wonyng fer be west
As fer as I wote . he was of Dertemowthe
He Rode on a Rouncy . as he wele cowth
In a goun of faldyng . doun to the kne
A dagger hangyng bi a lase . had he
A boute his nekke . vndir his arme a doun
The hote som . had made hym al brown
And certainly . he was a goode felawe
Ful many a draught of wyne . had he drawe
From Burdeauxward . while the M̉er/rechaunt sleepe
Of nyce concience . toke he no kepe
If that he faught . and had the hyer hand
Be watir he sent theym hom . to sundry lond
But of his craft . to Rekene wele his tides
His streames and his daungiers . hym besides
His herborow . and his lodemanage
Ther was non suche . from hulle to cartage
Hardy he was and wise . I vndirtake
With many a tempeste . had his berd bien shake
He knewe al the havenes . as they were
From Scotlond to Capfynistere
And eủer/rey crele in bretaygne and in spaigne
His Barge was clepid . the magdaleyne
With vs ther was . a doctor of phisike
In al the world . ne was thernon hym like
To speke of phisik . and of surgerye
For he was grounded . In astronomye
He kept his pacient . a ful grete dele
In his his houres . of magik naturele
Wele cowde he knowe . the fortune ascendent
Of his ymages . for his pacient
He knewe the cause . of eủer/rey malady
Were it of hote or cold . moist or drye
And where it engendrid . and of what humoᵘur
He was a Verray ꝑper/parfit . practisour
The cause he knewe . and of the cause the Roote
Anon he yaf . the sike man his boote
Ful redy had he . his Apotecaries
To sende hym drugges . and his lete waries
For eche of theym . made other for to wynne
Theyr frendship was nat . newe to begynne
Wele knewe he . the old Esculapius
And Discorides . and eke Rufus
Old Ipocras haly and Galien
Serapion Razis and avicen
Aueroys Damascen . and constantyn
Bernard Gatisden . and Gilbertyn
Of his diete . ful mesurable was he
For it was . of no suꝑper/parfluite
But grete norisshyng . and digestible
His studye was . but litel on the bible
In sangwyn and in ꝑper/parce . he clad wal al
Lyned with Taffata . and with Sendal .
And yit he was . but easy of dispense .
He kept that he wan . in pestilence
For gold in phisik . is accordial
Therfor loved he gold . in especial
A goode wif ther was . of beside bath
But she was sumdel def . and that was skath
Of cloth makyng had she . suche anhaunt
She passed hem of Ipres . and of gaunt
In al the ꝑper/parissh . wif was there non
That to the offryng . bi fore hir shuld gon
And if ther dide . certayn so wroth was she
That she was out . of al charitee
Her coủer/rechiefs . ful fyne were of ground
I durst swere . they weyed doun a pound
That on asunday . were vpon hir hede
Her hosyn were . of fyne skarlet Rede
Ful streite I tied . and shooes moyst and newe
Bold was hir face . faire and Rede of hewe
She was a worthy womman . al hir lyve
Husbondis at the chirche doore . hadde she fyve
Without other compaignie . in yowth
But therof nedith nat . to speke as nowth
And thryes had she be . at Ierusalem
She had passed many a straunge streame
At Rome had she be . and at Coloyne
In Galice at seynt Iame and at Boloyne
She cowde moche . of wandryng in the wey
Gattothed she was . sothly for to sey
Vpon an Ambuler . esily she sat
I wympled wele . and on hir hed an hat
As brode as a bokeler . or a targe
A foote Mantel . a boute hir hippes large
And on hir helis a paire of spooris sharpe
In felawship wele cowde she . laugh and carpe
Of Remedies of love . she cowde ꝑper/parchaunce
For of that arte . she cowde leede the daunce
A goode man ther was . of Religioun
And was a poore ꝑper/parson . of a Town
But Riche he was . of gostly thought and werk
He was also . a lierned man a clerk
That Cistes gospel . triewly . wold he preche
His ꝑper/parisshens . devoutly wold he teche
Benyngne he was . and woundir diligent
And in adủer/resite . ful pacient
And suche was he proved . oft sithes
Ful loth were he to curse . for his tithes
But rather wold he yeve . out of doute
Vnto his poore ꝑper/parysshens . round aboute
Of his offryng eke . and of his substaunce
Wyde was his ꝑper/parissh . and houses fer a sunder
But he left nat . for Reyne ne for thunder
In sikenesse nor in myschief . to visite
The furthest in his parissh . moche and lite
Vpon his feete . and in his hand a staf
This noble ensample . vnto his sheepe he yaf
That first he wrought . and after that he taught
Out of the gospel . these wordes he caught
And this figure . he addid therto
That if gold Rust . what shal Irn do
For if a priest be fowle . on whom we trust
No woundir is . a lewdeman to Rust
Shame it is . if a priest take kepe
A shiten shepperd . and a cleene sheepe
Wele ought a priest . ensample for to yeve
Bi his clennesse . how that his sheepe shuld live
He sette his benefice . nat vnto hyre
And lete his sheepe . encombre in the myre
And ren to london . vnto seynt powlis
To seeken hym a chᵃuntry . for soulis
Or with a bretherhed . to be withold
But dwellith at hom . and kepith his fold
So that the flok ꝑper/parissh nat . ne myscary
He was a Verray shepperd . and nat a M̉er/recenarie
And though he holy were . and Vertuous
He was nat to synful men dispitous
Ne of his speche . daungerous and digne
But in his techyng . discrete and benyngne
To drawe folk to hevene ward . with fairenesse
Bi goode ensample this was his busynesse
But it were any ꝑper/parsone . obstynate
What so he were . of highgh or low estate
Hym wold he snybben . sharply for the nones
A bettir prist I trowe . nowher non is
He waited after no pompe . ne reủer/reence
Ne made hym non . spiced conscience
But Cristes lore . and his aposteles twelve
He taught . but first he folowed it hym selve
With hym ther was . a ploughman his brother
That had I lad of dung . ful many a foother
A triewe swynker . and agoode was he
Lyveng in peas . and ꝑper/parfite charite
God loved he best . with al his hole hert
At al tymes . though he gramed or smert
And than his neyghburgh . right as hym selve
He wold thressh . and therto dike and delve
For Cristes sake . for eủer/rey poore wight
Withouten huyre . if it lay in his myght
His tithes paied he . ful faire and wele
Both in his ꝓpropre swynk . and his catel
In a tabbard he Roode . vpon ameere
There was also . a Ryve and a Miller
A Sompnoᵘur and a pardoner also
A Maunciple and my self . ther were nomo
The Miller was . a stout carl for the nones
Ful bigge he was . of brawn and of bones
That preved wele . for eủer/re where that he cam
At wrastelyng . he wold have the Ram
He was short . shuldred brode a thikke gnarre
Ther was no dore . that he nold heve of barre
Or breke it with a Rennyng . with his hede
His berde as any soowe . or fox was Rede
And therto bl brode . as it were a spade
Vpon the cop of his nose . he hade
A wert . and theron stoode a tuft of heris
Rede as the brustils . of a sowes eeris
Hys nostrels were . blac and wide
A swerd and a bokelier . he bare bi his side
His mowth as grete . as is a furneys
He was a Iangler . a Iolihardeys
And that was most . of synne and harlotries
Wele cowde he stele corn . and tolle thries
And yit he hadde . a thomb of gold ꝑper/parde
A white cote . and a bliew hoode wered he
A bagge pipe wele cowde . he blowe and sowne
And therwith al . he brought vs out of towne
A gentil maunciple ther was of a temple
Of whiche a Catour . myght take ensample
For to be wise . in byeng of vitaile
For whether he paide . or tooke bi taile
Algate he wayted so . in his achate
That he was ay be fore . and in goode state
Now is nat that of god . a ful faire grace
That suche a lewde mannys wit shal pace
The wisdom of anhepe . of lierned men
Of maistres hadde he . mo than thries ten
That were of lawe . expert and curious
Of whiche ther wer . a dossen in that hous
Worthy to bien stywardes . of Rent and lond
Of any lord . that is in Inglond
To make hym lyve . bi his ppre goode
In honoure detles . but if that he were woode
Or live as skarsly . as hym list desire
In any case that myght falle in a shire
And able for to helpen . al ashire
In any case that myght . falle or happe
And yit maunciple . set ther alther cappe
The Reeve was . a sklendir colerik man
His berd was shaave . as nygh as eủer/re it can
His her bi his eeris . ful round I shorn
His toppe was dokked . like a priest beforn
Ful long were his legges . and ful leene
Ful like a staf . ther was no calf I seene
Wele cowde he kepe . a garner and a bynne
Ther was non Auditour cowde on hym wynne
Wele wist he bi the drought . and bi the Rayne
The yieldyng of his seede . and of his grayne
His lordis sheep his neete . his dayrie
His swyn his hors . his steede and his pultrye
Was holy in this Reves . goủer/renyng
And bi his couenᵃnt . gaf the Rekenyng
Syn that his lord . was twenty yeere of Age
Ther cowde noman bryng hym . in Arrerage
Ther ne was baily . hierde nor other hyne
That knew his craft . his sleight and his covyne
They were a dradde of hym . as of the deth
His wonyng was fulfaire . vpon anheth
With grene trees . shadwed was his place
He cowde bettir . than his lord purchace
To yeve and leene hym . of his owne goode
And yit have thank . and cote and hoode
In yowthe lierned he hadde . a goode myster
He was a wele goode wright . a carpenter
This Ryve sat . vpon a wele goode stot
That was a pomel gray . and hight scot
Of northfolk was this Ryue . of whiche I telle
Biside a towne . men calle Baldiswelle
Tukked he was . as is a frere aboute
And eủer/re he Rode . hynderest of the Route
A Sompnour ther was . with vs in the place
That had a fier rede . cherubyns face
For sausfleame he was . with eyen narowe
And hote he was . and lecherous as a sparowe
With scaled browes . and pilled berd
Of his visage . chieldren were aferd
Ther nas qwike silủer/re . litarge ne brymston
Borace ceruse . ne oyle of Tarter non
Ne oynement that myght clense and bite
That hym myght help . of his whelkis white
Nor of the knobbis sittyng on his chekis
Wele loved he garlik . oynons and leekis
And for to drynk strong wyne . Rede as bloode
Than wold he swere . and crye as he were woode
And whan that he hadde . wele dronke the wyne
Than wold he speke noword but latyne
A fewe termes had he . two or thre
That he had lierned out of sum degre
No wonder is . he herd it al the day
And eke ye knowe wele . that a Iay
Can clepe wat as wele . as can the pope
But who cowde . in other thynges hym grope
Than had he sent . al his philosophie
A questio quid Iuris . wold he crye
He was a gentil harlot . and a kynde
A bettir felawe . shuld ther noman fynde
He wolde suffre . for a quarte of wyne
A goode felawe . to have his concubyne
A twelfmoneth . and excuse hym at the fulle
Ful prively . a fynche cowde he pulle
And if he fond oughwher . a goode felawe
He wold techen hym . to have non Awe
In suche a case . of the Archedekens curs
But if a mannes soule . were in his purs
For in his purs . he shuld I punysshed be
Purs is the Archedekens helle . quod he
But wele I wote . he lied right in deede
Of cursyng ought eche gilty man to drede
For curs sleeth . Right as soilyng savith
And also ware hym . of a significauit
In daunger had he . at his owne guyse
The yonge girles of the diocesise
And knewe theyr counseil . and was of theyr Rede
A garlond had he set . vpon his hede
As grete as it were . for an ale stake
A bokeler had he made hym of a cake
With hym ther Rode . a gentil pardoner
Of Rouncivale his friend and his comper
That streight was come . from the Court of Rome
Ful lowde he songe . com hider love come
The sompnour bare to hym a stif burdoun
Was neủer/re trumpe . of half so grete a sown
This ꝑper/pardoner had her as yolaw as wex
And smoth it hynge . as doth a strike of flex
Bi ounces hyng his lokkes . that he hadde
And therwith he . his shuldres oủer/re spradde
But thynne it lay . bi coulpons oon and oon
But hoode for Iolite . werid he non
For it was trussed . vppon his walette
Hym thought he Rode . al of the newe Iette
Discheuele save his cappe . he Rode al bare
Suche glaryng eyen had he . as hath anhare
A vernacle hadde he sowed . on his cappe
His wale bi fore hym . in his lappe
Bretful of pardoun . com from Rome al hoote
A voice he hadde . as smal as hath a gote
No berd had he . ne neủer/re shuld have
As smoth it was . as it were late shaave
I trow he were . a gildyng or a mare
But of his craft . from berwik vnto ware
Ne was ther suche . another ꝑper/pardoner
For in his male . he had a pilwe beer
Whiche that he saide . was oure lady vaile
He saide he hadde . a gobet of the saile
That seynt petir hadde . whan that he went
Vpon the see . til Ihu Crist hym hent
He had a crosse of laton . ful of stones
And in a glasse . he had piggesbones
But with these Relikes . whan that he fond
A poore ꝑper/parson . dwellyng vpon lond
Vpon a soneday . he gate more money
Than the ꝑper/parson gate . in monethis twey
And thus with feyned . flaterie and Iapis
He made the ꝑper/parson . and the ꝑper/parissh his apis
But triewly for to telle . at the last
He was in chirche . a noble ecclesiast
Wele cowde he Rede . a lesson or a story
And altherbest . he song an offitorye
For wele he wist . whan that song was song
He must preche . and file awhile his tong
To wynne silủer/re . as he wele cowde
Therfor he song . the more merily and lowde
Now have I told yow . sothly in a clause
Thestate tharray the nombre . and eke the cause
Why that assembled . was this compaignye
In southwerk . at this gentil hostillerye
That hight . the tabbard . fast bi the belle
But now is it tyme . to yow for to telle
How that we bare vs . that ilke nyght
Whan that we were . in that hostelrye a light
And after wil I telle yow . of oure viage
And al the Remenᵃnt . of oure pilgremage
But first I pray yow . of yowre curtesie
That ye it nat a Rette . for no vilanye
Though that I plainly . speke in this mater
To telle yow theyr wordis and theyr chere
Ne though I speke . theyr wordis ꝓpropirly
For this ye knowen . aswele as I
Who shal telle a tale . aftir a man
He must reherce . as nygh as he can
Eủer/reiche a word . if it be in his charge
Al speke he neủer/re so rudely ne so large
Or ellis he must telle . his tale vntriewe
Or feyne thyng . or fynd wordis newe
He may nat spare . although he were his brother
He must as wele sey . oo word as another
Crist spak hym self . ful brode in holy writ
And wele ye wote . no vilany is it
Eke Plato he saith . who so can hym Rede
The word must be cousyn . vnto the dede
Also I pray yow . to foryeve it me
Al have I nat sette folk . in theyr degree
Here in this tale . as they shuld stonde
My wit is shorte . ye may wele vndirstonde
Grete chiere made vs . oure host vs eủer/reichon
And to the souper . sette he vs a non
He ʆser/sirved vs with vitaile . of the best
Strong was the wyne . and wele drynke vs lest
A semely man . oure host was with al
For to bien a Marchal . in any lordis hall
A large man he was . with eyen steepe
A fairer burgeys . is ther non in chepe
Bold of his speche . wise and wele I taught
And of manhode . hym lakked right nought
Eke therto he was . a mirry man
And after souper to pleyen he bigan
And spak / of mirth . among other thynges
Whan that we hadde made . oure rekenyngges
And said now thus . lordis triewly
Ye be to me welcom . right hertily
For be my trowth . if I shal nat lye
I sawe nat this yeere . so mirry a compaignye
Atones in this herborow . as bien now
Fayn wold I do yow plesure . and I wist how
And of a mirth . Right now I am be thought
To don yow eaase . and it shal cost yow nought
Ye y gon to cauntirbury . god yow speede
The blisful martir . quyte yow yowre meede
And wele I wote . as ye go bi the way
Ye shapen yow . to talen and to play
For triewly comfort . ne myrth is non
To Ride bi the wey . domb as a ston
And therfor wil I . make yow disport
As I saide erst . and do yow comfort
And if yow like . al bi oon assent
For to stonden . at my Iugement
And for to werken . as y shal yow seye
To morow . whan ye Riden bi the weye
Now be my fader sowle . that is dede
But ye be mirrye . I yeve yow myn hede
Hold vp yowre handis withouten more speche
Oure counsaile . was nat . long for to seche
Vs thought it was nat worth . to make it uyse
And graunted hym . without more advise
And bad hym seye . his verdit hym lest
Lordynges quod he . now herkenyth for the best
But takith it nat . in disdayn I yow prayen
This is the poynt . to speke it short and playn
That eche of yow to short with oure weye
In this viage . shal tel . talis twey
To caunterbury ward . I meane it so
And homward . ye shal tellen . other two
Of Aventures whilom . that han bi falle
And whiche of yow . that berith hym best of alle
That is to sayn . that tellith in this case
Tales of best sentence . and of most solace
Shal have a sowper . at oure alther cost
Here in this place . sittyng bi this post
Whan we com agayne . from caunterbury
And for to make yow . the more mirry
I wil my self gladly . with yow ride
Right at myn owne cost . and be yowre guyde
And who so wil . my Iugement withseye
Shal paie for al . we spende bi the weye
And if ye fouchesauf . that it be so
Telle me anon . with out wordis moo
And I wil erly . shape me therfore
This thyng was graunted and othes I swore
With ful glad hert . and prayed hym also
That he wold . fouchesauf . to do right so
And that he wold . be oure goủer/renour
And of oure talis . Iuge and Reportour
And sette a souꝑper/par . at a certayn price
And we to be Rulid . at his devise
In high and low . and thus bi oon assent
We bien accordid . to his Iugement
And ther vpon . the wyne was fet anon
We dronken and to Rest . went echeon
Without any lengger taryeng
A morow whan the day . bigan to spryng
Vp ros oure host . and was oure alther cok
And gadred vs to gydre . al in a flok
And furth we Rode . litel more than a pase
Vnto the wateryng . of seynt Thomas
And ther our host . gan his hors aReste
And saide lordynges . herkenyth if yow leste
Ye wot yowre forward . and I it yow recorde
If evensong. and morow song accorde
Late see now . who shal telle the first tale
As eủer/ree mote I . drynk wyne or ale
Who so be Rebel . to my Iugement
Shal pay for al . that be the wey is spent
Now drawith cut . or ye further twynne
He that hath the shortest . he shal begynne
Sir knyght quod he . my maister and my lord
Now drawith cut . for that is myn accord
Cometh nere quod he . my lady Prioresse
And ye ʆser/sir clerk . late be yowre shamefastnesse
Ne studieth nat . lay hand on eủer/rey man
Anon to drawe eủer/rey wight began
And shortly for to telle . as it was
Were it bi aduenture . or soort or cas
The soth is this . the cut fil to the knyght /
Of whiche ful glad and blith . was eủer/rey wight
And tel he must his tale . as was Reasoun
Bi forward . and bi composicioun
As ye han herd . what nedith wordis mo
And whan this goode man . saw that it was so
As he that wise was . and obedient
To kepe his forward . and his fre assent
What welcom be cut in goddis name
He saide syn I . shalbe gynne the game
Now late vs Ride . and herken what I say
And with tha word . we Riden furth oure way
And he bigan . with Right a mirry chiere
His tale anon . and saide as ye may here
Iamque domos patria scithice post aspera gentis prelia laurigero
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree

div.l: (base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
(base) And alle we / that been in this array
(base) And maken / al this lamentacioun
(base) We losten alle oure housbondes / at that town
(base) Whil that the sege / ther aboute lay
(base) And yet now / the olde Creoun weylaway
(base) That lord is now / of Thebes the Citee
(base) Fulfild of Ire / and of Iniquitee
(base) He for despit and for his tyrannye
(base) To doon / the dede bodyes vileynye
(base) Of alle oure lordes / whiche that been slawe
(base) Hath alle the bodyes / on an heep ydrawe
(base) And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
(base) Neyther to been yburyed / nor ybrent
(base) But maketh houndes / ete hem in despit
(base) And with that word / withouten moore respit
(base) They fillen gruf and cryden pitously
(base) Haue / on vs wrecched wommen / som mercy
(base) And lat oure sorwe / synken in thyn herte
(base) ¶ This gentil Duc doun from his courser sterte
(base) With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Hym thoughte / that his herte wolde breke
(base) Whan he saugh hem / so pitous / and so maat
(base) That whilom weren / of so greet estaat
(base) And in hise armes / he hem alle vp hente
(base) And hem conforteth / in ful good entente
(base) And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
(base) He wolde doon / so ferforthly his myght
(base) Vpon the tiraunt Creon / hem to wreke
(base) That al the peple of Grece / sholde speke
(base) How Creoun was / of Theseus yserued
(base) As he that hadde his deeth / ful wel disserued
(base) And right anoon / withouten moore abood
(base) His baner he desplayeth / and forth rood
(base) To Thebesward / and al his oost bisyde
(base) No neer Atthenes / wolde he go ne ryde
(base) Ne take his ese / fully half a day
(base) But onward in his wey / that nyght he lay
(base) And sente anoon / ypolita the queene
(base) And Emelye / hir yonge suster sheene
(base) Vnto the town of Atthenes / to dwelle
(base) And forth he ryt ther nys namoore to telle
(base) ¶ The rede statue of Mars / with spere and targe
(base) So shyneth / in his white Baner large
(base) That alle the feeldes / glitren vp and doun
(base) And by his Baner / born was his penoun
(base) Of gold ful ryche / in which ther was ybete
(base) The Mynotaur / which that he wan in Crete
(base) ¶ Thus ryt this Duc . thus ryt this conquerour
(base) And in his oost of Chiualrye the flour
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Til that he cam to Thebes / and alighte
(base) Faire in a feeld / ther as he thoghte fighte

(base) This is to seyn / she may nat now haue bothe
(base) Al be ye neuere so Ialous / ne so wrothe
(base) And for thy / I yow putte in this degree

(base) ¶ My wil is this / for plat conclusioun
(base) Withouten any replicacioun
(base) If that yow liketh / take it for the beste

div.l: (base) And this day fifty wykes / fer ne neer
(base) Euerich of yow / shal brynge an hundred knyghtes
(base) Armed for listes / vp at alle rightes
(base) Al redy / to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) And this bihoote I yow / withouten faille
(base) Vpon my trouthe / and as I am a knyght
(base) That wheither of yow bothe / that hath myght
(base) This is to seyn / that wheither he or thou
(base) May with his hundred / as I spak of now
(base) Sleen his contrarie / or out of lystes dryue
(base) Thanne shal I yeue / Emelye to wyue
(base) To whom that Fortune / yeueth so fair a grace
(base) The lystes / shal I maken in this place
(base) And god so wisly / on my soule rewe
(base) As I shal / euene Iuge been and trewe
(base) Ye shul noon oother ende / with me maken
(base) That oon of yow / ne shal be deed / or taken
(base) And if yow thynketh / this is wel ysayd
(base) Sey youre auys / and holdeth yow apayd
(base) This is youre ende / and youre conclusioun
(base) ¶ Who looketh lightly now / but Palamoun
(base) Who spryngeth vp for ioye / but Arcite
(base) Who koude telle / or who koude it endite
(base) The ioye / that is maked in the place
(base) Whan Theseus / hath doon so fair a grace
(base) But doun on knees / wente euery maner wight
(base) And thonken hym / with al hir herte and myght
(base) And namely the Thebans ofte sythe

div.l: (base) They take hir leeue / and homward gonne they ryde

(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars secunda

(base) I trowe / men wolde deme it necligence
(base) If I foryete / to tellen the despence
(base) Of Theseus / that gooth so bisily

(base) That swich a noble Theatre / as it was

(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit

(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse

(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue

div.l: (base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie

(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland

(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces

div.l: (base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see

(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge

div.l: (base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two
(base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
(base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /

div.l: (base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel

div.l: (base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie

div.l: (base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone

div.l: (base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas

(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle

(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye

(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name

div.l: (base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge

div.l: (base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak

(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte

(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer

(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge

div.l: (base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree

(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour

div.l: (base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron

div.l: (base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go

div.l: (base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere

div.l: (base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge

(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial

(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde

(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye

div.l: (base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte
(base) For right anon / oon of the fyres queynte
(base) And quyked agayn / and after that anon
(base) That oother fyr was queynt and al agon
(base) And as it queynte / it made a whistlynge

div.l: (base) As it were / blody dropes many oon

(base) For she ne wiste / what it signyfied
(base) But oonly for the feere / thus hath she cryed
(base) And weep / that it was pitee for to heere
(base) ¶ And therwithal / Diane gan appeere
(base) With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
(base) And seyde doghter / stynt thyn heuynesse
(base) Among the goddes hye / it is affermed

(base) Thou shalt be wedded / vnto oon of tho

(base) Fare wel / for I ne may no lenger dwelle
(base) The fires / whiche that on myn Auter brenne
(base) Shul thee declaren / er that thow go henne
(base) Thyn auenture of loue / as in this cas
(base) And with that word / the Arwes in the Caas
(base) Of the goddesse / clateren faste and rynge
(base) And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
(base) For which / this Emelye astoned was
(base) And seyde / what amounteth this allas
(base) I putte me / in thy proteccioun
(base) Diane / and in thy disposicioun
(base) And hoom she gooth anoon / the nexte weye
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ The nexte houre of Mars / folwynge this
(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is

div.l: (base) Of fierse Mars / to doon his sacrifise
(base) With alle the rytes / of his payen wise
(base) With pitous herte / and heigh deuocioun
(base) Right thus to Mars / he seyde his orisoun
(base) ¶ O stronge god / that in the regnes colde
(base) Of Trace / honoured art and lord yholde
(base) And hast in euery regne / and euery lond
(base) Of armes / al the brydel in thyn hond
(base) And hem fortunest as thee list deuyse
(base) Accepte of me / my pitous sacrifise
(base) If so be / that my youthe may disserue
(base) And that my myght be worthy for to serue
(base) Thy godhede / that I may be oon of thyne
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to rewe vpon my pyne
(base) For thilke peyne / and thilke hote fyr
(base) In which / thow whilom brendest for desir
(base) Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
(base) Of faire yonge / fresshe Venus free
(base) And haddest hire / in armes at thy wille
(base) Although thee ones / on a tyme mysfille
(base) Whan Vulcanus / hadde caught thee in his laas
(base) And foond thee lyggyng by his wyf allas
(base) For thilke sorwe / that was in thyn herte
(base) Haue routhe as wel / vpon my peynes smerte
(base) I am yong / and vnkonnyng as thow woost /
(base) And as I trowe / with loue offended moost
(base) That euere was / any lyues creature
(base) For she that dooth me / al this wo endure
(base) Ne reccheth neuere / wher I synke or fleete

div.l: (base) And wel I woot er she me mercy heete
(base) I moot with strengthe / wynne hire in the place
(base) And wel I woot withouten help and grace
(base) Of thee / ne may my strengthe noght auaille
(base) Thanne help me lord / tomorwe in my bataille
(base) For thilke fyr / that whilom brende thee
(base) As wel as thilke fyr / now brenneth me
(base) And do that I tomorwe / may haue victorie
(base) Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
(base) Thy souereyn temple / wol I moost honouren
(base) Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
(base) In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
(base) And in thy temple / I wol my baner honge
(base) And alle the armes / of my compaignye
(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde
(base) And eek to this auow / I wol me bynde
(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown
(base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun
(base) Of Rasour / nor of Shere / I wol thee yiue
(base) And been thy trewe seruant whil I lyue
(base) Now lord haue routhe / vpon my sorwes soore
(base) Yif me the victorie / I axe thee namoore
(base) ¶ The prayere stynt of Arcita the stronge
(base) The rynges / on the temple dore that honge
(base) And eek the dores / clatereden ful faste
(base) Of which Arcita / som what hym agaste
(base) The fires brende / vpon the Auter brighte
(base) That it gan al the temple for to lighte

div.l: (base) A swete smel / anoon the ground vp yaf
(base) And Arcita / anoon his hand vp haf
(base) And moore encens / in to the fyr he caste
(base) With othere rytes mo / and at the laste
(base) ¶ The statue of Mars / bigan his hauberk rynge
(base) And with that sown / he herde a murmurynge
(base) Ful lowe and dym / and seyde thus / victorie
(base) For which / he yaf to Mars / honour and glorie
(base) ¶ And thus with ioye / and hope / wel to fare
(base) Arcite anoon / vnto his In is fare
(base) As fayn as fowel / is of the brighte sonne
(base) ¶ And right anoon / swich stryf ther is bigonne
(base) For thilke grauntyng in the heuene aboue
(base) Bitwixe Venus / the goddesse of loue
(base) And Mars / the sterne god armipotente
(base) That Iuppiter / was bisy it to stente
(base) Til that the pale / Saturnus the colde
(base) That knew so manye / of auentures olde
(base) Foond in his olde experience / an art
(base) That he ful soone / hath plesed euery part
(base) As sooth is seyd / elde hath greet auantage
(base) In elde / is bothe wisdom and vsage
(base) Men may the olde at renne / and nat atrede
(base) Saturne anoon / to stynten stryf and drede
(base) Al be it that it is agayn his kynde
(base) Of al this stryf he kan remedie fynde
(base) ¶ My deere doghter Venus / quod Saturne
(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne
(base) Hath moore power / than woot any man
(base) Myn is the drenchyng in the See so wan

div.l: (base) Myn is the prison / in the derke cote
(base) Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
(base) The murmur / and the cherles rebellynge
(base) The groynyng and the pryuee empoysonynge
(base) I do vengeance / and pleyn correccioun
(base) Whil I dwelle / in the signe of the leoun
(base) Myn is the ruyne / of the heighe halles
(base) The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
(base) Vpon the Mynour / or the Carpenter
(base) I slow Sampson / shakyng the piler
(base) And myne be / the maladies colde
(base) The derke tresons / and the castes olde
(base) My lookyng is the fader of pestilence
(base) Now weep namoore / I shal doon diligence
(base) That Palamon / that is thyn owene knyght
(base) Shal haue his lady / as thow hast hym hight
(base) Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yet nathelees
(base) Bitwixe yow / ther moot be som tyme pees
(base) Al be ye noght of o complexioun
(base) That causeth al day / swich diuisioun
(base) I am thyn Aiel / redy at thy wille
(base) Weep now namoore / I wol thy lust fulfille
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynten / of the goddes aboue
(base) Of Mars / and of Venus / goddesse of loue
(base) And telle yow / as pleynly as I kan
(base) The grete effect. for which that I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit tercia pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitʳ pars quarta ~
(base) ¶ Greet was the feeste / in Atthenes that day
(base) And eek the lusty sesoun / of that May
(base) Made euery wight to been in swich plesaunce

div.l: (base) That al that monday / Iusten they and daunce
(base) And spenden it in Venus heigh seruyse
(base) And by the cause / that they sholde ryse
(base) Erly / for to seen the grete sight
(base) Vnto hir reste / wente they at nyght
(base) And on the morwe / whan the day gan sprynge
(base) Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
(base) Ther was in hostelryes / al aboute
(base) And to the paleys / rood ther many a route
(base) Of lordes / vpon steedes and palfreys
(base) Ther maist thow seen / deuysynge of harneys
(base) So vnkouth / and so ryche / and wroght so weel
(base) Of Goldsmythrye / of Broudyng and of steel
(base) The sheldes brighte / testers / and trappures
(base) Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes / cote armures
(base) Lordes in parementz / on hir coursers
(base) Knyghtes of retenue / and eek Squyers
(base) Nailynge the speres / and the helmes bokelynge
(base) Gyggynge of sheeldes / with layners lasynge
(base) Ther as nede is / they were no thyng ydel
(base) The fomy steedes / on the golden brydel
(base) Gnawynge / and faste the Armurers also
(base) With fyle and hamer / prykyng to and fro
(base) Yemen on foote / and communes many oon
(base) With shorte staues / thikke as they may goon
(base) Pipes / trompes / Nakers / Claryounes
(base) That in the bataille / blowen blody sownes
(base) The paleys ful of peples / vp and down

div.l: (base) Deuynynge / of thise Thebans knyghtes two
(base) Somme seyde thus / somme seyden it shal be so
(base) Somme helden with hym / with the blake berd
(base) Somme with the balled / somme with the thikke herd
(base) Somme seyde / he looked grym / and he wolde fighte
(base) He hath a Sparth / of twenty pound of wighte
(base) Thus was the halle / ful of deuynynge
(base) Longe after / that the sonne gan to sprynge
(base) ¶ The grete Theseus / that of his sleep awaked
(base) With mynstralcye / and noyse that was maked
(base) Held yet the chambres / of his paleys ryche
(base) Til that the Theban knyghtes / bothe yliche
(base) Honoured /. weren in to the Paleys fet
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / is at a wyndow set
(base) Arrayed / right as he weere a god in Trone
(base) The peple preeseth / thiderward ful soone
(base) Hym for to seen / and doon heigh reuerence
(base) And eek / to herkne his heste / and his sentence
(base) ¶ An heraud on a Scaffold / made an .oo.
(base) Til al the noyse / of the peple was ydo
(base) And whan he say the peple / of noyse al stille

(base) ¶ The lord hath / of his heighe discrecioun
(base) Considred / that it were destruccioun
(base) To gentil blood / to fighten in the gyse
(base) Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
(base) Wher fore / to shapen / that they shal noght dye
(base) He wole / his firste purpos modifie
(base) ¶ No man therfore / vpon peyne / of los of lyf

div.l: (base) No manere shot ne polax / ne short knyf

(base) No man ne drawe / ne bere it by his syde
(base) Ne no man / shal vnto his felawe ryde

(base) Foyne if hym list on foote / hymself to were
(base) Ne noman so hardy this ordenaunce forto breke
(base) And he that is at meschief / shal be take
(base) And noght slayn / but be broght vnto the stake
(base) That shal been ordeyned / on eyther syde
(base) But thider he shal bi force / and ther abyde
(base) And if so falle / the Chiefteyn be take
(base) On outher syde / or ellis sleen his make
(base) No lenger / shal the tourneying laste
(base) God spede yow / go forth and ley on faste
(base) With long swerd / and with mace / fighteth your fille
(base) Go now youre wey / this is the lordes wille
(base) ¶ The voys of peple / touched the heuene
(base) So loude cryde they / with loude steuene
(base) God saue swich a lord / that is so good
(base) He wilneth / no destruccioun of blood
(base) ¶ Vp goon the trompes / and the melodye
(base) And to the lystes / ryt the compaignye
(base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye

div.l: (base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree

(base) It nas nat of the day / yet fully pryme
(base) ¶ Whan set was Theseus / ful ryche and hye
(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye
(base) And othere ladyes / in degrees aboute

(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte

(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun

(base) So euene / withouten variacioun

(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon
(base) That in hir nombre / gyle were ther noon

(base) Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
(base) ¶ The heraudes / lefte hir prikyng vp and down

div.l: (base) In goon the speres / ful sadly in the arest
(base) In gooth the sharpe spore / in to the syde
(base) Ther seen men / who kan Iuste / and who kan ryde
(base) Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
(base) He feeleth / thurgh the herte spoon the prykke
(base) Vp spryngeth speres / twenty foot on highte
(base) Out goon the swerdes / as the siluer brighte

(base) He thurgh the thikkest of the throng gan threste
(base) Ther stomblen steedes stronge / and doun gooth al
(base) He rolleth vnder foot as dooth a bal
(base) He foyneth on his feet with his tronchoun

(base) He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake
(base) Maugree his heed / and broght vnto the stake
(base) As forward was / right there he moste abyde
(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo

(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte

div.l: (base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood

(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite

(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
(base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun

(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught

(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun
(base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
(base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon

(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye

div.l: (base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne

(base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue

(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
(base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille

(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye

(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite

(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon
