(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
¶ Here endith the knyghtis tale¶ The Prolog . of the Millers tale
WHan that the knyght . had thus his tale I told
In al the compaignie . nas ther yong ne old
That he ne seide . It was a noble storie
And worthy for to be drawen . in memorye
And namly the gentils . eủer/reychon
Oure host lough . and swore so mote I gon
This goth a right . vnbokeled is the male
Late se now . who shal telle another tale
For triewly the game . is wele bigonne
Now tellith ye ʆser/sir monke . if that ye konne
Som what to qwite . to xx the knyghtes tale
The Miller that for drunk . was al pale
So that vnneth . vpon his hors he sat
He nold avale . neyther hoode ne hat
Ne abide noman . of his curtesie
But in Pilates voys . he gan to crye
And swore bi armes . bloode and bones
I can a noble tale . for the nones
With whiche . I wil now . quite the knyghtis tale
Oure host sawe . that he was drunke of ale
And seyde abide Robyn my lief brother
Som bettir man . shal tel vs first another
Abide and lete vs . werken thriftily
Bi goddis sowle . quod he . that wil nat I
For I wil speke . or ellis go my wey
Oure host aunswerde . telle on a devilwey
Thow art a foole . thi wit is oủer/recome
Now herkenyth quod the Miller . al and some
But first I make . a ꝓprotestacioun
That I am dronke . I knowe it be my sowne
And therfor . if I myspeke . or seye
Wite it the Ale of Suthwerk I yow prey
For I wil tel . a legende and a lif
Betwene a carpenter . and his wif
How that a Clerk . set the wrightes cappe
The Rieve aunswerd and saide . stynt thi clappe
Late be thy lewde drunken harlotrie
It is a synne . and eeke a grete folie
To appeyren any man . or hym defame
And eke to bryngen wifes . in suche a blame
Thow mayst I nowgh . of other thynges seyn
This dronken Miller . spak ful soone ageyn
And saide . lief brother Oswold
Who hath no wif . he is no cukold
But I sey nat therfor . that thow art non
Ther bien ful goode wyves . manyon
And eủer/re a thousand goode . agenst on badde
This knowest thow wele . but if thow madde
Why artow angry . with my tale now
I have a wif parde . aswele as thow
Yit nold I for the oxen in my plough
Take vpon me more . than I nawgh
As demen of my self . that I were on
I wele bileeve . that I am non
An husbond . shal nat be . Inquisitiff
Of goddis Privite . and of his wif
So he may fynde . goddis foysoun there
Of the Remenᵃnt . nedith nat to enquere
What shuld I seyn . but this Miller
He nold his wordis . for noman forber
But told his cherols tale . in his manere
Me athynkith that I shal . reherse it here
And therfor eủer/rey gentil wight I pray
Demyth nat for goddis love . that I say
Of evil entent . but for I mote Reherse
Theyr tales all . be they bet or werse
Or ellis falsen . som of my matiere
And therfor who so list nat . ne it to here
Turne oủer/re the lef . and cheese another tale
For he shal fynde I now . grete and smale
Of storial thyng . that towchith gentilnesse
And eeke moralite . and holynesse
Blameth nat me . if ye cheese amys
The Miller is cherol . ye knowe wele this
So was the Rieve eeke . and other moo
And harlotrie they tolden both two
Aviseth yow . and put me out of blame
And eeke men shal nat . make ernest of game
¶ Here bigynneth . the Millers tale
WHilom ther was dwellyng . at Oxenford
A Riche gnof that gestis hadde to bord
And of his craft . he was a Carpentier
With hym was dwellyng . a poore Scoler
Had lierned art . but al his fantasie
Was turned for to lierne Astrologie
And cowde a certeyn . of conclusiouns
To demen . bi Interrogaciouns
What that men askid hym . in certeyn houres
Whether men shuld have drought . or ellis shouris
Or if men askid . what shuld be fall
Of eủer/rey thyng . I may . nat Reken all
This clerk was clepid . hend Nicholas
Of dierne love he cowde . and of solas
And therto he was slygh . and ful prive
And like amaide . meke for to see
A chambre had he . in that hostelerie
Aloon . without . any compaignie
Ful fetisly dight . with herbis swote
And he hym self . as swete as is the Roote
Of licorice . or any Cedwale
Of almageste . bookes grete and smale
His Astrolabie . longyng for his art
His Augrym stones . layen ful faire apart
On shelvis cowched . at his beddis hede
His presse coủer/reed . with a faldyng rede
And al above ther lay . a gay sawtrie
On whiche he made . on nyghtes melodie
So swetely . that al the . chambre Rong
And Angelus ad Virginem he song
And after that he song . the kynges note
Ful oft blissed . was his myrry throte
And thus this swete clerk . his tyme spent
After his friendis fyndyng . and his Rent
This carpentier had weddid . newe a wif
Whiche that he loved . more than his lif
Of . xviij . yeere she was of aage
Ialous he was . and hield hir narow in cage
For she was wield . yong . and he was old
And demed hym self . be like a cookold
He knew nat Caton for his wit was Rude
That biddith aman . wedde his similitude
Men shuld wedde . after theye estate
For yowth and eld . is oft at debate
But sithen he was . falle in the snare
He must endure . as other folk his care
Faire was this yonge wif . and ther with al
As any wesil . hir body gent and smal
A seynt she wered . barred al of silke
A barme cloth . as white as morne mylke
Vpon hir liendes ful of many a gore
White was hir smok . and broyded al bifore
And eeke behynd . on hir coler aboute
With cole blac silke . withynne and eeke withoute
The tapes . of hir white Volupier
Were of the same sute . of hir coler
Hir fillet brode of silk . and sat ful hie
And sikerly she had . a likerous eye
Ful smale pulle . were hir brawes twoo
And tho were bent . and blac as any sloo
She was more blisful . vnto see
Than is the newe . ꝐPer/Parionet tree
And softer than the wulle . of a wether
And bi hir girdel . hyng a purs of lether
Tasseld with silk . and ꝑper/parled with latou
In al this world . to seeken vp and doun
Ther was noman so wise . that cowde thenche
So gay a pupelot . or suche awenche
Ful brighter was the shyneng of hir hewe
That in the toure . the noble forged newe
And of hir song . it was so lowd and yerne
As any swalow . chit̉er/reyng on a berne
Therto she cowde skippe . and make game
As any kidde or calf . folwyng the dame
Hir mowth was swetter . than braket or the meth
Or hoord of Apples . laid in hey or heth
Wynsyng she was . as is a Ioly colt
Long as a Mast . vpright as a bolt
A broche she bare . vpon hir lawe Colier
As brode as is the boose . of a bokelier
Hir shon were lacid . on hir leggis hye
She was a Prymerol . a pigges nye
For any lord . to leggen in his bedde
Or yit . for any goode yoman to wedde
Now ʆser/sir and eft sir . so bifel the caas
That on a day . this hend Nicholas
Fil with this yong wif . to Rage and to play
While that hir husbond . was at Osenay
As clerkis bien . ful subtil and fulqweynte
And prively he caught hir . bi the qweynte
And saide I wis . but I have my wille
For dierne love of the . lemman I spille
And hield hir hard bi the haunche bones
And saide lemman . love me atones
Or I wil dey . also god me save
And she sprong . as a colt in the trave
And with hir hed . she wryed fast awey
She saide I wil nat . kisse the be my fay
Whi late be quod she . lat be Nicholas
Or I wil cry out . harrow and Alas
Do wey yowre handis . for yowre curtesie
This Nicholas gan mercy . for to crye
And spak so faire . and proferd hir so fast
That she hir love hym grauntid . at the last
And swore hir oth bi seynt Thomas of kent
That she wold be . at his comaundement
Whan that she may hir leiser wele espie
Myn husbond is . so ful of Ialousie
That but ye waite wele . and bien prive
I wott right wele . I am but ded quod she
Ye must be ful dierne . as in this case
Nay therof care the nought . quod Nicholas
A Clerk had litherly . biset his while
But if he cowde . a cely carpentir beguyle
And thus they bien accordid . and I sworn
To ho waite a tyme . as I have told aforn
Whan Nicholas had don thus . eủer/reydele
And thakked hir . vpon the liendis wele
He kissed hir swete . and takith his sawtrie
And pleyeth fast . and makith melodie
Than fel it thus . that to the parissh chirche
Cristes owne werkes . for to werche
This goode wif went . on anhaliday
Hir forhed shoone . as bright as any day
So was it wasshen . whan she lete hir werk
Now was ther . of the chirche a parissh clerk
The whiche that was clepid absolon
Crul was his her . and as the gold it shoon
And strowted as a fanne . large and brode
Ful streight and evene . lay his Ioly shoode
His Rudde was Rede . his eyen gray as goos
With Poulys wyndows . corven on his shoos
In hoses Rede . he went fetisly
I clothed he was . ful smal and propirly
Al in a kirtil . of light wachet
Ful faire and thykke bien the poyntes I sette
And thervpon he had . a gay surplise
As whit as the blossom vpon the Rise
A myrrie chield he was . so god me save
Wele cowde he lete bloode . clippe and shave
And make a charter of lond . and acquitaunce
And on twenty man . cowde he trippe and daunce
After the scoole . of Oxenford tho
And with his legges . casten to and fro
And pleyen songes . on a small Ribible
Therto he song sumtyme . a lawde qwynible
And aswele cowde he pley . on a gyterne
In al the hous . nas brewhouse ne taủer/rene
That he ne visite it . with his solas
There any gay . galaunt tapster was
But soth to say . he was sumdel squaymous
Of fartyng . and of speche daungerous
This Absolon that Ioly was and gay
Goth with a sencer . on the haliday
Sensyng the wifes of the ꝑper/parissh fast
And many a lovely looke . on hem he cast
And namly . on this carpent̉er/res wif
To looke on hir . hym thought a myrry lif
She was so propre . swete and likerous
I dare wele seyn . if she had bien amous
And he a cat . he wold hir hent anon
This parissh clerk . this Absolon
Hath in his herte . a love longyng
That of no wif . toke he non offryng
For curtesie he seide he wold non
The Moone whan it was nyght . x ful bright shoon
And Absolon his guytern hath I take
For paramour . he thought for to wake
And furth he goth . Ioly . and amerous
Til he com . to the carpenters hous
A litel after Cokkis . had I crowe
And dressid hym vp . bi ashot wyndowe
That was vpon . the carpenters wal
He syngith in his voice . gentil and smal
Now dere lady . if thy wil be
I pray yow that ye wil rewe on me
Ful wele accordaunt . to his gyternyng
The Carpenter a woke . and herd hym syng
And spak vnto his wif . and saide anon
What Alisoun . heristow nat absolon
That chauntis thus . vndir oure bowres wal
And she aunswerd hir husbond . therwith al
Yis god wote Iohn I here it eủer/reydele
This passith furth . what wil ye bet than wele
From day to day . this Ioly Absolon
So wowith hir . that hym is wo bigon
He wakith al the nyght . and al the day
He kembith his lokkis a brode . and made hym gay
He wowith hir bi meanes . and brocage
And swore he wold . be hir owne page
He syngith brokkyng . as a nyghtyngale
He sent hir pyment Meth and spiced ale
And wafres pipyng hote . out of the glede
And for she was of towne . he proferd mede
For som folke wilbe wonnen bi Richesse
And som for strokes . and som bi gentilnesse
Vnde Ovidius Ictibus agrestis . and maistrae
He playeth herowd . vpon a scafold hie
But what availeth hym . in this caas
She lovith so . this hend Nicholas
That Absolon may blowe . the bukkes horn
He ne hath for al his labour . but askorn
And thus she makith Absolon hir ape
And al his ernest . turnyth to a Iape
For soth is this ꝓprouerbe . it is no lye
Men seyn right thus . alwey the nyghslye
Absence makith . the fer lief to be loth
For though that Absolon . be woode and wroth
Bi cause that he fer was from hir sight
This nygh Nicholas stoode in his light
Now bere the wele . thow hend Nicholas
For Absolon may waile . and synge alas
And so bi fel it . that on a satirday
This carpentier was gon to Osenay
And hend Nicholas . and Alisoun
Accordid bien . to this conclusioun
That Nicholas shal shapen hym a wile
This cely Ialous husbond . for to be guyle
And if so were . the game go aright
She shuld slepe in his armes . al that nyght
This was his desire . and hirs also
And right anon . without wordis mo
This Nicholas no lengger wold tarie
But doeth ful soft . vnto his chambre carie
Both mete and drynk . for a day or twey
And to hir husbond . bad hir to sey
If that he asked . after Nicholas
She shuld sey . she nyst wher he was
Of al that day . she sigh hym nat with eye
She trowed that he was in som maladie
For no cry hir maide . cowde hym calle
He nold aunswer . for nothyng that myght falle
This passith furth . al thilke Satirday
That Nicholas . in his chambre lay
And eete and sleepe . and dide what hym lest
Til Soneday that the sonne . goth to Rest
This cely carpenter . hath grete mvaile
Of Nicholas . or what thyng myght hym ayle
And saide I am adrad bi seynt Thomas
It standith nat a Right . with Nicholas
God shield that he deyde . sodainly
This world is ful tikel . now sikerly
I say to day a corps . born to chirche
That now a monday last . I saw hym wirche
Go vp quod he . to his knave anon
Clepe at his doore . or knok with aston
Loke how it is . and tel me boldelie
This knave goth hym vp ful sturdilye
And cryed and knokked . as he were woode
At the chambre doore . while that he stoode
What how what do ye . Maister Nicholay
How may ye sleepen . al the lang day
But al for nought . herd nat oo word
Anhole he fonde ful lowe vpon a bord
Wher as the catte . was wont in for to crepe
And at that hoole . he looked in ful deepe
And at the last . he had of hym a sight
This Nicholas sat . gapyng vpright
As he had kiked . after newe moone
Adoun he goth . and told his Maister soone
In what array . he saw this ilk man
This carpenter to blissen hym began
He saide help vs . seynt Fritheswide
A man wote ful lite . what shal hym be tide
This man is falle . with his Astronomye
In som woodenesse . or som Agonye
I thought ay wele . how that it shuld be
Men shuld nat knowe . of goddis privite
Ye blissed be alwey . a lewde man
That nought only . his bileve can
So fierd another clerk with Astronomye
He walked in the fieldis . for to prie
Vpon the sterris . what ther shuld falle
Til he was in a Marlepitte I falle
He saw nat that but yit bi seynt Thomas
Me Rewith sore . of hend Nicholas
He shalbe Ratid . of his studyeng
If that I may . bi Ihıı̄uns hevene kyng
Gete me astaf . that I may vndirspoore
While that thow Robyn hevest vp the dore
He shal out of his studyeng . as I gesse
And to the chambre dore . he gan hym dresse
His knave was a strong carle . for the nones
And bi the haspe have it vp atones
In to the floore . the doore fel anon
This Nicholas sat ay stille . as a ston
And eủer/re gapid vp . in to the eyre
This carpentier wend he were in dispeyre
And hent hym bi the shuldres . myghtily
And shooke hym harde . and cryed spitously
What Nicholas what how looke adoun
A wake and thynk on Cristes passioun
I crowche from Elves . and from wightis
Therwith the nyght spel . saide he anon rightis
On foure halves . the house aboute
And on the thresshold . the doore withoute
Ihıı̄uns Crist . and seynt benedict
Blesse this house . from eủer/rey wikkid wight
From the nyghtismare . the white Pater noster
Where wonestow . seynt Petirs sustir
And at the last . this hende Nicholas
Gan for to sigh sore . and saide Alas
Shal al the world be lost . eftsones now
This carpentier aunswerd . what seistow
What thynk on god . as we don men that swynke
This Nicholas aunswerde . fecche me drynke
And after wil I speke . in privite
Of certayn thyng . that towchith the and me
I wil tel it nonother man certayn
This carpenter goth doun and comyth agayn
And brought of myghti ale . a large quart
And whan eche of hem . had dronken his part
This Nicholas his doore . fast shette
And doun the carpentier bi hym sette
And saide Iohn myn host lief and diore
Thow shalt vpon thy trowth . swere me here
That thow to no wight . shal this counsail wrey
For it is Cristes counsail . that I sey
And if thow it tel any man . thow art forlore
For this vengeaunce . thow shalt have therfore
That if thow wrey me . thow shalt be woode
Nay crist forbede . for his holy bloode
Quod tho this cely man . I nam no labbe
And though I sey it . I am nat lief to gabbe
Sey what thow wilt . I shal it neủer/re telle
To chield ne wif . bi hym that harwid helle
Now Iohn quod Nicholas I wil nat lie
I have I founde . in myn Astrologie
As I have looked . in the Moone bright
That now a monday next . at quart̉er/re nyght
Shal fal a Rayne . that half so wield and woode
Ne half so grete . was neủer/re Noes floode
This world he saide . in lasse than in an hour
Shalbe dreynt . so hidous . is the showr
Thus shal mankynd drenche . and leese theyr lif
This carpenter aunswerd . alas my wif
And shal she drenche . alas my Alisoun
For feere of this . he fil adoun
And saide is ther no remedie in this caas
Why yis forgod . quod hend Nicholas
If thow wilt werk . after loore and Rede
Thow maist nat werke . aftir thyn owne hede
For thus seith Salamom . that was ful triewe
Werke all bi counsail . and thow shalt neủer/re Rewe
And if thow werk wilt . bi goode counsaile
I vndirtake . with out mast or saile
Yit shal I save hir . the and me
Hastow nat herd . how saved was Noe
That oure lord warned . hym be forn
That al the world . with water shuld be lorn
Yis quod this carpenter . ful yore ago
Hastow nat herd . quod Nicholas also
The sorwe of Noe . with his felawship
Er that he myght . gete his wif to ship
Hem hadde wele lever . I dare wele vndirtake
At thilke tyme than al his wethers blake
That she hadde had ashippe . hir self alone
And therfor wostow . what is best to done
This askith hast . and of anhasty thyng
Men may nat preche . ne make taryeng
Anon go gete vs . fast in to this Inne
Of knedyng trowghes . or ellis kemylyne
For eche of vs . but looke that they be large
In whiche we mowe swymme . as in a barge
And have thern vitaile . sufficiaunt
But for a day . fy on the Remenᵃnt
The water shal a slake . and gon a way
Aboute pryme . on the next day
But Robyn may nat wite of this . thy knave
Ne thy mayde Gille I may nat save
Aske nat why . for though thow aske me
I wil nat tellen . goddis privite
Sufficith the . but if thi wittis madde
To have as grete a grace . as Noe hadde
Thy wif shal I wele save . out of doute
Go now thy wey . and spede the here aboute
Whan thow hast for hir . the and me
I geten vs . thiese knedyng tubbes thre
Than shaltow hange hem . in the Roof ful hie
That noman . of oure purviaunce aspie
And whan thow hast don . as I have saide
And hast oure vitaile . faire in hem laide
And eke anaxe . to smyte the cord atwo
Whan that the water comyth . that we may go
And breke anhole out . oủer/re the gable
Vnto the gardyn ward . oủer/re the stable
That we may frely passen . furth our wey
Whan that the grete shoure . is gon awey
Than shaltow swymme . as myrry I vndertake
As doth the white . after the drake
Than wil I clepe . how Alisoun how Iohn
Be myrry for the floode . wil passe anon
And thow wilt sey . haile Maister Nicholay
Goode morow I see the wele . for it is day
And than shuln we bien lordis al oure lyf
Of al the world . as Noe and his wif
But of oothyng . I warne the fulright
Be wele avised . on that ilke nyght
That we bien entred . in to oure shippes boord
That non of vs . ne speke nat oo word
Ne clepe ne crye . but be in his prayer
For it is goddis owne . heste diere
Thy wif and thow . mote hang fer asunder twynne
For that betwixt yow . shalbe no synne
No more in lookyng . than ther shal in dede
This ordynaunce . go god the spede
To morow at nyght . whan al folk bien a sleepe
In to oure knedyng troughes . wil we crepe
And sitte there . abidyng goddis grace
Go now thy way . I have no lengger space
To make of this no lengger ʆser/sirmonyng
Men seyn thus . send the wise and sey nothyng
Thow art so wise it nedith nat the to teche
Go save oure lives . I the beseche
This cely carpenter . goth furth his way
Ful oft he saide . alas and welaway
And told his wif . al his Privite
And she was ware . and knew it bet than he
What althis qweynt craft . was to sey
But natheles she ferd . as she wold dey
And saide alas . go furth a non
Help vs to scape . or we bien ded echon
I am thy triew . verray weddit wif
Go diere spouse . and help to save oure lif
Lo whiche a grete thyng . is affeccioun
Aman may deye . of Imagynacioun
So deepe may . inpressioun be take
This cely carpenter . bigynnyth to qwake
Hym thynkith verily . that he may see
Noes floode com walwyng . as the see
To drenchen Alisoun . his hony diere
He wepith wailith . and makith sory chiere
He sighith with ful many . a sory swough
And goth and getith hym . a knedyng trough
And after that a tubbe . and a kemelyn
And prively sent hem to his In
And hyng hem in the Roof in Privite
His owne hand . made laddres thre
To clymben bi the ronges . and the stalkes
Vnto the tubbes . hangyng in the balkes
And hem vitailed . both trough and tubbe
With brede and chese . and goode ale in a Iubbe
Sufficyng right I now . as for oo day
But or than he had made . althis array
He sent his knave . and his wenche also
Vpon his nede . to london for to go
And vpon the monday . whan it drew tonyght
He shitte his doore . with out any candel light
And dressid althyng . as it shuld be
And shortly to seyn . they clomben vp al thre
And seten stille . wele afurlong wey
Now Pater noster . clum seide Nicholay
And clum saide Iohn . Clum . quod Alisoun
This carpenter . saide his devocioun
And stille he sittith . and biddith his prayer
Waityng on the Rayne . if he it here
The ded sleepe . for verray busynesse
Fell on this carpenter . sothly as I gesse
About Courfiew tyme . or litel more
For travailyng of his gost . he gronyth sore
And oft he Rowted . for his hed myslay
Doun on the ladder . stalkith Nicholay
And Alisoun . ful soft adoun she spedde
Without wordis mo . gon they to bedde
Ther as the carpentier . was wont to lie
Ther was the Revel . and the Melodye
And thus is Alisoun and Nicholas
In busynesse of myrth and of solas
Til that the Belle of laudes . gan to Ryng
And freris in the chauncel . gan to syng
The Parissh clerk . this amerous Absolon
That is for love . so wo bigon
Vpon the Monday . was at Osenay
With compaignie . hym to disport and pley
And asked vpon cas . a cloystrer
Ful prively after Iohn the carpenter
And he drough hym apart . out of chirche
And saide I saw hym . here nat werche
Sith satirday . I trowe that he be went
For tymber there oure Abbot . hath hym sent
For he is wont for tymber for to go
And dwellen at the graunge . a day or two
Or ellis he . is . at his house certayn
Where that he be . I can nat sothly sayn
This Absolon ful Iolif . was and wight
And thought now is tyme . to wake alnyght
For sikerly . I saw hym nat stiryng
About his doore sith day bigan to spryng
So mote I thryve . I shal at Cokkescrowe
Ful prively knokken . at his wyndowe
That stant ful lowe . vpon his bowres wal
To Alisoun . now wil I tellen al
My love longyng. for yit I shal nat mysse
That at the lest wey yit I shal hir kisse
Som maner comfort . shal I have ꝑper/parfay
My mowth hath Icched . al this long day
That is a signe . of kissyng at the leste
Alnyght I dreamed . that I was at a feste
Therfor I wil go sleepe . anhoure or twey
And althe nyght wil I walke and pley
Whan that the first cok had crowe Anon
Vprist this Ioly lover Absolon
And hym arraieth gay . at Poynt devise
But first he chewid grayn and licorise
To smellen swete . or he had kembed his her
Vndir his tunge . a triew love he ber
For therby he wend . to be gracious
And forth he Rometh . to the carpent̉er/res hous
And stil he stant vndir the shot wyndow
Vnto his brest it raught . it was so low
And soft he cought with a semy sowne
What do ye honycombe . swete Alisoun
My faire bridde . my swete Synamome
A wakith lemman myn . and speke tome
Wel litel thynk ye . vpon my wo
That I for yowre love . swelt ther I go
No wounder is . though I swelt or swete
I moorne as doth the lamb . after the teete
I wis lemman . I have suche love longyng
That like a Turtil triewe . is my mornyng
I may nat ete namore . than may a maide
Go fro my wyndow . Iak foole she saide
As help me god . it wil nat be com pame
I love another . and ellis I were to blame
Wele bet than the . bi Ihu Absolon
Go furth thy wey . or I wil cast a ston
And lete me sleepe . a twenty devil way
Alas quod Absolon and welaway
That triew love was eủer/re . so evil be set
Than kisse me . sith it may be no bet
For Ihus love . and for the love of me
Wiltow thanne . go thy way quod she
Ye certis lemman . quod this Absolon
Than make the redy quod she . I com anon
This Absolon doun set hym . on his knees
And saide I am a lord . at al degres
For after this I hope . ther comyth more
Lemman thi grace . and swete bridde thyn ore
The wyndow she vndoth . and that in hast
Have do quod she com of . and speede the fast
Lest that oure neyghburghs . the aspie
This Absolon gan wipe . his mowth ful drye
Derk was the nyght . as piche or ellis the cole
And at the wyndow . she put out hir hole
And Absolon hym felt no bet ne wers
But with his mowth he kissed hir naked ars
Ful sauourly . or he were ware of this
A bak he stirt . and thought it was a mys
For wele he wist . a womman hath no berd
He felt athyng alrowgh . and long I herid
And seyde fy alas . what have I do
Tehee quod she . and clapped the wyndow to
And Absolon goth furth a sory pas
A berd a berd . quod hend Nicholas
Bi goddis corpus . this goth faire and wele
This cely Absolon herd eủer/rey dele
And on his lippe . he gan for anger bite
And to hym self he saide . I shal the qwite
Who Rubbith now . who froteth now his lippes
With dust with sand . with straw with cloth with chippes
But Absolon that ful oft seide alas
My sowle be take I . vnto Sathanas
But me were leủer/re . than al this towne quod hee
Of I this dispite . a wroken for to be
Alas quod he Alas . I ne hadde I blent
His hote love was cold . and al I qweynt
For from tyme . that he had I kist hir ars
Of paramours . sette he nat a kers
For he was helid . of that maladie
Ful oft paramours . he gandefie
And wept as doeth a chield . that is I bete
A softe pas . he went oủer/re the strete
Vnto a smyth was callid . Gaun Gervays
That in his forge . smytheth plough harnays
He sharpith share . and cultur busily
This Absolon knokkith . al esily
And saide vndo Geruays and that anon
Who artow . it am I Absolon .
What Absolon . what Cristes swete tree
Why rise ye so rathe . ey benedicite
What eyleth yow . som gay gerl . god it wote
Hath brought yow thus . on the veritot
Bi seynt noote . ye wote what I meane
This Absolon . ne Rought nat a beane
Of al his play . no word agayn he gaf
He had more tow . on his distaf
Than Gervays knew of . and saide friend so dere
That hote cultur . in the chymeny here
So leene it we me . I have therwith to done
I wil bryng it . the agayn ful soone
Gervays aunswerd . certis were it gold
Or in a poke . nobles vntold
Thow shuldest have . as I am triewe smyth
Ey cristes fo . what wil ye do therwith
Therof quod Absolon be as be may
I shal wele tel it the . another day
And caught the cultour . bi the cold stele
Ful soft out of the doore . gan he stele
And went vnto . the carpent̉er/res wal
He coughed first . and knokked with al
Vpon the wyndow . right as he dide er
This Alisoun aunswerd . who is ther
That knokkith so . I waraunt it a thief
Why nay god wote . my swete lief
I am thyn Absolon . thy derlyng
Of gold quod he . I have the brought a Ryng
My moder yave it me . so god me save
Ful fyne it is . and therto wole I grave
This wil I yeve the . and thow me kisse
This Nicholas was risen for to pisse
And thought he wold amende al the Iape
He shuld kisse his ars . or than he scape
And vp the wyndow . he dide hastily
And out his ars . he puttith prively
Oủer/re the buttok . to the haunche bon
And therwith spak this clerk this Absolon
Speke swete herte . I not where thow art
This Nicholas . anon lete flie a fart
As grete as it hadde bien . a thunder dynt
That wite strok . he was ny blent
And he was redy . with his Irn al hote
And Nicholas . in the ars he smote
Of goth the skynne . anhand brede aboute
The hote cultur . brend so his toute
That for the smerte . he wend for to dye
As he were woode . for feere he gan to crye
Help water water . for goddis herte
This carpenter out . of his slumbre sterte
And herd oon crye water . as he were woode
And thought alas . now cometh Noes floode
He set hym vp . without wordis mo
And with his ax . he smote the cord atwoo
And doun goth he . and fond nothyng to selle
Nother brede nor ale . til he com to the shelle
Vpon the floore . and ther . aswoune he lay
Vp stirt Alisoun vp stirt Nicholay
And cryeden out . and harow . in the strete
The neyghburghs . both smale and grete
In Ronnen . for to gawren on this man
That a swoun lay . both pale and wan
For with the fal . brost he hath his arm
But stond he must . vnto his owne harm
For whan he spak . he was a non bore doun
With hend Nicholas and Alisoun
They told eủer/rey man . that he was woode
He was agast so . of Noes floode
Thurgh fantasie . that of his vanite
He had hym bought . knedyng tubbis thre
And had hem hanged . in the Roof above
And than he praied hem . for goddis love
To sitten in the Roof . ꝑper/par compaignie
The folk gan laughen . at his fantasie
In to the Roof . they kikyn and they gape
And turn al his harm . vnto a Iape
For what so . this carpenter aunswerd
It was for nought . no man his reasoun herd
With othes grete . he was born a doun
That he was holden woode . of al the toun
For eủer/rey clerk . anon Right hield with other
They seyde the man was woode . my lief brother
And eủer/rey wight gan laugh . at this strif
Thus swyved was the carpenters wif
For al his kepyng . and Ialowsie
And Absolon hath kist hir nether eye
And Nicholas is scalded in myddes the toute
This tale is don . and god save al the Route
¶ Here endith teh Millers tale

(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age

(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys

div.l: (base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe

(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl

(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke

(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth

(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne

(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng

div.l: (base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche

(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
(base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue

(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon

Of eloquence . that shalbe thy peere
If that thow lyve . god yeve the goode chaunce
And in vertu sende the contynuaunce
For of thi speche . I have grete deynte
I have a sone . and bi the Trynite
I hadde lever . than .xxᵗⁱ. pound worth land
Though it Right now . were falle in to myn hand
He were a man . of suche discrecioun
As that ye bien . fy on possessioun
But if aman be vertuous with al
I have my sone snybbed . and yit shal
For he to vertu list nat to entende

And leese althat he hath . is his vsage

Where he myght lierne . gentilesse aright
Straw for yowre gentilesse . quod oure host
What Marchaunt parde . wele thow wost
That eche of yow mote tellen at the lest
A tale or two . or breken his bihest
That know I wele ʆser/sir . quod the Marchaunt certayn
I pray yow havith me . nat in disdayn

Telle on thy tale . withoute wordes mo
Gladly ʆser/sir host quod he . I wil obey

I wil yow nat contrarien . in no wise
As fer as that . my wittes wil suffice
I pray to god . that it p may plesen yow
Than wote I wele . that it is goode I now
Whilom ther was dwellyng . in Lumbardye

In whiche he lived . in grete prosperite
And . lx . yeere . a wifles man was he
And folwith ay . his bodily delite
On wymmen . there as was his appetite
As don these fooles . that bien seculier
And whan that he was passed . thre score yeere
Were it for holynesse . or for dotage
I can nat sey . but a suche grete corage
Hadde this knyght . to be a weddit man
That day and nyght . he doeth al that he can
To spyen where he myght . I weddit be
Preyeng oure lord . to graunt hym that he
Might oones knowe . of that blisful lif
That is betwixt . anhusbond and his wif
And for to lyve . vndir that holy band
With whiche that god . man and womman bond
Nonother lif he saide . is worth a beane
For wedlok . is so easy and so clene
That in this world . it is a paradise
Thus sayde this old knyght . that was so wise
And certainly . as soth as god is kyng
To take a wif . it is a glorious thyng
And namly whan a man . is old and hore
Than is a wif . the fruyte of his tresore
Than shuld he take . a yong wif and afaire
On whiche he myght . gete hym anheyre
And lede his lif . in Ioye and solas
Where as thiese bachillers . man syng alas
Whan that they fynde . any aduersite
In love whiche nys . but chieldissh vanite
And triewly it sit . wele to be so
That bachillers have oft peyne and woo
On brotil grounde . they bield brotilnesse
They fynde whan they wene sikernesse
They live but as a bridde . or a beste
In liberte . and vnder non arreste
There as a weddit man . in his estat
Liveth a lif blisful . and ordynat
Vnder the yok . of mariage Ibounde
Wele may his herte . in Ioye and blisse habounde
For who can be so buxoum as a wif
Who so is so triew . and so ententif
To kepe hym sike and hole . as is his make
For wele or wo . she wil hym nat forsake
She is nat wery . hym to love and serve
Though that he lye bedered . til he sterve
And yit som clerkis seyn . it is nat so
Of whiche Theofrast is oon of tho
What fors though Theofrast list for to lye
Ne take no wif quod he . for husbondrye
As for to spare in houshold thy dispence
And a triewe ʆser/siruᵃnt . doeth more diligence
Thy goode to kepe . than thyn owne wif
She wil clayme half part al hir lif
If thow be sike . so god me save
Thy verray friendis . or a triewe knave
Wil kepe the bet . than she that waiteth ay
After thi goode . and hath do many a day
And if thow take awif in dede
In sorow and care . thi lif shaltow leede
This sentence . and anhundred tymes worse
Writith this man . there god his bones curse
But take no kepe . of al suche vanite
Defye Theofrast and herken me
A wif is goddis gift verily
Alother man . yiftis hardily

Or mobles albien yiftes . of fortune

But drede nat . if plainly I speke shal
A wif wil last . and in thyn hous endure
Wel lenger . than the list ꝑper/paraduenture
Mariage is aful grete sacrament
The whiche that hath no wif . I hold hym shent
He liveth helples . and al desolate
I speke of folk . in seculer estate
And herken whi I sey nat this for nought
That womman is . for mannes help wrought
The hye god whan he had Adam maked
And sawe hym alone . bely naked
God of his grete goodenesse . saide thanne
Lat vs now make . an help vnto man
Like to hym self . and than he made Eue
Here may ye see . and here may ye preve
That wif is mannes help . and comfort
His paradis terestre . and his disport
So buxum . and so vertuous is she
They must neodis . live in vnite
O flessh they bien . and oo flessh as I gesse
Hath but on herte . in wele and distresse
A wif . a seynte Marie benedicite
How myght aman . han any aduersite
That hath a wif . certis I can nat sey
The blisse whiche that is betwixt hem twey
Ther may no tunge telle . ne herte thynke
If he be pore . she helpith hym to swynke
She kepith his goode . and wastith neuadele
Al that hir husbond lust . hir likith wele
She seith nat ones nay . whan he saith yee
Do this saith he . al redy ʆser/sir saith she
O blisful order . o wedlok precious
Thow art so murie . and eke so vertuous
And so commendid . and a proued eeke
That my womman . that halt hym worth a leeke
Vpon his knees . ought al his lif
Thank his god that hym hath sent a wif
Or ellis prey to god . hym for to sende
A wif to last . vnto his hiswifes lives ende
He may nat be disceyued as I gesse
For than his lif . is set in sikernesse
So that he werke . after his wifes rede
Than may he boldely . bere vp his hede
They bien so triew . and therwith al so wise
For whiche of yow . wil werken as the wise
Do alwey so as wymmen . wil the Rede
Lo how that Iacob as thiese clerkis Rede

For whiche his fadirs . beneson he wan
Lo Iudith as the storie . eke telle can
Bi goode counsail . goddis people kepte

Bi goode counsail . delyủer/red out of woo

Of Assuere . enhaunsed for to be
Ther nys nothyng . in gre suꝑper/parlatif
As seith Seneca a bove an humble wif
Soeffre thy wifes tunge . as Caton bit
She shal comaunde . and thow shalt sooffre it
And yit she wil obey . of curtesie
A wif is keper . of thy husbondrye
Wele may ye sike men . be waile and wepe
There as ther nys no wif . the hous to kepe
I warne the if thow . wilt wisely wirche
Love wele thy wif . as Crist loved his chirche

She fostrith . and therfor bidde I the
Cherissh thy wif . or thow shalt neủer/rethe

They bien so knyt . ther may non harm betide
And namly . vpon the wifes side
For whiche this Ianuarie that I of told
Considred hath . withyn his dayes old
The lusty lif . the vertuous quiete
That is in mariage . hony swete
And for his friendis . on a day he sente
To tellen theym . theffecte of his entente
With face sad . this tale he hath hem told
He saide friendis . I am hore and old
And almost god wote . at my pittes brynke
Vpon my soule . somwhat must I thynke
I have my body . folily dispendid
Blissed be god . that it shalben amendid
For I wil be certayn . a weddit man
And that anon . in al the haste I can
Vnto som maide . faire and tendre of age
I pray . yow shapith . for my mariage
Al sodainly . for I wil nat abide
And I wil founde . for to espyen on my side
To whom I may be weddid . hastily
But for asmoche . as ye bien more than I
Ye schuln rather . suche a thyng espyen
Than I . and where me best were to alien
But o thyng warne I yow . my friendis deere
I wil non old wif han . in nomanere
She shal nat passe . xx . yeere certayn
Old fissh and yong flessh . wold I have fayn
Bet is quod he a pike . than a pikerel
And better than old bief . is the tendir veel

It is but beane straw . and grete forage

They konne somoche craft . of wades bote

I wil non old wif have . right for this cause

For if so were . I hadde suche myschaunce

Than shuld I leede my lif . in avoutrie

Yit had I lever . houndes had me frete

In straunge handes . and this I tel yow alle
I doote nat . I wote the cause why

But sirs with yowre leve . that am nat I
For god bi thank it . I dare make avaunt
I feele my lymes . strong and sufficiaunt
To do althat . aman be longith to
I wote my self . what I may do
Though I behore . I fare as doeth a tree

Myn herte and al my lymes . bien as greene

Som blame it . som praise it certayn

Ther fil a strif betwixt his brethern two

Ful litel neode hadde ye . my lord so dere

That yow ne likith . for yowre high prudence

This word seide he vnto echeon
Werke althyng bi counsaile . thus saide he
And thow shalt nat . than repenten the
But though that Salamon . spak suche aword

Doeth now in this matiere . right as ye list

Wel moche more . I ought avised be
To whom I yeve my body for alwey
I warne yow wele . it is no chieldis pley
Men must enquere this is myn entent

A Chidester or waster of thy goode

Non in althis world that trottith hole in al

How that ye entren . in to Mariage
And namly . with a yong wif and afaire

The yongest man that is in al this Route

Ye shuln nat pleasen hir . nat fully yeeris thre
This is to seyn . to don hir ful plesaunce
A wif axith . ful many anobseruaunce
I pray yow that ye be nat yvel apaied
Wele quod this Ianuarie . and hastow said

Of scole termes . wiser men than thow
As thow hast herd . assentiden right now
To my purpos . placebo what sey yee

That lettith Matrimony . sikerly
And with that word . they Risen sodeynly

Bien weddid whan hym list . and whan he wold

For hir sadnesse . and hir benyngnite

And som were Riche . and had bad name
But natheles . betwene ernest and game
He at the last apoyntith . hym vpon oon
And lete al the other . from his hert gon
And ches hir . of his owne auctorite
For love is blynd alday . and may nat see
And whan that he was . in his bed I brought
He portreyde in his herte . and in his thought

That Impossible it were . to replie
Agayn his choyse . and his fantasie
His friendis sent he to . at his Instaunce

He wold abrigge they labour . al and some
Nedith nomore for hym . to go ne Ride
He was apoynted . wher he wold abide
Placebo cam . and eeke his friendis soone
And altherfirst . he bad hem al aboone
That non of hem . non argumentis make
Agayn the purpos . whiche that he hath take
Whiche purpos plesaunt . to god saide he
And verray ground . of his ꝓprosꝑper/parite
He saide ther was . a mayde in that towne
Whiche that of beaute . hadde grete Renown
Al were it so . she were of smal degre

And thanked god . that he myght han hir al
That no wight his blisse . parten shal
And preyde hem to labouren . in this Rede
And shapen . that he faile nat to speede
For than he saide . his spirit was at ease
Than is nothyng . that may me displease
Save oothyng prikith . in my conscience
The whiche I wil reherse . in yowre presence
I have quod he herd seid . ful yoore ago
Ther may no man have . ꝑper/parfite blisses two
This is to sey . in erth and eke in heuene
For though he kepe hym from the synnes seuene
And eeke from eủer/rey braunche . of thilke tre
Yit is ther . so ꝑper/parfite felicite
And so gret ease and lust in mariage
That eủer/re I am agast . now in myn age
That I shal leede now . so myrie a lif
So delicat . withouten werre or stryf

For sith that verray heuene . is bought so dere

How shuld I thanne . that live in suche plesaunce
As al men don . with theyr wyves
Come to the blisse . there Crist et̉er/rene on live is
This is my drede . and ye my brethern tweye
Assoileth me this questioun . I yow preye
Iustinus whiche that hatid his folie
Aunswerd anon . right in his Iaperie
And for he wolde . his longe tale a bregge

But ʆser/sir he saide . if ther be non obstacle
Other than this . god of his hye myracle
And of his mercy . may so for yow wirche
That or ye have . the Rightes of holichirche
Ye may repente . of weddid mannes lif
In whiche ye seyn . ther nys no woo ne strif
And ellis god forbede . but he sente
A weddid man hym grace to Repente
Wele ofter . than a sengle man
And therfor ʆser/sir . the best Rede I can
Dispeyrith yow nat . but have in memorie
ꝐPer/Paraduenture she may . be yowre purgatorie
She may be goddis meane . and goddis whippe
Than shal yowre soule . I hope to hevene skippe
Swifter than doeth anarow . out of a bowe
I hope to god herafter . ye shal knowe
That ther nys . no suche felicite
In mariage . ne neủer/re shalbe
That yow shal lette . of yowre saluacioun
So that ye vse . as skille is and reasoun
The lustes of yowre wif . attemprely
And that ye please nat . to amerously
And that ye kepe yow . from other synne
My tale is don . for my wit is thynne
Be nat herof agast . my brother deere
But late vs wade out . of this matiere
The wif of Bath if ye have vndirstande
Of mariage . whiche ye han vndirhande
Declared hath ful wele . in litel space
Farith now wele . god have yow in his grace
And with that word . Iustyn and his brother
Han take theyr leve . and eche of hem of other
For whan they sawe . that it must nedis bee
They wrought so . bi sleight and bi trete
That she this Maide . whiche that Mayus hight
As hastily . as eủer/re she myght
Shal weddid be . vnto this Ianuarie
I trow it were to long . yow to tarie
If I yow told . of eủer/rey script and bond
Bi whiche that she was feffid . in his hond
Or for to herken . of hir Riche array
But fynally I comen . is the day
That to the chirche . both bien they went
For to Resceyve . the holy sacrament
Furth comyth the prist . with stoole a bowte his nekke
And bad hir be like Sarra and Rebek
In wisdom and in trowth of Mariage
And saide his oreisouns . as is vsage
And crowchith theym . and bad god shuld hem blesse
And made al siker Inowgh . with holynesse
Thus bien they weddid . with solempnite
And at the last . sittith he and she
With other worthy folk vpon the deys
Al ful of Ioye and blisse . is the paleys
And ful of Instrumentis . and of vitaile
The most deyntevous . of al Itaile
Beforn hym stoode Instrumentis . of suche soun
That Orpheus nor Thebes Amphioun
Ne made neủer/re . suche a melodie

Ne neủer/re trumped . Iaspus for to here
Ne he Theodomas yit half so cliere
And Thebes whan the citee was in doute
Bachus the wyne . he yaf al aboute
And Venus laughith . vpon eủer/rey wight
For Ianuarie was . bicom hir knyght
And wold both assay . his corage
In liberte . and eke in mariage
And with hir firy firyblondbrond . in hir hand aboute

And certayn . I dare wele sey thus
Imeneus that god of weddyng is
Sawe neủer/re in his lif . so myrie a weddit man
Hold thow thi peas . thow poete Marcian
That writest to vs . thilke weddyng myrie
Of hir philologe . and he M̉er/recurie
And of the songes . that the Muses songe
To smal is both . thy penne and thy tonge
For to discryven . al this Mariage
Whan tendre yowth . hath weddyng stoupyng age
Ther is suche myrth . that it may nat be writen
Assaieth it yowre self . than may ye witen
If that I lie or no . in this matiere
Mayus that sit . with so benyngne chiere
Hir to bihold . it semyth a fayrie
Qwene hester loked neủer/re . with suche an eye
