But thus moche . of hir beaute tel I may
But that she was like . the bright morow of May
Fulfilled of al beaute . and plesaunce
This Ianuarie is Ravisshed . in a traunce
At eủer/rey tyme . he lokid on hir face
But in his herte he gan hir manace
That he that nyght . in armes wold hir streyne
Harder than eủer/re paris dide heleyne
But natheles . yit had he grete pite
That thilke nyght . offenden hir must he
And thought alas . otendre creature
Now wold god . ye myght wele endure
Al my corage . it is so sharp and kene
I am agast . ye shul it nat sustene
But god forbede . I dide al my myght
Now wold god . it were woxen nyght
And that the nyght . wold last eủer/remo
I wold that al this . were ago
And fynally he doeth al his labour
As he best myght . savyng his honour
To hast hym from the mete . in subtil wise
The tyme cam . that Reason was to Rise
And after that men daunce . and drynke faste
And spicez al aboute the hous they caste
And ful of Ioye and blisse is eủer/rey man
Al but a squyer hight Damyan
Whiche carf before the knyght ful many a day
He was so Ravisshed . on his lady May
That for the verray peyne . he was ny woode
Almost he swelt . and swouned ther he stoode
So sore hath venus . hurt hym . with hir brond
As that she bare it dauncyng . in hir hond
And to his bed . he went hym hastily
Nomore of hym . at this tyme speke I
But ther I lete hym wepe Inowgh . and compleyne
Tyl fressh May wil Rewe . on his peyne
O ꝑper/parilous fuyre . that in the bedstraw breedith
O famulier foo . that his ʆser/sirvice bedith
O ʆser/siruᵃnt traitoᵘur . false homly hewe
Like to the nadder . in bosum sly vntriewe
God shield vs al . from yowre acqueyntaunce
O Ianuar dronken . in plesaunce
In Mariage see how thy Damyan
Thyn owne squyer . and thy born man
Entendith . for to do the vilany
God graunte the . thyn homly foo for to espie
For in this world . nys no noworldeworsse pestilence
Than homly foo . alday in thi presence
ꝐPer/Parfourmed hath the sonne . his ark dyurne
No lengger may the body . of hym soioᵘne
On thorisont . as in that latitude
Night with his Mantel . that is derk and Rude
Gan oủer/re sprede . the emysperies a boute
For whiche departed . is this lusty rowte
For Ianuarie with thank . on eủer/rey side
Hom to theyr housis . lustily they ride
Where as they don theyr thynges . as hem list
And whan they sawe tyme . they gon to Rest
Sone after that . this hasty Ianuarie
Wold go to bedde . he wold no lengger tarie
He drynkith Ipocras Clarrey and vernage
Of spices hoote . to encreasen his corage
And many a letuarie . hadde he ful fyne
Suche as the cursid Monke . daun Constantyne
Had writen in his booke . de Coitu
To eten hem alle . he nas nothyng eschu
And to his prive friendis . thus thushe saide he
For goddis love . as sone as it may be
Late voide al this house . in curteys wise
And they handon . Right as he dide devise
Men drynken . the traủer/res drawe anon
The bride was brought a bedde . as stille as ston
And whan the bed . was with the prist I blessed
Out of the chambre . hath eủer/rey wight hym dressid
And Ianuarie hath fast . in armes take
His fressh May . his ꝑper/paradice his make
He lullith hir . he kissith hir ful ofte
With thilke bristels . of his berd ful vnsofte
Like to the skyn of houndfissh . sharp as brere
For he was shave al newe . in his manore
He Rubbith hir . aboute hir tendir face
And seyde thus alas . I must trespace
To yow my spouse . and yow gretely offende
Or tyme . that me must descende
But natheles . considerith this quod he
Ther nys no werkman . what so eủer/re he be
That may werke wele and hastily
This wold be don . at leyser ꝑper/parfitely
It is no fors how long . that we pley
In triew wedlok . knyt bien we twey
And blissed be the yok . that we bien Inne
For in oure actis . we mow do no synne
A man may do no synne . with his wif
Ne hurt hym self . with his owne knyf
For we have leve to pley vs . bi the lawe
Thus labourith he . til the day gan dawe
And than he takith a sop . in fyn Clarie
And vpright . in his bed than sittith he
And after that he sang . ful lowde and cliere
And kissith his wif . and makith wanton chiere
He was al coltissh . ful of Ragerie
And ful of Iargoun . as is a flekked pie
The slak skyn . aboute his nekke shakith
While that he sang . so chauntith he and crakith
But god wote . what May thought in herte
Whan she hym sawe . vp sat in his sherte
In his nyght cappe . and his nekke leene
She praisith al his werk . nat worth a beene
Than seyd he thus . my Rest wil I take
Now day is comen . I may no lengger wake
And doun he leyd his hede . and sleepe til pryme
And after that . whan he saw his tyme
Vp risith Ianuarie but fressh May
Hield hir chambre . vnto the fourthe day
As vsage is . wifes for the best
For eủer/rey labour . sumtyme mote Rest
Or ellis longe . may he nat endure
This is to sayn . no lyves creature
Be it fissh or brid . best or man
Now wil I speke . of woful Damyan That langwisshed
That langwisshed for love as ye shul here
Therfore I speke to hym . in this manere
I sey o cely Damyan alas
Answere to my demaunde . as in this cas
How shaltow to thi lady . fressh May
Tel thy woo . she wil alwey sey nay
Eeke if thow speke . she wol thy wo bewrey
God be thyn help . I can nomore sey
This sike Damyan . in Venus fyre
So brennyth . that he deyeth for desire
For whiche he put . his lif in aventure
No lengger myght he . in this wise endure
But prively a penner . gan he borwe
And in a lettir . wrote he al his sorwe
In maner of a compleynt or a lay
Vnto this faire . fressh lady May
And in a purs of silk . hyng it on his sherte
He hath it put . and laide it at his herte
The Moone that at none . was thilke day
That Ianuarie . hath weddid fressh May
Out of Taure . was in to toCancre gliden
So longe hath Mayus . in hir chambre biden
As custom is . vnto this nobles alle
A bryde shal nat eten . in the halle
Til dayes foure . or thre at the leste
I passed bien . than late hir go to feste
The fourth day complete . from none to noone
Whan that the hye Masse . was I done
In halle sit this Ianuarie and May
As fressh as is . the bright soms day
And so bifel . that this goode man
Remembrid hym . vpon this Damyan
And saide seynt Marie . how may this be
That Damyan entendith nat . vnto me
Is he ay sike . or how may this betide
His squyers whiche that stondith ther beside
Excused hym . bi cause of his sikenesse
Whiche lettith hym . to don his busynesse
Nonother cause . myght make hym tarie
That me forthynkith . quod this Ianuarie
He is a gentil squyer . be my trowth
If that he deyde . it were grete rowth
He is as wise discrete . and eeke secre
As any man I wote . of his degre
And therto manly . and eeke ʆser/siruisable
And for to be a thrifty man Right able
But after mete . as sone as eủer/re I may
I wil my self visite hym . and eeke may
To do hym al the comfort . that I can
And for that word . hym blissed eủer/reyman
That he of his bounte . and gentilesse
He wold so comforten hym . in his sikenesse
His squyer . for it was a gentil dede
Dame quod this Ianuarie . takith goode heede
At after mete . ye with yowre wymmen al
Whan ye han be in chambre out of this hal
That al ye go . to this Damyan
Doeth hym disport . he as a gentil man
And tellith hym that . I wil hym visite
Have I nothyng . but restid me alite
And spede yow fast . for I wil abide
Til that ye sleepe fast be my side
And with that word . he gan to hym calle
A squyer that was M̉er/reschal of his halle
And told hym certayne thynges . that he wold
This fressh May . hath hir streight wey I hold
With al hir wymmen . vnto Damyan
Doun be his beddis side . sitte she than
Comfortyng hym . as goodely as she may
This Damyan whan that he his tyme say
In secrete wise . his purs and eke his bille
In whiche that he Iwriten . had his wille
Hath put in to hir hand . withoute more
Save that he sighed . wonder deepe and soore
And softly to hir . Right thus saide he
Mercy . and that ye nat discouere me
For I am ded . if that this thyng be kyd
This purs hath she . withyn hir bosum hid
And went hir wey . ye gete nomore of me
But vnto Ianuarie I comen is she
That on his beddis side . sat ful softe
And takith hir and kissith ful ofte
And laide hym doun to sleepe . and that anon
She feyneth hir . as that she muste gon
There as ye wote . that eủer/rey wight must neede
And whan she of this bille . hath taken heede
She rent it al to clowtis . and at the last
And in the privy . softly it cast
Who studieth now . but faire fressh May
Adoun bi old Ianuarie . she lay
And sleepe til that the cowgh had hym awaked
Anon he praide . to stripe hir al naked
He wold of hir he saide . have som plesaunce
He saide hir clothis . dide hym encombraunce
But lest that precious folke . be with me wroth
And she obeyeth be she lief or loth
How that he wrought . I dar nat vnto yow telle
Or whether he thought it . ꝑper/paradice or helle
But here I lete hem werke . an theyr wise
Til euenson Rong . that they must arise
Whether it be destyne . or bi aduenture
Were it bi Influence . or bi nature
Or in constellacioun . that in suche estate
The hevene stoode . that tyme fortunate
As for to put a bille . of Venus werkis
For althyng hath tyme . as seyn thiese clerkis
To any womman . for to gete hir love
I can nat sey . but the grete god above
That knowith . that non acte is causeles
He deme of al . for I wil hold my pees
But sooth is this . that this fressh May
Hath take suche . Impression that day
Of pite . of this sike Damyan
That from hir hirhert she ne dryve can
The remembraunce . for to don hym ease
Certeyn thought she . though this thyng displease
I rekke nat . for here I hym assure
To love best . of any creature
Though he nomore had . than his sherte
His love shal neủer/re . out of myn herte
Here Heremy may ye see . how excelent fraunchise
In wymmen is . whan they narow hem avise
Som tyraunt is . as ther bien many on
That hath an herte . as hard as any ston
Whiche wold han lete . hym sterve in the place
Wel rather than han graunted hym hir grace
And hem reioysen . in theyr cruel pride
And rekke nat to bien . anhomycide
This gentil May . fulfild of pite
Right of hir owne . hand . a lettre mad she
In whiche she gᵃunted hym . hir verray grace
There lackith nat . but only day and space
Where that she myght . vnto his lust suffice
For it shalbe . right as he wil devise
And whan she saw hir tyme . vpon aday
To visite this Damyan goth fressh May
And subtily this lre . doun she thriste
Vndir his pilwe . Rede it if hym liste
She takith hym bi the hand . and hard hym twist
So secretely . that noman of it wist
And bad hym be alhole . and furth she went
To Ianuarie . whan he for hir sente
Vp risith Damyan . the next morwe
Al passid was . his sikenesse and his sorwe
He kembith hym . proygneth and pikith
He doeth al that his lady lust and likith
And eeke to Ianuarie . he goth as lowe
As eủer/re dide . dogge for the bowe
He is so plesaunt . vnto eủer/rey man
For craft is al . who so do it can
That eủer/rey wight is fayn . to do hym goode
And fully in his lady grace . he stoode
Thus lete I Damyan aboute his neede
And In my tale . I wil procede
Som clerkis holden . that felicite
Stant in delite . and therfor certayn he
This noble Ianuarie . with al his myght
In honest wise . as longith to a knyght
Shoope hym to live . ful deliciously
His housyng his array . as honestly
To his degre was made . as a kynges
Among other . of his honest thynges
He had a gardyn . wallid al with ston
So faire a gardyn . wote I nowhere non
For out of doute . verraily I suppose
That he that wrote . the Romaunce of the Rose
Ne cowde of it . the beaute wele divise
Ne Priapus myght nat suffice
Though he be god of gardyns . for to telle
The beaute of the gardyn . and the welle
That stoode vndir a lawrer . al wey grene
Ful often tyme . he Pluto and his qwene
Proserpyna . and al hir fairye
Disported hem . and maden melodye
Aboute that welle . and dauncen as men told
This noble knyght . this Ianuarie the old
Suche deynte hath . in it to walke and pleye
That he wold no wight . suffre bere the keye
Save he hym self . for of the smal wiket
He bare alwey . of silủer/re a Cliket
With whiche whan he . hym list vnshette
And whan he wold paie his wif hir dette
In som season . thider wold he go
And May his wif . and no wight but they two
And thynges . whiche were nat don abedde
He in the Gardyn . ꝑper/parfoᵘurmed hem and spedde
And in this wise . many a myrrye day
Lived Ianuarie . and his fressh May
But worldly Ioy . May nat alwey endure
To Ianuarie . ne to no creature
O thow sodeyn hap . o thow fortune vnstable
Like a Scorpioun so disceyuable
That flaterist with thyn hed . whan thow wilt stynge
Thy taile is deth . thurgh thyn envenemyng
O brotil Ioye . o swete venymous qweynte
O Monstre . that so subtily canst peynte
Thi yiftes vndirhewe . of stidefastnesse
That thow disceyvest . both more and lesse
How hastow Ianuarie thus disceyved
That haddest hym . for thi ful friend receyved
And now thow hast . bi reft hym both his eyen
For sorow of whiche . desirith he to dyen
Alas the noble . Ianuariethe free
A mydde his lust . and his ꝓprosperite
Is woxen blynd . and that al sodainly
He wepith and wailith . and that pitously
And therwith al . the fuyre of Ialousie
Lest that his wif . shuld fal in som folye
So brent his herte . that he wold fayne
That som man hadde . both hym and hir slayn
For neither after his deth . ne in his lif
Ne wold he she were love ne wif
But ever live as widewe . in clothis blake
Soul as the Turtil that lost hath hir make
But at the last . after a Moneth or twey
His sorow gan aswage . sooth to sey
For whan he wist . it myght nonother be
He paciently . toke his aduersite
Sauf out of doute . he may nat forgon
Th it he was Ialous . eủer/remore in oon
Whiche Ialousie . was so outrageous
That neither in halle . nor in other hous
Ne in nonother place . neủer/re the mo
He nold soeffre hir . for to Ride or go
But if he had hand . on hir alway
For whiche ful oft . wepith fresh May
That lovith Damyan . so brennyngly
That . she must other dyen sodainly
Or ellis she must . han hym at hir list
She waiteth . whan hir hert wold brest
Vpon that other side . this Damyan
Bicomen is . the sorowfullest man
That eủer/re was . for neither nyght ne day
Ne myght he speke a word . with fressh May
As to his purpos . of suche matiere
But if that Ianuarie . must it here
That had anhand . vpon hir eủer/remo
But natheles bi writyng . to and fro
And prive signes . wist he what she ment
And she knew eeke . the fyne of his entent
O Ianuaire what myght it the availe
Thow myghtest see as fer as shippes saile
For as goode is blynd . disceyved be
As to be disceyved . whan a man may see
Lo Argus whiche had . anhundrid eyen
For al that eủer/re he cowde . powre or pryen
Yit was he blynded . and god wote so bien mo
That wenyth wisly . it be nat so
Passe oủer/re is isa anease . I sey nomore
This fressh May that I spak of yore
In warm wexe . hath prynted the cliket
That Ianuarie bare of . the smal smalcliketwiket
Bi whiche in to his gardyn . oft he went
And Damyan that knew . al hir entent
The cliket countrefeted prively
Ther nys nomore to sey . but hastily
Som wounder bi this cliket . shalbe tyde
O noble Ovide fulsooth seistow god wote
That sleight is it . though it be long or hote
That he nyl fynd it . in som manere
By Pyram9 and Thesbe . may men leere
Though they were kept . ful long streite oủer/re al
They bien accordid Rownyng . thurgh a wal
Ther no wight cowde have founden . suche a sleight
But now to purpos . or that dayes eyght
Were passed or the Moneth . of Iule fil
That Ianuarie hath caught . so grete a wil
Thurgh eggyng of his wif to pleye
In his gardyne . and nowight but they tweye
That in a morwe . vnto his May seith he
Rise vp my wif . my love my lady free
The Turtils voys is herd . my douf sweete
The wynter is gon . with Reynes wete
Com furth now . with thyn eyen columbyne
How faire bien thi brestis . than is the wyne
The gardyn is enclosid al aboute
Com forth my swete spouse out of doute
Thow hast me wounded . in myn hert wif
No spot in the . ne know I in al my lif
Com furth and late vs take . oure disport
I ches the for my wif . and my comfort
Suche old lewd wordis . vsed he
On Damyan a signe . made she
That he shuld go bi forn . with his cliket
This Damyan than . openyth the wiket
And in he stirt . and that in suche manere
That no wight . myght it see ne heere
And stille he sitte . vndir a bussh anon
This Ianuarie as blynd as aston
With Mayus in his hand . an no wigh mo
In to his fressh gardyn . is a go
And clapt to the wiket . so sodainly
Now wif quod he . here nys but thow and I
That art a creature . that I best love
For bi the lord . that sat in hevene above
Lever hadde I deyen . on a knyf
Than the offende . deere triewe wif
For goddis sake . thynk how I the ches
Nought for no couetise . douteles
But only for the love . I ought to the
And though that I be old . and may nat see
Be to me triewe . and I telle yow why
Thre thynges certis . shul ye wynne therby
Firstlove of Crist . and to yowre self honour
And al myn heritage . toun and tour
I yeve it yow . make chartres as yow leste
This shalbe don to morow . or sonne reste
So wisly god my soule . bryng in blisse
I pray yow first in couenᵃunt . ye me kisse
And though that I be Ialous . wite me nought
Ye bien so deepe enprientid . in my thought
That whan I considre . yowre beaute
And ther with al . the vnlikly eld of me
I may nought certis . though I shuld dye
For bere to bien out . of yowre compaignie
For verray love . this is withouten doute
Now kisse me wif . and late vs rome aboute
This fressh May . whan she thiese wordis herde
Benyngly to Ianuarie aunswerd
But first and formest . she bigan to wepe
I have quod she . a soule for to kepe
Aswele as ye . and also myn honour
And of my wifhod . thilk tendir flour
Whiche that I have assured . in yowre hand
Whan that the priest . to yow my body band
Wherfor I wold aunswere . in thilke manere
Bi the leve of yow . my lord so deere
I pray to god . neủer/re dawe that day
That I ne sterve . as foule as womman may
If eủer/ree I do . vnto my kyn that shame
Or ellis I empeyre . so my name
That I be false . and if I do that lacke
Do stripe me . and put me in a sak
And in the next Ryver . do me drenche
I am a gentil womman . and nowenche
Why speke ye thus . but men bien eủer/re vntriewe
And wymmen han reproef . of yow ay newe
Ye han nonother . countenaunce I leeve
But speke to vs . of vntrust and repreve
And with that word . she saw wher Damyan
Sat in the bussh . and coughen she be gan
And with hir fynger . signes made she
That he shuld clymbe . vpon a tree
That chargid was withe fruyt . and vp he went
For verraily he knew . al hir entent
And eủer/rey signe . that she cowde make
Wel bet than Ianuarie hir owne make
For in a lettir . she told hym al
Of this matier . how he werken shal
And thus I lete hym sitte . vpon the pirie
And Ianuarie and May Romyng myrie
Bright was the day . and blew the firmament
Phebus with his golden streames . hath doun sent
To gladden eủer/rey flowre . with his warmnesse
He was that tyme in Gemynis I gesse
But a litel . from his declynacioun
Of Cancer Iouis exaltacioun
And so bifel . that bright morow tide
That in the gardyn . on the ferther side
Pluto that was . kyng of fairie
And many a lady . in his compaignie
Folwyng his wif the qwene . proserpyne
Walkyng to and fro . in the gardyne
While she gadred . flowris in the mede
In Clawdian ye may the story Rede
How in his grisely cart he hir sette
This kyng of fairie . than adoun sette
Vpon abenche of turffes . faire and greene
And right anon . thus saide he to his qwene
My wif quod he . ther may no wight sey nay
Thexꝑper/parience so previth it eủer/rey day
The treason whiche that wymmen don to man
Ten hundred thousand . telle I can
Notable of yowre vntrowth . and doublenesse
O Salamon Riche wise . of al Richesse
Fulfilled of sapience . and worldly glorie
Ful worthy bien thi wordis in memorie
To eủer/rey wight . that wit and reason can
Thus praisith he yit . the bounte of Man
Among a thowsand men . yit fond I oon
But of wymmen al . ne fonde he non
Thus seyde the kyng . that knew yowre wikkidnesse
And Iesus filius Sirak as I gesse
Ne spekith of yow . but sield reủer/reence
A wield fuyre . and corrupt pestilence
So fal vpon yowre bodies . yit to nyght
Ne see ye nat . this honurable knyght
Bi cause alas he is blynd and old
His owne man . shal make hym cokeold
Lo where he sitte . the lecchour in the tree
Now wil I graunte . of my Mageste
Vnto this old . worthy knyght
That he shal have . ageyn his eye sight
Whan his wif . wil do hym vilanye
Than shal he knowe . al hir harlotrie
Both in Reproef of hir . and othir mo
Ye quod Preʆser/sirpyne and wil ye so
Now be my moders sires soule . I swere
That I shal yeven hir . sufficiaunt aunswere
And al wymmen aftir . for hir sake
Although they be . in any gilt I take
With face bold . they shuld hem self excuse
And bere hem doun that wolden hem accuse
For lak of aunswer . non of theym shal deyen
Al had men seen a thyng . with both theyr eyen
Yit shal we wymmen . visage it hardily
And wepe and swore . and I chide subtily
So as ye men shul . bien as lewd as gees
What rekkith me . of yowre auctorites
I wote wele that this Iewe . this Salamon
Fond of vs wymmen . foolis manyon
But though that he ne fond . no goode womman
Yit hath ther founde . many another man
Wymmen ful triew . ful goode and vertuous
Witnesse of theym . that dwelle in Cristis hous
With Martirdom . they previd theyr constaunce
The Romayn geestis . eeke maken remembraunce
Of many a verray triewe wif also
But ʆser/sir ne be nat wroth . though it be so
Though that he saide . he fond no goode womman
I pray yow . take the sentence of the man
He ment thus . that in soủer/reayne bounte
Nys non but god . neyther he ne she
Ey for verray god . that nys but oon
What make ye somoche . of Salamon
What though he made . a temple goddis hous
What though he were Riche . and glorious
So made he a temple . vnto false goddis
How myght he do a thyng . that more forbode is
Parde as faire as his name . is in emplastre
He was a lecchour . and an Idolastre
And in his eld . his verray god forsooke
And if god ne hadde . as saith the booke
Spared hym . for his fadirs sake he shuld
Have lost his Reigne . rather than he wold
I sette right nought . of al the velany
That ye of wymmen wrate . a butterfly
I am a womman . needis must I speke
Or ellis swelle . til myn hert breke
For sithen he sayde . we bien Iangleresses
As eủer/ree hole mote I . browke my tressis
I shal nat spare . for no curtesie
To speke hym harm . that wold vs velanye
Dame quo this Pluto . be no lengger wroth
I yeve it vp . but sith I swore myn oth
That I wold graunte hym . his sight ageyn
My word shal stonde . I warne yow certeyn
I am a kyng . it sit me nat to lye
And I quod she . a qwene of the fairie
Hir aunswer shal she have . I vndirtake
Late vs no mo wordis . herof make
For sooth I wil no lengger . yow contrarie
Now late vs turne ageyn . to Ianuarie
That in the gardyn . with his faire May
Syngith myrier . than the popinIay
Yow love I best and shal . and other non
So long aboute the Aleys . is he gon
Til he was come . to thilke pirie
Wher as this Damyan . sittith ful murie
Among anhigh . the fressh leves grene
This fresh May . that is so bright and sheene
Gan for to sike . and saide alas my side
Now ʆser/sir quod she . for aught that may betide
I must have . of the peris in the tree
Or I must dye . so sore longith me
To eten of the smale peris greene
Help for hir love . that is hevene qwene
I tel yow wele . a womman . in my plite
May have to fruyte . suche an appetite
That she may deyen . but she of it may have
Alas quod he that I ne had . here a knave
That cowde clymbe . alas alas quod he
For I am blynd . ye sir nofors quod she
But wolde ye fouchesauf . for goddis sake
The pirie withyn . yowre armes take
For wele I wote . that ye mystrust me
Than shold I clymbe wele I nough quod she
So I my foote . myght sette vpon yowre bak
Certis quod he . theron shalbe no lak
Might I yow help . with myn herte bloode
He stowpid . and on his bak she stoode
And caught hir bi atwist . and vp she goth
Ladyes I pray yow . that ye be nat wroth
I can no glose . I am a Rude man
And sodainly anon . this Damyan
Gan pul vp the smok . and in he throng
And whan Pluto . saw this grete wrong
To Ianuarie he gaf . ageyn his sight
And made hym see aswele . as eủer/re he myght
And whan he had caught . his sight agayn
Ne was ther neủer/re man . of thyng so fayn
But on his wif . his thought was eủer/remo
Vnto the tre . he cast his eyen two
And saw how that Damyan . his wif had dressed
In suche mane . it may nat be expressed
But if I wold speke . vncurteisly
And vp he yaf . a Roryng and a cry
As doth the moder . whan the chield shal dye
Out help alas . harow he gan cry
O strong lady stoore . what doestow
And she aunswerde and seide . ʆser/sir what eylith yow
Have pacience and Reason . in yowre mynd
I have yow holpen . of both yowre eyen blynd
Vp ꝑper/parel of my soule . I shal nat lien
As me was taught . to hele with yowre eyen
Was nothyng bet . to make yow see
Than strugle with aman . vpon a tree
God GodI wote I dide it . in ful goode entent
Strugle quod he . ȝe algate in it went
God yeve yow both . on shames deth to dyen
He swyved the . I saw it with myn eyen
And ellis be I hanged . bi the hals
That is quod she . my medicyne alfals
For certaynly . if ye myght see
Ye wold nat sey . thiese wordis vnto me
Ye han som glymsyng . and no ꝑper/parfit sight
I see quod he aswele . as eủer/re I myght
Thankyd be god . with both myn eyen two
And be my trowth . me thought he dide the so
Ye maze maze . goode sir quod she
This thank have I . for I have made yow see
Alas quod she . that eủer/re was so kynde
Now dame quod he late passe . al out of mynde
Com doun my lief . and if I have myssaide
God help me so . as I am evil apaied
But be my fadir soule . I wende have seyn
How that this Damyan . had bi the layn
And that thy smok . had leyn vpon thy brest
Ye ʆser/sir quod she . ye may wene as yow lest
But ʆser/sir aman . that wakith out of his sleepe
He may sodainly . wele taken kepe
Vpon a thyng . ne see it ꝑper/parfitely
Til he be adawid . verrily
Right so aman that hath . long blynd be
Ne may nat sodainly . so wele see
First whan his sight . is newe come ageyn
As he that hath a day . or two I seyn
Til that yowre sight . I satled be a while
Ther may ful many a sight . yow begile
Be ware I pray yow . for bi heuene kyng
Ful many a man wenyth . to se a thyng
And it is another . than it semyth
He that mysconceyvith . mysdemyth
And with that word . she lept doun from the tree
This Ianuarie . who is glad but he
He kissith hir . and clippith hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe . he strokith hir ful softe
And to his palays . hom he hath hir lad
Now goode men . I pray yow to be glad
Thus endith here my tale . of Ianuarie
God blesse vs . and his Moder seynt Marie

l.hi:
¶ Explicit Fabula Mercatoris
¶ Incipit prologus vxoris de bath

div.l: Experience . though non Auctorite
Were in this world . were Right I now for me
To speke of woo . that is in Mariage
For lordynges . sith I was . xij . yeere of Age
Thankyd be god . that is et̉er/renal on live
Husbondis at the Chirche dore . I have had five
If / I so oft . myght han weddid be
And al were worthy men . men in theyr degre
But me was taught certayn . nought long agon is
That sith that Crist ne went bott . oonys
To weddyng . in the . Cane of Galile
That bi the same ensample . taught he me
That I ne shuld weddid be . but oones
The verray certainte wold I know . for the nones
Beside a welle . Ihıı̄uns god and Man
Spak in Repref . of the Samaritan
Thow hast I had . fyve husbondis quod he
And that ilke man . whiche that now hath the
Is nat thyn husbond . thus saide he certayn
What he ment therby . I can nat seyn
But that I aske why . that the fift man
Was non husbonde . to the Samaritan
How many myght she have in mariage
Yit herd I neủer/re . tel in myn Age
Vpon the nombre . diffynicioun
Men may deme . and glosen vp and doun
But wele I wote . expresse withouten lie
God bad vs for to wexe . and Multiplie
That gentil text . can I wele vndirstonde
Eke wele I wote he saide myn husbonde
Shuld lete fadir and Moder . and take to me
But of no nombre . mencioun made he
Of bigamye . ne of Octogamye
Why shuld men than . speke of it vilanye
Lo here the wise kyng . Daun Salamon
I trow that he had wyves . mo than oon
As god wold . it lieful were to me
To be refresshed half so oft as he
What yift of god had he for al his wyves
Noman hath suche . that in this world a live is
God wote this noble kyng . as to my wit
The first nyght . had many a myrrie fit
With eche of theym . so wele was hym on lyve
Blissed be god . that I have weddid fyve
Welcom the sixte . whan that eủer/re he shal
Forsoth I wil nat . kepe me chast in al
Whan myn husbonde . is fro the world agon
Som cristen man . shal me wedde anon
For than the Apostil saith . that I am free
To wedde a goddis half . whan it liketh me
He seith that to be weddid . it is no synne
Bet is to be weddid . than to brenne
What rekkith me . though folke sey velany
Of shrewde lameth . and his bigamye
I wote wele . Abrahᵃm was anholy man
And Iacob eeke . as fer as eủer/re as I can
And eche of theym had wyves . mo than tow
And Many another holy man also
Where can ye sey . in any man of age
That the high god . defendid mariage
Bi expresse word . I pray yow tellith me
Or where comaundid he . virgynite
I wote aswele as ye . it is no drede
Thapostel . whan he spak of maydenhed
He saide that precept therof had he non
Men may counseil . a womman to be oon
But counsaile . is no comaundement
He put it . in oure owne Iugement
For had god comaunded . maydenhed
Than hadde he dampned weddyng with the dede
And certis if ther were . no seede I sowe
Virgynite than wherof . shuld it growe
Paul durst nat comaunde it at the leste
A thyng of whiche his Maister yaf non heste
The dart is set vp . for virgynite
Cacche who so may . who Rennyth best late see
But this word is nat take . of eủer/rey wight
But ther as god list . to yeve it of his myght
I wote wele that thapostil . was a Maide
But natheles . al that he wrought or saide
He wold that eủer/re wight . were as he
Al nys but counsaile . to virgynite
And for to bien a wif . he yaf me leve
Of Indulgence . so is it no Repreve
To wedde me . if that my make dye
Without excepcioun . of Bigamye
Al were it goode . no womman for to towche
He ment as in his bedde . or in his cowche
For ꝑper/parel is both . fier and tow tassemble
Ye know what this ensample . doth resemble
This is al and sum . he hield virgynite
More ꝑper/parfite . than weddyng in frealte
Frealte clepe I . but if that he and she
Wolden al hir lif . in chastite
I graunt wele . I have non envie
Though maydenhed . preferre bigamye
It liketh theym . to be clene in body and gost
Of myn estate . ne wil I make no bost
For wele I knowe . a lord in his household
Hath nat his vessel . al of pure gold
Som bien of tree . and don theyr lord ʆser/sirvice
God clepith folk to hym in sundry wise
And eủer/reiche hath of god . a propre . yift
Som this som that . as hym likith shift
Virgynite . is a grete ꝑper/parfeccioun
And contynence . eeke with devocioun
But Crist that of ꝑper/parfeccioun . is welle
Bad nat eủer/rey wight . that he shuld selle
Al that he hadde . and yeve it to the poore
And in suche wise . folow hym and his loore
He spak to hym . that wold live ꝑper/parfitely
And lordynges bi yowre leve . that am nat I
I wil bestow the flowre . of al myn Age
In the actes . and in fruyt of mariage
Tel me also . to what conclusioun
Were membres made . of generacioun
And inso ꝑper/parfite wise . athyng I wrought
Trustith right wele . they were nat made for nought
Glose who so wil . and sey both vp and doun
That they were made . for purgacioun
Of vryne . and oure both thynges smale
Was eeke to knowe . amale from a female
And for nonother cause . sey ye no
Exꝑper/parience wote wele . it is nat so
So that thiese clerkis . be nat with me wroth
I sey that they bien made . for both
That is to say . for office and for an ease
Of engendrure . thar we nat god displease
Why shuld men ellis . in theyr bookis sette
That man shal yield . to his hir dette
Now wherwith . shuld he make his paiement
If he ne vsid his cely Instrument
Than were they made . vpon a creature
To purge vryne . and eeke for engendrure
But I sey nat . that eủer/rey wight is hold
That hath suche harneys as I yow told
To gon and vsen hem . in engendrure
Than shuld men take . of chastite no cure
Crist was a mayde . and shapen as a man
And many a seynt . sith the world bigan
Yit lived they eủer/re . in parfite chastite
I wil nat envie . with virgynite
Late theym ete brede . of pure whete seed
And late vs wyves . ete barly breed
And yit with barly . brede Mark tel can
Oure lord Ihesus Refresshed many aman
In suche estate . as god hath clepid vs
I wil ꝑper/parseủer/re . I am nat precious
In wifhod wil I vse . myn Instrumēmt
As freely as my maker . hath it sent
If I be daungerous . god yeve me sorow
Myn husbond shal it have . both Eve and morow
Whan that hym list com forth . and paie his dette
Anhusbonde wil I have I wil nat lette
Whiche shalbe both . my . dettour and my thralle
And have his tribulacioun with al
For though he loke . as woode as a lyoun
Yit shuld he faile . of his conclusioun
Than wold I sey . goode lief take goode kepe
How mekely lokith . wilkyn oure sheepe
Com nere my spouse . late me ba thy cheke
Ye shuld albe pacient and meke
And have asweete spiced conscience
Sith ye can preche so . of Iob his pacience
Soeffre al we . syn ye so wele can preche
And but ye don . certayn we shal yow teche
That it is ful faire . to have a wif in peas
On of vs two must bowen doutles
And sith a man . is more resonable
Than a womman is . ye must be soefrable
What eyleth yow thus . to grucche and grone
It is for ye wold have . my qweynt alone
Whi take it al lo have it eủer/rey del
Petir I shrewe yow . but ye love it wel
For If I wold selle . my bele chose
I cowde walke . as fressh as a Rose
But I wil kepe it . for myn yowre owne tooth
Ye be to blame . bi god I sey yow sooth
I swore that my walkyng . out bi nyght
Was for to espye . wenchis that he dight
Vndir that colour . had I many a myrth
For al suche wit . is yoven vs in oure birth
Disceyt wepyng . spynnyng god hath yevyn
To wymmen kyndly . while they may liven
And thus of oothyng . I avaunt me
At thende I hadde the bet in eche degre
Bi sleight or fors . or bi som man of thyng
As bi contynuel murmʳ and grucchyng
Namly a bedde had they myschaunce
Ther wold I chide . and do hem no plesaunce
I wold no lengger . in the bedde abide
If that I felt his arm . oủer/re my side
Til he had made his Raunsoun vnto me
Than wold I soeffre hym . do his nycete
And therfor eủer/rey man . this tale I telle
Wynne who so may . for al is to selle
With empty hand . men may no hawkes lure
For wynnyng wold I . al his lust endure
And make me . a feyned appetite
And yit in bacon . had I neủer/re delite
That made me . that eủer/re I wold hem chide
For though the pope . had seten bi his side
I wold nat spare hym . at his owne boord
For bi my trowth . I quytte hym word for word
As help me verray god . omnipotent
Though I Right now . shul make my testament
I ne owe hym a word .that it nys qwyt
I brought it so a boute . bi my wit
That they must yeven it vp al for the best
Or ellis had we neủer/re bien in Rest
Suche man wordis had we on honde
Now wil I speke of my fourth husbond
My fourth husbond . was a Reuelour
That is to say . he had aparamour
And I was yong . and ful of Ragerye
Styboᵘurne and strong . and Ioly as apie
Lord so I cowde daunce . to anharpe smale
And syng I wis . as any nyghtyngale
Whan I had drunk . a draught of swete wyne
Metulius the cheorl . the fowle swyne
That with a staf . biraft his wif hir lif
For she drank wyne .though I had bien his wif
Ne shuld nat han dauntid me from drynk
And after wyne . on Venus must I thynk
For as so siker . as cold engendrith haile
A likerous mowth . must have a likerous taile
In womman vynolent . is no defence
This knowith lechours . bi exꝑper/parience
But lord Crist whan I Remembre me
Vpon my yowth . and my Iolite
It tikelith me . aboute myn herte Rote
Vnto this day . it doeth myn hert boote
That I have had the world . as in my tyme
But age alas . that al doeth envenyme
Hath me biraft . my beaute and my pith
Late go farwel . the devil go ther with
The flour is gon . ther is nomore to telle
The bran as I best can . now must I selle
Now herkenyth how I bare me ꝓpropirly
For god it wote . I chidde hem spitously
Ye wise wyfes . that can vndirstond
Thus shuld ye speke . and bere hem wrong on hond
For half so . boldly . can noman
Swere and lye . as a womman can
I sey nat this bi wifes . that bien wise
But it be whan . they hem mysavise
A wise wif . if she can hir goode
Shal bere hym anhond . the cow is woode
And take witnesse . of hir owne maide
Of hir assent . but herkenyth how I saide
Sir old Kaynard is this thyn array
Whi is myn neyghburghs wif so gay
She is honoured oủer/real . wher she goth
I sitte at hom . I have no thrifty cloth
What doestow . at my neygburghs hous
Is she so faire . artow so amerous
What rowne ye with oure maide benedicite
Sir old lechour . late thi Iapes be
And if I have . a gossip or a friend
Withouten gilt . ye chiden as a fiend
If that I walke . or pley onto his hous
Thow comest hom . as dronke as a Mous
And prechest on thy benche . with evil pref
Thow seist to me . it is a grete myschief
To wedde a pore womman . for costage
And if she be Riche . of high parage
Than seistow . it is a turmentrye
To soeffre hir pride . and hir malencolye
And if that she be faire . thow verry knave
Thow seist . that eủer/rey holour . wil hir have
She may no while . in chastite abide
That is assailed . vpon iche aside
Thow seist som folk desiren vs . for oure Richesse
Som for oure shap . and som for oure fairenesse
And som for she can . other synge or daunce
And som gentillesse . and daliaunce
Som for hir handis . and hir armes smale
Thus goth al to the devil . bi thy tale
Thow seyst men may nought . kepe a castel wal
It may so long be . assailed oủer/real
And if she be fowle . thow seist that she
Coueytith eủer/rey man . that she may see
For as a Spaynel she wil on hym lepe
Til that she may fynde . somman that wil hir chepe
Ne non so grey goos . that swymmyth in the lake
As seistow . wilbe . without amake
And seist it is . anhard thyng for to weld
A thyng that noman wil . his thankes held.
Thus saistow lorel . whan thow gost to bedde
And that in nowise . noman nedith to wedde
Ne noman that entendith vnto the hevene
With wield thundir dynt . and fyry levene
Mote thy welked nekke . be to broke
Thow seist that droppyng houses . and eke smoke
And chidyng wifes . maken men to flee
Out of theyr houses . ey benedicite
What aylith . suche anoldman to chide
Thow seist we wifes . wil oure vices hide
Til we be fast. and than we wil hym shewe
Wele may that be of a shrew a ꝓproủer/rebe of a shrew
Thow seist . oxen . hors . asses . and houndes
They bien assaied . at dyủer/res stoundes
Basyns lauours . or that men hem beye
Spones stooles . and suche husbundrye
And so be pottis . clothis and array
But folk of wyves . maken non assay
Til they bien weddid . old dotard shrewe
And than seistow . we wil oure vicis shewe
Thow seist also . it pleasith nat me
But if that thow . preise my beaute
And but thow powre . alwey in my face
And clepe me faire dame . in eủer/rey place
And but thow make a fest . on thilk day
That I was born . and make me fressh and gay
And but thow doo . to my neese honour
And to my chambrer . withyn my bour
And to my fadirs folke . and his alyes
Thus seistow old lorel . ful of lyes
And yit of oure prentice Iankyn
For his crisp her . shynnyng as gold fyn
And for he squyerth me both vp and doun
Yit hastow caught . false suspeccioun
I wil hym nought . though thow were ded to morow
But tel me this . whi hidestow with sorow
The keyes of thi chest . a wey from me
It is my goode as wele . as thyn ꝑper/parde
What wenestow make . anydiote of oure dame
Now bi that lord . that callid is seynt Iame
Thow shalt nat both . that thow were woode
Be maister of my body . and of my goode
That oon thow shalt forgo . mawgre thyn eyen
What helpith it of me . to enquere and aspyen
I trowe thow woldest . lok me in thy chest
Thow shuldest sey . wif go where ye lest
Take yowre disport . I leeve no talis
I know yow for a triew wif . Dame Alis
We love noman . that takith kepe or charge
Where that we gon . we wil be at oure large
Of al men . blissed mote he be
The wise Astrologier . Daun Ptholome
That seith this ꝓprouerbe . in his Almageste
Of al men his wisdom . is hieste
That rekkith nat . who hath the world in hond
Bi this ꝓproủer/rebe . thow shalt vndirstond
Have thow I nowgh . what thar the Rek or care
How myrily . that other folkes fare
For certis old dotard by yowre leve
Ye shul have qweynte . I nowgh at Eve
He is to grete a nygard . that wil werne
A man to light a candel . at his lanterne
He shal have neủer/re the lasse light parde
Have thow I nough . the thar nat playn the
Tho seist also . that if make vs gay
With clothis and with precious array
That it is ꝑper/parel . of oure chastite
And yit with sorow . thow must enforcen the
And sey thiese wordis . in the ꝓprophetis name
In habite made . with chastite and shame
Ye wymmen shal appairaille yov quod he
And nat in tressed her . and gay perre
As perlis ne with gold . and clothis riche
Aftir thy text . ne after thy Rubriche
I wil nat werk nomore . than wil a gnat
Thow seist also . that I was like a cat
For who so wil senge . a cattis skynne
Than wil the cat . dwel in his Inne
And if the Cattiskynne . be fressh and gay
She wil nat dwel at hom . nat fully half a day
But furth she wil . or any day be dawed
To shewe hir skynne . and go a cattirwawed
This is to say . if I be gay ʆser/sir shrewe
I wil renne out . my borel for to shewe
Sir old shrewe . what helpith the to spyen
Though thow prey Argus with his hundred eyen
To be my ward corps . as he can best
In feith he shal nat kepe me . but if me lest
Yit cowd I make his berd as somote I the
Thow seist also . ther bien thynges thre
The whiche thynges .troublen al this erth
And that noman . may endure the ferth
O lief ʆser/sir shrewe Ihushort thy lif
Yit prechestow and seist . an hateful wif
I Rekened is for oon . of thiese myschaunces
Bien ther nonother . resemblaunces
That ye likne . yow parables to
But if a cely wif . be oon of thoo
Thow likenest eke . wommannes love to helle
To bareyn land . there water may nat dwelle
Thow liknest also . to wield fuyre
The more it brennyth . the more it hath desire
To consumen eủer/rey thyng . that brend wilbe
Thow seist right as wormes . shende a tree
Right so a wif . distroyeth hir husbond
Lordynges right thus . as ye han vndirstand
Bar I stifly myn old husbondis onhond
That they seyden . in theyr dromkennesse
And al was fals . but that I toke witnesse
Of Iankyn . and of my neece also
O lord the pyne that I dide theym an the wo
Ful giltles . bi goddis swete pyne
For as an hors . I cowde both bite and whyne
I wold playne . and I was in the gilt
Or ellis oft tymes . I had be spilt
Who that first to Mille comyth first grynt
I pleyned first . so was oure werre stynt
They weren ful glad . to excusen hem blyve
Of thyng whiche they neủer/re gilt. in theyr live
Of wenchis wold I . bere theym onhond
Whan that forsike . they myght vnnethstond
Yit tikeled I his herte . for that he
Wend that I hadde of hym . so grete chierte
Vpon his flessh duryng . al my lif
I have the power . while I am his wif
Vpon his ꝓpropre body . and nat he
Right thus thapostle . tolde vnto me
And bad oure husbondis . for to love vs wele
Al this sentence . me likith eủer/rey del
Vp stirt the ꝑper/pardoner . and that anon
Now dame quod he . bi god and bi seynt Iohn
Ye be a noble prechour . in this cas
I was aboute . to wedde a wif alas
What shuld I bye it . on my flessh so deere
Yit had I leủer/re . wed no wif to yeere
A bide quod she . my tale is nat bigunne
Nay thow shalt drynk . of a nother tonne
Or that I go . shal sauoᵘur worse than Ale
And whan that I have . told the any tale
Of tribulacioun . in Mariage
Of whiche I am exꝑper/part . in al myn age
That is to seyn . my self hath bien the whippe
Than maistow cheese . whider thow wilt skippe
Of thilke tonne . whiche I shal appr a broche
Be ware of it . or thow to nygh aproche
For I shal tel ensamples . mo than ten
Who so yit nel . be ware bi other men
Bi hym shal other men correctid be
Thiese same wordis . writith Ptholome
Rede in his Almageste and take it there
Dame I wold pray yow . if it yowre wil were
Saide this ꝑper/pardoner . as ye bigan
Tel furth yowre tale . spare for noman
And teche vs yong men . of yowre practik
Gladly quod she . sith it may yow like
But first I pray . to al this compaignie
If that I speke . after my fantasie
Ne take it nat a grief . of what I seye
For myn entent is . but for to pleye
Now ʆser/sir than wil I . telle furth my tale
As eủer/re mote I . drynke wyne or Ale
I shal sey sooth . tho husbondis that I hadde
As thre of hem were goode . and two were badde
The thre men were goode . Riche and old
Vnneth myght they . the statute hold
In whiche they were bounden vnto me
Ye wote wele what I meane . of this parde
As help me god I laugh whan I thynk
How pitously anyght . I made hem swynk
And bi my faith . I told of it no store
They had me yeven . theyr lond and theyr tresore
What shuld I do . lengger diligence
To wynne theyr love . or do hem reủer/reence
They loved me so wele . bi god above
That I ne told no deynte . of theyr love
A wise womman . wil busie her eủer/re in oon
To gete her love . ther she hath non
But sith I had hem holy in myn hond
And sithen they had yeven me al theyr lond
What shuld I take kepe . hem to please
But it were . for my profite and myn ease
I sette hem so awerke . be my fay
That many a nyght . they songen welaway
The bacon was nat bi theym as I trowe
That som men han in Essex . at Donmowe
I goủer/rened hem so wele . after my lawe
That eche of theym ful blisful was and fawe
To bryng me gay thynges . from the faire
They were ful glad . whan I spak to hem faire
Now wil I tel yow . of my forth husbond
But yit to be right myrrie . wil I found
I sey I had in herte . grete dispite
That he of any other hadde delite
But he was quyte . by god and bi seynt Ioose
I made hym of the same woode . a croose
Nat of my body . in fowle mane
But certainly I made . other folk suche chiere
That in his owne grese . I made hym frye
For anger . and for verray Ialousie
Bi god in erth . I was his purgatorye
For whiche I hope . his soule be in glorie
For god it wote . he sat ful oft and song
Whan that his shoo . ful bittorly hym wrong
Ther was no wight . save god and he that wist
In many wise . how sore I hym twist
He deyde whan I cam . from Ierusalem
And lith I grave . vndir oure Rode Beam
Al is his tombe . nat so curious
As was the sepulcre . of hym Darius
Whiche that Apellus wrought so subtily
It is but wast . to burie hym preciously
Late hym farewele . god yeve his soule goode Reste
He is nowe in his grave . and in his chest
Now of my fift husbond . wil I telle
God lete his soule . neủer/re come in helle
And yit was he to me . the most shrewe
That feele I on my Ribbes . alby rewe
And eủer/re shal . vnto myn endyng day
But in my bed . he was so fressh and gay
And also therwith . cowde me so glose
Whan that he wold . have my bel chose
That though he hadde me bete on eủer/rey bon
He cowde wynne agayne . my love anon
I trow I loved hym best . for that he
Was of his love . daungerous to me
We wymmen . if that I shal nat lye
In this matiere . have a qweynt fantasie
Waite what thyng . we may nat lightly have
Ther after alday . wil we crye and crave
Forbede vs thyng . and that desiren we
Prese on vs fast . and than wil we flee
With daungier oute we . al oure ware
Grete prese at market . making dere ware
And to grete chepe . is holden at litel prise
This knowith eủer/rey womman . that is wise
My fift husbond . god his soule blisse
Whiche that I tooke for love . and no Riches
He som tyme was . a Clerk of Oxenford
And had left scole . and went at hom to bord
With my gossib . dwellyng in oure towne
God have hir soule . hirname was Alisoun
She knew myn herte . and eke my privite
Better than oure parissh priest . also mote I the
To hir I be wreyed . my counseil al
For had myn husbond . I pissed agenst a wal
Or don a thyng . that shuld have cost his lif
To hir and to another . worthy wif
And to my neece whiche that I loved so wele
I wold have told . his counseil eủer/reydel
And so I dide ful oft . god it wote
That made his face . oft Rede and hote
For verray shame . and blamed hym self for that he
Had told to me . so grete a privite
And bi fil . oones in alent
So oft tymes . I to my gossib went
For eủer/re I loved . yit to be gay
And for to walke . in Marche April and May
From hous to hous . to here sundry talis
Of Iankyn clerk . and my gossib dame / Alis
And I my self . in to the fieldis wente
Myn husbond . was at london al the lente
I had the better leiser . for to pley
And for to see . and eeke for to sey
Of lusty folke . what wist I where my grace
Was shapen for to bien . and in what place
Therfor I made my visitaciouns
To vigiles . and to ꝓprocessiouns
To prechynges . and to pilgremages
To pleyes myracles . and to mariages
To were vpon . my gay skarlet gytes
Thiese wormes ne thiese mothis . ne thiese mytes
Vpon my ꝑper/parel fret hem neủer/re a dele
And wostow why . for they were vsed wele
Now wil I tel furth . what happid me
I sey that in the fieldis . walkid we
Til trewly we had suche Daliaunce
This clerk and I . that of my purviaunce
I spak to hym .and said how that he
If I were wydowe . shuld wedde me
For certainly . I sey it for no bobaunce
Yit was I neủer/ree . without pʳviaunce
Of mariages . ne of other thynges eke
I hold a Mouses herte . nat worth a leeke
That hath but oon hole . to stirt to
And if that faile . that is al I do
But now ʆser/sir late me see . what shal I sayn
Aha bigod . I have my tale agayn
Whan that my fourth husbond was on beere
I wept algate . and made sory chiere .
As wifes moten . for it is his vsage
And with my coủer/rechief . I coủer/reed my visage
But for that I was purveide . of a make
I wepe but smal . and that I vndirtake
To chirche was myn husbond . born amorow
With neyghburghs . that for hym made sorow
And Iankyn the clerk . was oon of thoo
As help me god . whan that I saw hym go
After the beere . me thought he had a peyre
Of legges and feete . so clene and faire
That al myn herte . I yave vnto his hold
He was I trowe . twenty wynter old
And I was fourty . if I sey sooth
But I had alwey . a coltis tooth
Gat tothed I was . and that becam me wele
I had the prynte . of seynt venus seale
As help me god . I was a lusty oon
And faire and Riche . yong and wele bigon
And triewly as myn husbonde . told me
I had the best quoniam that myght be
Myn ascendent was Taure . and Mars was therin
Alas alas . that eủer/re love was synne
That made me that I cowde . nat withdrawe
My chambre of Venus from a goode felawe
What shuld I sey . but at the monthes end
This Ioly clerk Iankyn . that was so hend
Hadde me weddid . with grete solempnite
And to hym yave I . al the lond and fee
That eủer/re was me yeven . ther before
But afterward . repentid me ful sore
He nold soeffre . nothyng of my lift
Bi god he smote me . oones on the list
For that I Rent . out of his booke a lef
That of the stroke . myn eere wax def
Stiboᵘurn I was . as is a lyonesse
And of my tong . a verray Iangleresse
And walk I wold . as I had don bi forn
From hous to hous . al though he had it sworn
For whiche he often tymes . wold preche
And me of old . Romayn gestis teche
How he Simplicius gallus lost his lif
And hir forsooke . terme of al his lif
Nought but for openhed . he hir say
Lokyng out at the dore . vpon a day
Another Romayn . told he me bi name
That for his wif . was at a soms game
Without his wityng . he forsooke hir eke
And than wold he . in his bible seeke
That ilke proủer/rebe . of Ecclesiast /
Where he comaundith . and forbedith fast
Man shal nat soeffre his wif . go Rowle aboute
Thanne wold he sey Right thus . withoute doute
Who so buyldith his house .al of salwes
And prikith his blynd hors . oủer/re the falwes
And soeffrith his wif . for to seeken halwes
Is worthy to be hangged . an high on the galwes
But al for nought . I set nat anhawe
Of his prouerbis . ne of his old lawe
I wold nat bi theym correctid be
I hate hym . that my vices tellith me
And so do mo god wote . of vs than I
This made hym with me . wode al vttirly
That I nold forbere hym . in nocas
Now wil I sey yow sooth . bi seynt Thomas
Whi that I rent . out of his booke a lef
For whiche he me smote . that I was def
He had a booke . that gladly nyght and day
For his disport . he wold Rede alway
He clepid it Valerie and Theofrast
In whiche booke . he looked alwey fulfast
And eke ther was sumtyme . a clerk in Rome
A Cardinal . that hight seynt Ierome
That made a booke . agayn Iouynian
In whiche booke . ther was Terculan
Crisippus . Trotula and Helowis
That was Abbesse . nat fer from paris
And eke the ꝓproabolis . of Salamon
Ovides art . and bookes manyon
And althiese were bounden . in oon volume
And eủer/rey nyght and day . was his custume
Whan he had leysoᵘur . and vacacioun
From other worldly . occupacioun
To Redyn in this booke . of wikked wyfes
He knew of theym . mo legendis and lives
That be of goode wyves . in the Bible
For trustith wele . it is anImpossible
That any clerk wil speke . goode of wyves
But it be . of holy seyntis lives
Ne of non other womman . neủer/re the mo
Who peynted the lyoun . telle me who
Bi god if wymmen . had writen stories
They wold have write of men . more wikkednesse
Than al the mark of Adam may redresse
The chieldren . of M̉er/recurie and Venus
Bien in theyr werkyng ful contrarious
M̉er/recurie lovith wisdom . and science
And venus lovith Riot . and dispence
And for theyr dyủer/res . disposicioun
Eche failith . in others exaltacioun
In Pisses where Venus is exaltatate
And Venus failith . wher M̉er/recurie is elat
Therfor wher M̉er/recuerie is Reysed
No womman of any clerk is preysed
The Clerk whan he is old . and may nough doo
Of Venus werkis . worth his old shoo
Than sit he doun . and writ in his dotage
That wymmen can nat . kepe theyr mariage
But now to purpose . whi I told the
That I was beten . for a booke ꝑper/parde
Vpon anyght . Iankyn that was oure sire
Red on his booke . as he sat bi the fire
Of Eua first . for hir wikkednesse
Was al mankynd . brought to wrecchidnesse
He Rad me how Sampson lost his heris
Slepyng his lemman kit with hir sheris
Thurgh whiche treason . he lost both his eyen
Tho Red he me . if I shal nat lien
Of Herculeus . and of Diamyre
That causid hym . to set hym self a fire
Nothyng forgate he . the sorow and the wo
That Socrates had . with his wyves two
How Xantippa . cast pisse on his hed
This cely man sat stil . as he were ded
He wiped his hed . no more durst he seyn
But ar than thundir stynt . comyth Reyn
Of Pasipha . that was qwene of Crete
For shrewdnesse . hym thought the tale swete
Of hir horrible lust . and hir likyng
Fy speke nomore . it is a grisely thyng
Of Clitemystra for hir lecherye
That falsly made . hir husbond for to die
And Red it . with ful goode deuocioun
He told me eeke . for what occasioun
Amphiorax at Thebes lost his lif
My husbund had a legend . of his wif
Exiphile . that for a broche of gold
Hath privily . vnto the grekis told
Where that hir husbond . hid hym in aplace
For whiche he had at Thebes sory grace
Of Lyuia told he me . and of Lucie
They both made hir husbondis . for to die
That oon for love .thatother for haate
Lyuia hir husbond . on an Evyn late
Empoysened hath . for that she was his foo
Lucia licorous . loved hir husbond so
For that he shuld alwey . vpon hir thynke
She yaf hym suche a man love drynke
That he was ded . orit were bi the morow
And thus algates .husbondes han moche sorow
Than told he . how oon Latymius
Complayned vnto his felaw Arrius
That in his gardyn . grewe suche a tree
On whiche he saide . how his wifes thre
Hyng hem self . for hert dispetous
O lief brothir . quod this Arrius
Gyve me a plant . of that blissed tree
And in my gardyn plantid shal it be
Of latter date of wifes . hath he Red
That som han slayn hir husbondis in hir bed
And late hire lechour . dight hir al the nyght
Whan that the corps . lay in the floore vpright
And som han dryven nailes . in theyr brayn
While that they sleepe . and thus they han hem slayn
Som han hem yeven . poyson in theyr drynk
He spak more harm than . hert can thynk
And ther withal he knew . of mo ꝓprouerbis
Than in this world . growen gras or erbis
Bet is quod he . thyn habitacioun
Be with a lyoun . or with a fowle dragou
Than with a womman . vsyng for to chide
Bet is quod he in the Rof . for to abide
Than with an Angry wif .doun in the hous
Thei bien so wikked . and so contrarious
They hate that the husbond lovith ay
He saide a womman . cast hir shame a way
Whan she castith of hir smok . and furthermo
A faire womman . but she be chast also
Is like a gold Ryng . in a sowes nose
Who wold weene . or who wold suppose
The woo that in myn hert was . and pyne
And whan I saw . he wold neủer/re fyne
To Reden on this cursid booke . al nyght
Al sodenly .thre leevis have I plight
Out of his booke . right as he Rad and eeke
I with my fist . so toke on the cheke
That in oure fier . he fil bakward a doun
And he vpstirt . as doeth a woode lyoun
And with his fist . he smot me on the hed
That in the floore . I lay as I were ded
And whan he saw . how stille that I lay
He was agast . and wold han fled his way
Til at the last . I out of my swoun abrayde
And hastow slayn me . fals thief I saide
And for my lond hastow . murtherd me
Or I be ded . yit wil I kisse the
And nere he cam . and kneled faire adoun
And saide dere suster Alisoun
As help me god . I shal the neủer/re smyte
That I have don . it is thi self to wite
For yeve it me . and that I the beseke
And with that word . I hit hym on the cheke
And seyde thief . thus mochel am I a wreke
Now wil I deye . I may no lengger speke
But at the last . with moche care and wo
We fil accorden . betwene our selven two
He yaf me al the bridel . in myn hond
To have the goủer/renaunce . of house and lond
And of his tonge . and his handes also
And made hym brenne hys booke anon right tho
And whan I had . goten vnto me
Bi Maistrie . al the soủer/reante
And than he saide . my owne triewe wif
Do as ye list . terme of al yowre lif
Kepe thyn honour . and eke myn estate
After that day . had we neủer/re debate
God help me so . I was to hym as kynde
As any wif . from Denmark vnto ynde
And also trewe . and so was he to me
I pray to god . that sit in mageste
So blisse his soule . for his moder dere
Now wil I sey my tale . if ye wil here
The frere lough . whan he herd al this
Now dame quod he . so have I blis
This is a long preambule . of a tale
And whan the Sompnoᵘur herd the frere gale
Lo quod the somnoᵘur . for goddis armes two
A frere and a fart . wil entremete eủer/remo
Lo goode men a flie . and eke afrere
Wil falle in eủer/rey dissh . and matiere
What spekistow . of preambulacioun
What amble or trot or pisse . or go sit adoun
Thow lettest oure disport . in this manere
Ye wiltow so ʆser/sir Sompnoᵘur quod the frere
Now bi my faith . I shal or than I go
Tel of a Sompnoᵘur . suche a tale or two
That al the folk . shal laugh in this place
Now ellis frere . I be shrewe thi face
Quod this sompnoᵘur. and I be shrewe me
But I tel talis / two or thre
Of freris . or I come to Sydyngboᵘurne
That shal make thyn hert . for to moᵘurne
For wele I wote .thi pacience is gon
Oure host cried peas . and that anon
And saide late the womman . tel hir tale
Ye fare as folk . that drunken bien of Ale
Dame tel furth yowre tale . and that is best
Al redy ʆser/sir quod she . Right as yowre lest
If I had licence . of this worthy frere
Yis dame telforth . and I wil here
¶ Explicit prologus / Incipit Fabula Vxoris de Bath /
(base) Here bigynneth the tale of the Wyf of Bathe
(base) Narrat
(base) IN tholde dayes of the kyng Arthour
(base) Of which that Britons speken greet honour
(base) Al was this land fulfild of Fairye
(base) The Elf queene with hir ioly compaignye
(base) Daunced ful ofte in many a grene mede
(base) This was the olde opynyoun as I rede
(base) I speke of many hundred yerys ago
(base) But now kan no man se none Elues mo
(base) For now the grete charitee and prayeres
(base) Of lymytours and othere holy freres
(base) As thikke as any motis in the sonne beme
(base) That serchen euery lond and euery streem
(base) As thikke as motes in the sonne beem
(base) Blessynge halles chambres kichenes boures
(base) Citees Burghes Castels hye Toures
(base) Thropes Bernes Shipnes Dayeryes
(base) This maketh that ther been no fairyes
(base) For ther as wont to walken was an Elf
(base) Ther walketh now the lymytour hymself
(base) In vndermelys and in morwenynges
(base) And seith his matyns and his holy thynges
(base) As he gooth in his lymytacioun

div.l: (base) Wommen may go saufly vp and down
(base) In euery bussh or vnder euery tree
(base) Ther is noon oother Incubus but he
(base) And he ne wol doon hem but dishonour
(base) And so bifel that this kyng Arthour
(base) Hadde in his hous a lusty Bachiler
(base) That on a day cam ridyng fro Ryuer
(base) And happed that allone as he was born
(base) He say a mayde walkynge hym biforn
(base) Of which mayde anoon maugree hir hed
(base) By verray force he rafte hir maydenhed
(base) For which oppressioun was swich clamour
(base) And swich pursuyte vnto the kyng Arthour
(base) That dampned was this knyght for to be deed
(base) By cours of lawe and sholde han lost his heed
(base) Par auenture swich was the Statut tho
(base) But that the queene and othere ladyes mo
(base) So longe preyden the kyng of grace
(base) Til he his lyf hym graunted in the place
(base) And yaf hym to the queene al at hir wille
(base) To chese wheither she wolde hym saue or spille
(base) The queen thanked þe kyng wiþ al hir might
(base) And after this thus spak she to the knyght
(base) Whan that she saw hir tyme vpon a day
(base) Thow standest yet quod she in swich array
(base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) That of þi life / yit hastou kanst tel me
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me
(base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren
(base) Be war and keep thy nekke boon from Iren
(base) And if thow kanst nat tellen me anon
(base) Yet wol I yeue thee leue for to gon

div.l: (base) A twelf monthe and a day to seche and lere
(base) An answere suffisant in this matere
(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace
(base) Thy body for to yelden in this place
(base) Wo was this knyght and sorwefully he siketh
(base) But what he may nat doon al as hym liketh
(base) And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
(base) And come agayn right at the yeres ende
(base) With swich answere as god wolde hym purueye
(base) And taketh his leue and wendeth forth his weye
(base) He seketh euery hous and euery place
(base) Where as he hopeth for to fynde grace
(base) To lerne what thyng wommen loue moost
(base) But he ne koude arryuen in no coost
(base) Where as he myghte fynde in this matere
(base) Two creatures acordyng in feere
(base) Somme seyden wommen louen best richesse
(base) Somme seyde honour somme seyde Iolifnesse
(base) Somme riche array somme lust abedde
(base) And ofte tyme to be widwe and wedde
(base) Somme seyde that oure herte is moost esed
(base) Whan that we been yflatered and yplesed
(base) He gooth ful ny the sothe I wol nat lye
(base) A man shal wynne vs best with flaterye
(base) And with attendaunce and with bisynesse
(base) Been we ylymed bothe moore and lesse
(base) And somme seyn that we louen best
(base) For to be free and do right as vs lest
(base) And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
(base) But seye that we be wise and no thyng nyce

div.l: (base) For trewely ther is noon of vs alle
(base) If any wight wolde clawe vs on the galle
(base) That we nyl kike for he seith vs sooth
(base) Assay and he shal fynde it that so dooth
(base) For be we neuer so vicious with Inne
(base) We wol be holden wise and clene of synne
(base) And somme seyn that greet delit han we
(base) For to be holden stable and eek secree
(base) And in o purpos stedefastly to dwelle
(base) And nat biwreye thyng that men vs telle
(base) But that tale is nat worth a Rake stele
(base) Pardee we wommen konne no thyng hele
(base) Witnesse on Mida wol ye heere the tale
(base) Ouyde amonges othere thynges smale
(base) Seyde Mida hadde vnder his longe herys
(base) Growynge vpon his heed two Asses erys
(base) The which vice he hidde as he best myghte
(base) Ful sotilly from euery mannes sighte
(base) That saue his wyf ther wiste of it na mo
(base) He loued hire moost and trusted hire also
(base) He preyed hire that to no creature
(base) She sholde tellen of his disfigure
(base) She swoor hym nay for al this world to wynne
(base) She nolde do that vileynye or syn
(base) To make hir housbonde han so foul a name
(base) She nolde nat telle it for hir owene shame
(base) For repuyng of hem and foule shame
(base) But nathelees hir thoughte that she dyde
(base) That she so longe sholde a conseil hyde
(base) Hir thoughte it swal so soore aboute hir herte
(base) That nedely som word hir moste asterte
(base) And sith she dorste nat telle it to no man

div.l: (base) ¶ The prologe of the Freres tale
(base) Et incipit Prologus Freris

(base) To yow sire frere so ye be nat wrooth
(base) How that this fart sholde euene ydeled be
(base) Among youre Couent if it liked me
(base) Tel quod the lord and thow shalt haue anon
(base) A gowne clooth by god and by Seint Iohn
(base) My lord quod he whan that the weder is fair
(base) Withouten wynd or parturbynge of Air
(base) Right here before you sittyng in a chaire
(base) Lat brynge a Cartwheel heere in to this halle
(base) But looke that it haue his spokes alle
(base) Twelf spokes hath a Cartwheel comunly
(base) And brynge me thanne twelf freres woot ye why
(base) For thrittene is a Couent as I gesse
(base) Youre confessour heere for his worthynesse
(base) Shal parfourne vp the nombre of this Couent
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thanne shal they knele adown by oon assent
(base) And to euery spokes ende in this manere
(base) Ful sadly leye his nose shal a frere
(base) Youre noble Confessour ther god hym saue
(base) Shal holde his nose vp right vnder the Naue
(base) Thanne shal this cherl with baly stif and toght
(base) As any tabour hider been ybroght
(base) And sette hym on the wheel right of this Cart
(base) Vpon the Naue and make hym lete a fart
(base) And ye shal seen on peril of my lyf
(base) By proue which that is demonstratyf
(base) That equally the soun of it wol wende
(base) And eek the stynk vnto the spokes ende
(base) Saue that this worthy man youre Confessour
(base) By cause he is a man of greet honour
(base) Shal han the firste fruyt as reson is
(base) The noble vsage of freres yet is this
(base) The worthy men of hem shul first be serued
(base) And certeynly he hath it wel disserued
(base) He hath to day taught vs so muchel good
(base) With prechyng in the pulput ther he stood
(base) That I may vouche sauf I seye for me
(base) He hadde the firste smel of fartes thre
(base) And so wolde al his Couent hardily
(base) He bereth hym so faire and holily
(base) The lord the lady ech man saue the frere
(base) Seyden that Iankyn spak in this matere
(base) As wel as Euclyde or Protholomee
(base) Touchynge the cherl they seyde subtiltee
(base) And hy wit made hym speke as he spak
