div.l: (base) He nys no fool ne no demonyak
(base) And Iankyn hath ywonne a newe gowne
(base) My tale is doon we been almoost at towne
(base) Here endeth the Somnours tale
(base) Hic finita fabula Summonitoris
¶ Incipit ꝓprologus cler Oxon
SIr Clerk of Oxenford . oure host saide
Ye ride as coy and stille . as doeth a mayde
That were newe spoused . sittyng at the boord
This day ne herd I . of yowre tung a word
I trow ye study . about som Sophyme
But Salamon seith . eủer/rey thyng hath tyme
For goddis sakesakeas beth of bettir chiere
It is no tyme . for to studyen here
Tel vs som myrie tale . bi youre fey
For what man is entrid in to a play
He nedis mote . vnto the pley assente
But prechith nat . as freris don in lente
To make vs for oure old synnes to weepe
Ne that thi tale . make vs to sleepe
Tel vs som myrrie thyng . of aventures
Yowre termes yowre colowres . and yowre figures
Kepe hem in store . til so that ye endite
High stile . as men to kynges write
Spekith so playne . at this tyme we yow preye
That we may vndirstonde . what ye seye
This worthy clerk . benygnely annswerd
Host quod he . I am vndir yowre yerde
Ye han of vs . asmoche the goủer/renaunce
And therfor wil I do yowre obeisaunce
As fer as reason askith hardily
I wil yow tel a tale . whiche that I
Lerned at Padowe of a worthy clerk
As proved bi his word . and bi his werk
He is now ded . and nailed in his cheste
I pray to god . so yive his soule goode reste
Fraunceys Petrak the Laureat poete
Hight this clerk whos Rethorik swete
Enlumyned al Itailie . of poetrie
As Lymon dide . of Philosophie
Or lawe . or other art ꝑper/particuler
But deth that wil nat . soeffre vs to dwelle here
But as it were . a twynklyng of anye
Hem both hath slayn . and al shal we dye
But furth to tellen . of this worthy man
That taught me this tale as I began
I seye that firste with hie stile . he enditith
Eủer/rey body of this tale he writith
A ꝓprobleme in whiche . discryvith he
Peomond and of Saluces the contre
And spekith of Alpre the hillis hie
That bien the boundes . of west Lumbardie
And of the mount Vesulus in especial
Where as the Poo but of a welle smal
Takith his first spryng . and his cours
To Emelward to Ferare and to Venyse
That estward . encreasith in his cours
The whiche a long thyng . were to devise
And triewly . as to my Iugement
Me thynkith it a thyng inꝑper/partynent
Sauf that he wil conueyen his manere
But this is his tale whiche that ye shul here
¶ Explicit ꝓprologus / Incipit Fabula
Ther is at the west side . of Itaile
Doun at the roote . of vesulus cold
Lusty playne . habundaunt of vitaile
Where many a towre and Towne thow maist behold
That founded were . in tyme of fadres old
And many another . delitable sight
And Saluces this noble cuntre hight
¶ A marquis whilom . lord was of that lond
As wery his worthy eldris hym before
And obeysaunt redy to his hond
Were al his lieges . both lesse and more
Thus in delite he livith . and hath don yore
Biloved and drad thurgh fauoᵘur of fortune
Both of his lordis . and of his comune
Therwith he was . to speke as of lynage
The gentillest I born . of Lumbardy
A faire ꝑper/parsone . strong and yong of age
And ful of honoᵘur . and of curtesie
Discrete Inough . his cuntre for to guye
Save in som thynges . he was to blame
And Walter was this yong lordis name
¶ I blame hym thus . that he considred nought
In tyme comyng . what myght hym betide
But on his luste present . was al his thought
As for to hauke and hunt . on eủer/rey side
Welnygh alother cures . lete he slide
And eke he nold . and that was worst of alle
Wedde no wif for aught that myght be falle
¶ Only that poynte his people bare so sore
That flokmele vpon aday . they to hym went
And oon of theym . that wisest was of lore
Or ellis that the lord . best wold assent
That he shuld telle hym . what his people ment
Or ellis cowd he shewe suche matiere
He to the Marquys saide as ye shal here
¶ O noble Marquys youre humanyte
Assurith vs and yᵉvith vs hardynesse
As oft as tyme is . of necessite
That we to yow mow telle oure heuynesse
Acceptith lord now of youre gentilnesse
That we with pitous herte vnto yow pleyne
And late youre eeris . nought my voys disdeyne
¶ Al have I nat to don . in this matiere
More than another man . hath in this place
Yit for asmoche . as ye my lord so dere
Han alway shewed me fauour and grace
I dar the bettir aske . of yow a space
Of audience to shewen . oure requeste
And ye my lord . to don right as yow leste
¶ For certis lord . so wele vs likith yow
And al yowre werk . and eủer/re have don that we
Ne cowde oure self . devisen how
We myght lyve . in more felicite
Save o thyng lord . if yowre wilbe
That for to bien a weddid man . yow lest
Than were yowre people . insoủer/reayn hertis rest
¶ Bowith yowre nekke . vndir that blisful yok
Of soủer/reante . and nought of ʆser/siruice
Whiche that men clepe . spousaile or wedlok
And thynkith lord . among yowre thoughtis wise
How that oure dayes passen in sundry wise
For though we sleepe . wake . renne . or ride
Ay fleeth the tyme . it nyl noman abide
¶ And though yowre grene yowth . flowre as yit
In crepith age alwey . as stille as stone
And deth manasith . eủer/rey age and smyt
In eche estate for ther escapith non
And also certayne . we knowen echon
That we shal dey . vncertayn we alle
Bien of that day . whan deth shal on vs falle
¶ Acceptith than of vs . oure trewe entent
That neủer/ree yite refusede . yowre biheste
And we woln lord . if that yow lestyow lestye wil assent
Chese yow a wif . in short tyme at the lest
Born of the gentillest . and of the mest
Of al this lond . so as it oughte seeme
Honour to god . so as we can deeme
¶ Delyủer/re vs out . of al this busy drede
And take a wife . for hie goddis sake
For if so bifel . as god for bede
That thurgh yowre deth . yowre lynage shuld aslake
And a straunge successour . shuld take
Yowre heritage . o wo were vs alyve
Wherfor we pray yow hastily to wyve
¶ Theyr meke prayer . and theyr pitous chiere
Made the Marquys herte . to have pite
Ye wil quod he . myn owne people dere
To that I neủer/re thought . constreyne me
In me reioysith . of my liberte
That sield tyme is founde . in mariage
Ther I was fre . I mote bien in ʆser/siruage
¶ But natheles I see . yowre triewe entent
And trustith vpon yowre wit . and have don ay
Wherfor of my fre wil . I wil assent
To wedde me as soone . as eủer/re I may
But ther as ye han . ꝓprofred me to day
To chese me a wif . I yow relese
Of choys I pray yow . of that ꝓprofre cease
¶ For god it wote . that chieldren often bien
Vnlik theyr worthy eldris . hem bifore
Bounte comyth al of god . nat of the streen
Of whiche they bien engendred . and I bore
I truste nat beaute but in god . and therfore
My mariage myn estate . and reste
I hym be take . he may do . as hym leste
¶ Late me alone . in chesyng of my wif
That charge vpon my bak . I wil endure
But I pray yow . and charge vpon youre lyf
That what wif I take . ye me assure
To worship hir . while that hir lif may dure
In word and werk . both here and eủer/rey where
As she an Emꝑper/parours doughter were
¶ And furthermore . this shal ye swere that ye
Agayn my choys . shal neythe grucche ne stryve
For sith I shal forgo . my liberte
At yowre request . as eủer/re mote I thryve
Ther as myn hert is set . ther wil I wyve
And but ye wil assente . in suche manere
I pᵃy yow spekith nomore . in this matiere
¶ With hertly wil . they sweren and assenten
To al this thyng . ther saide no wight nay
Bisekyng hym of grace . or that they wenten
That he wold graunt theym . a certayn day
Of his spousaile . as soone as eủer/re he may
For yit alway . the people somwhat dredde
Lest that the marquys . no wif wold wedde
¶ He grauntid theym a day . as hym lest
On whiche he wold be wedded . sikerly
And saide he dide althis . at theyr request
And they with humble entent . buxumly
Knelyng on theyr knees . ful reủer/reently
Hym thanken alle . and thus they have anend
Of theyr entent . and hom agayn they wend
¶ And here vpon . he to his officers
Comaundith for the feste . to purvey
And to his prevy . knyghtis and squyers
Suche charge yaf . as hym list . on theym ley
And they to his comaundement . dide obey
And eche of theym doth . his diligence
To do to the feste . drew reuerence
¶ Explicit pars prima / Incipit pars secunda
Nought fer fro thilke paleys . honurable
Where as thilke marquys . shoope his mariage
There stoode a Throop . of sight delitable
In whiche that poore folke . of that village
Hadden theyr bestis . in herbegage
And of theyr labour . toke theyr sustenaunce
After that the erth . yaf hem habundaunce
¶ Among thiese poore folk . ther dwelt a man
Whiche that was hold . porest of hem alle
But the hie god . sumtyme sende can
His grace in to a litel oxes stalle
Ianicula of that thrope . men hym calle
A doughter hadde he faire Inough to syght
And Gresield this yong mayden hight
¶ But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she oon . the fairest vndir sonne
Ful porelich I fostred . vp was she
No licorous luste . was thurgh hir hert I ronne
Wele ofter of the welle . than of the Tonne
She drank . and for that she wold vertu please
She knew wele labour . but non Idel ease
¶ But though this mayde . tendir were of age
Yite in the brest . of hir virginite
Ther was Iclosed . ripe and sad corage
And in grete reủer/reence . and devoute charite
Hir old poore fadir . fostred she
A fewe sheep spynnyng . in the field she kepte
She wold nat bien Idel . til she slepte
¶ And whan she homward cam . she wold bryng
Wortes or other herbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shredde . and sath for his lyveng
And made hir bedde ful hard . and nothyng softe
And ay she kept . hir fadirs lif on lofte
With eủer/rey obeisaunce . and diligence
That chield may don . to fadirs reuerence
¶ Vpon Gresield this poore creature
Ful oft sith . this marquys set his eye
As he on huntyng . rode par auenture
And whan it fel . that he myght hir espye
He nat with wanton . lokyng of folie
His eyen cast on hir . but in sad wise
Vpon hir chier . he wold hym oft avise
¶ Commendynge in his hert . hir wommanhed
And hir vertu . passyng any wight
Of so yong age . as wele in chiere as deede
For though the people had no grete insight
In vertue . he considred ful right
Hir bounte . and disposed if that he wold
Wedde hir only . if eủer/ree he wedde shold
The weddyng day cam . but no wight can telle
What womman . that it shuld be
For whiche mvaile . woundred many aman
And saiden . whan they were in privite
Wil nat oure lord . yit leve his vanite
Wil he nat wedde . alas the while
Why wil he thus . hym self and vs beguyle
¶ But natheles this marquys . hath don make
Of gownnes set in goold . and in Azure
Brochis and rynges . for Gresieldis sake
And of hir clothyng . toke he the mesure
Of a mayde . like to hir stature
And eke of other . ornamentis alle
That vnto suche a weddyng . shuld falle
The tyme of vndren . on the same day
Approchith that this weddyng . shuld be
And al the Paleys . put was in aray
Both halle and chambres . eche in his degre
Houses of offices . stuffid with plente
There maistow see . deyntevous of vitaile
That may be found . as fer as lastith Itaile
This rial Marquys roialich arayed
Lordis and ladies . in his companye
The whiche to that feste . were bode and praied
And of his retenue . the bachillerye
With many asowne . of sundry melodye
Vnto the village . of whiche I tolde
In this array . the right way han hold
Gresield of this . god wote ful Innocent
That for hir was shapen . al this array
To fecche water . at the welle is went
And comyth hom . as soone as eủer/re she may
For wele she had herd sey . that thilke day
The marquys shuld wedde . and if she myght
She wold fayn have seen . som of that sight
¶ She thought she wold . with other maydens stonde
That bien my felawes in oure doore and see
The Marqwyses and therfor wil I founde
To don at hom . as soone as it may be
The labour whiche . that longith vnto me
And than I may at leyser . hir biholde
If she this wey . vnto the Castel holde
¶ And as she wold . oủer/re the thresshold gon
The marqwys cam . and gan hir for to calle
And she set doun . hir water pot anon
Beside the thresshold . in anoxes stalle
And doun on hir knees . she bigan to falle
And with sad countenaunce knelid stille
Til she had herd . what was the lordis wille
¶ This thoughtful marquys . spak vnto this mayde
Ful sobrely and saide thus . in this manere
Where is yowre fadir . o Gresield he saide
And she with reủer/reence . and humble chiere
Annswerd lord . he is al redy here
And in she goth . without lengger lette
And to the marquys . she hir fadir fette
¶ He bi the hand . than toke this old man
And saide thus . whan he had hym aside
Ianycula I neyther may ne can
Lenger the plesaunce . of myn hert hide
If that thow fouchesauf . what so betide
Thi doughter wil I take . or that I wende
As for my wif . vnto my lives end
Thow lovest me . I wote it wele certayn
And art my feithful . liege man I bore
And althat liketh me . I dare wele sayn
It liketh the . and specialy therfore
Tel me that poynt . that I seyd before
If thow wil . vnto tha drawe
To take me as for thy soone in lawe
¶ The sodeyn cas . this man astonyed so
That rede he wax abasshed . and al quakyng
He stoode vnneth seyde he wordis mo
But only this lord quod he my willyng
Is as ye wil . ne ageyns yowre likyng
I wol no thyng ye be my lord so deere
Right as yow list gouerneth this matere
Yet wol I quod this Markys softely
That in thy chambre I and thow and she
Haue a collacioun and wostow why
For I wol aske if it hir wille be
To be my wyf and rule hir after me
And al this shal be doon in thy persence
I wol noght speke out of thyn audience
And in the chambre whil they were aboute
Hir tretys which as ye shal after heere
The peple cam vn to the hous with oute
And wondred hem in how honeste manere
And tentifly she kepte hir fader deere
But outrely Grisildis wondre myghte
But veraily wundir they myght
For neuere eft ne saw she swich a sighte
No wonder is thogh that she were astoned
To seen so greet a gest come in to place
She neuere was to swiche gestes woned
For which she looked with ful pale face
But shortly forth this matere for to chace
Thise arn the wordes that this Markys sayde
To this benygne verray feithful mayde
Grisilde he seyde ye shal wel vnderstonde
¶ Grisilde he saide ye wille welle vndir stande
It liketh to youre fader and to me
That I yow wedde and eek it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wol that it so be
As I suppose that ye wele that it may so be
But thise demandes aske I first quod he
But this demaunde I aske firste quoth he
That sith it shal be doon in hastif wyse
That sithin I shall be done on hasty wise
Wol ye assente or ellis yow auyse
I sey this be ye redy with good herte
To al my lust and that I frely may
As me best thynketh do yow laughe or smerte
And neuere ye to grucche it nyght ne day
And eek whan I sey ye ne sey nat nay
Neither by word ne frownyng contenance
Swere this and heere I swere oure alliance
Wondrynge vp on this word quakyng for drede
She seyde lord vndigne or vnworthy
I am to thilke honour that ye me bede
But as ye wol your self right so wol I
And heere I swere that neuere willyngly
In werk ne thoght I nel yow disobeye
For to be deed thogh me were looth to deye
This is ynough Grisilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a ful sobre cheere
Out at the dore and after that cam she
And to the peple he seyde in this manere
This is my wyf quod he that standeth heere
Honureth hire and loueth hire I preye
Who so me loueth ther is namoore to seye
And for that no thyng of hir olde gere
She sholde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wommen sholde dispoylen hir right there
Of which thise ladys were noght right glad
To handle hir clothes wher Inne she was clad
But nathelees this mayde bright of hewe
Fro foot to heed they clothed han al newe
Hir herys han they kembd that laye vntressed
Ful rudely and with hir fyngres smale
A coroune on hir heed they han ydressed
And set hir ful of owches . grete and smale
Of hir array . what shuld I make atale
Vnneth the people hir know . for hir fayrenesse
Whan she translated was . in swich richesse
¶ This marquys hath hir spoused . with aryng
Bought for the same cause . and than hir sette
Vpon anhors snow white . wele amblyng
And to his paleys . or he lengger lette
With Ioyful people . that hir ladde and mette
Conveyed hir . and thus they spende the day
In revel til the sonne . gan descende away
¶ And shortly forth this tale . for to chace
I sey to this newe Marquysesse
God hath her sent such fauoᵘur . of his grace
That it ne semed nat bi liklynesse
That she was born . and fed in rudenesse
As in a Cote . or in anoxes stalle
But norisshed in anemꝑper/parours halle
To eủer/rey wight . she woxen is so dere
And worshipful . that folk ther she was bore
That from hir burgh hir yere bi yere
Vnneth trowith they hir . but durst have swore
That to Ianycula of whiche I spak before
The doughter were . for as bi coniecture
Hem thought she was . another creature
¶ For though that eủer/re vertuous was she
She was encreased . in suche xcelence
Of thewes goode set in hie bounte
And so discrete . and faire of eloquence
So benygne and so digne . of reuerence
And cowde so the peoplis . hertis enbrace
That eche hir lovid that lokid on hir face
¶ Nought only of Saluce in the toun
Publisshed was the bounte . of hir name
But eeke beside . many a Regioun
If on saide wele . another saide the same
So spradde of hir hy bounte . the fame
That men and wymmen . aswele yong as old
Gon to Saluce on hir to bihold
Thus Walter now lowly . nay but roially
Weddid with fortunat . honeste
In goddis peas . livith ful honestlyhonestly esily
At hom and outward . grace Inough had he
And for he saw . that vnder lowe degre
Was of vertu oft hid . the people hym hielde
A prudent man . and that is seen ful sielde
¶ Nought only this Gresield thurgh hir wit
Cowde al the fete . of wifly humblesse
But eeke whan the case requyred it
The comune ꝓprofite . cowde she redresse
Ther nas discord rancoᵘur . nor hevynesse
In al the land that she ne kowde appese
And wisely bryng . al in reste and ease
¶ Though that hir husbond absent were or non
If gentil men and other . of hir cuntre
Were wroth . she wolde bryng theym at oon
So wise and ripe wordis . had she
And Iugement . of so grete equite
That she from hevene . sent was as men wende
People to save . and eủer/rey wrong to amende
¶ Nat long tyme after . that this Gresield
Was I weddid . she a doughter hath I bore
Al had hir lever . had aman chield
Glad was the Marqwise and the folk therfore
For though amayde chield . com al bifore
She may vnto amayde chield atteyne
Bi liklyhed . syn she nys nat bareyne

l.hi: ¶ Explicit pars secunda Incipit pars tercia

div.l: Ther fil as it bifallith tymes mo
Whan this chield had sowkid . but a throwe
This marqwys in his hert . longith so
To tempte his his wif . hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne myght . out of his hert throwe
This mvailous desire . his wif to assay
Natheles god wote . he thought hir to affray
¶ He hath assaied hir . Inough bifore
And fond hir eủer/ree goode . what nedith it
Hir for to tempte . and alwey more and more
Though som men preise it . for a subtil wit
But as for me I sey . I set nyl it
To assay a wyf whan it is no neede
And put hir . in angwissh and in drede
¶ For whiche this marqwys wrought in this manere
He cam alone anyght . ther as she lay
With stierne face . and with trouble chiere
And saide thus Gresield . quod he that day
That I yow toke . out of yowre poore array
And put yow in estate . of hie noblesse
Ye have nat forgeten . that as I gesse
¶ I seie Gresield . this present dignite
In whiche I have put yow . as I trowe
Makith yow nat foryeteful for to be
That toke I yow . in poore estate ful lowe
For my wele ye mote yowre selven knowe
¶ Ye wote yowre self . how that ye cam here
In to this hous it is nat long ago
And though that ye to me . be lief and dere
Vnto my gentils . ye be nothyng so
They seyn vnto theym . it is grete shame and woo
For to be subgect . and in ʆser/siruage
To the that born art . of a so smal lynage
¶ And namly sith thi doughter . was Ibore
Thiese wordis han they spoke douteles
But I desire . as I have don bifore
To lede my lif with hem . in rest and peas
I may nat in this case . be recheles
I mote don with thy doughter . for the best
Nat as I wold . but as my people lest
¶ And yit god wote . this is ful loth to me
But natheles . without yowre wityng
I wil nat don . but this wil I quod he
That ye to me assent . as in this thyng
Shew ye now yowre pacience . as in wirchyng
That ye me highte and swore . in yowre village
That day that maked was . oure mariage
¶ Whan she had herd al this . she nat amevid
Nother in word chiere or countenaunce
For as it semed . she was nat agreved
She saide lord al lith in yowre plesaunce
My chield and I . with hertly obeysaunce
Bien yowres al . and ye may save or spille
Yowre owne thyng . werkith after yowre wille
¶ Ther may nothyng . god so my soule save
Lykeng to yow . that may displesen me
Ne I desire . nothyng for to have
Ne drede for to leese . save only ye
This wil is in myn herte . and ay shalbe
Ne length of tyme or deth . may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage . in to another place
¶ Glad was this Marqwise of hir annsweryng
But yit he feyned . as he were nat so
Al drery was his chiere . and his lokyng
Whan that he shuld . out of the chambre go
Soone aftir this . afurlong wey or two
He prively hath told . al his entente
Vnto aman . and to his wif hym sent
¶ A man of a sgeaunt . was this prevy man
The whiche that feithful . fuloft I founden hadde
In thynges grete and eke suche folk wele can
Don execusioun . in thynges badde
The lord knewe wele . that he hym loved and dradde
And whan this sgeaunt . wist his lordis wille
In to the chambir . he stalkith hym ful stille
¶ Madame he saide . ye mote foryeve it me
Though I do thyng . to whiche I am constreyned
Ye bien so wise . that ful wele knowe ye
That lordis hestis . mow nat bien I feyned
They mowe wele bien wailed . or compleyned
But men must nedis . vnto theyr lustis obeye
And so wil I . ther is nomore to seye
¶ This chield I am comaundid for to take
And spak nomore . but the chield out hent
Dispitously and gan a chiere make
As though he wold . han slayn it or he went
Gresield mote al soeffre . and consent
And as a lamb she sittith meke and stille
And lete this crue ʆser/sirgeaunt . don al his wille
Suspecious was . the fame of this man
Suspect his face . suspect his word also
Suspect the tyme . in whiche he this bigan
Alas hir doughter . that she loved so
She wend he wold . have slayn it tho
But natheles . she neyther wepte ne siked
Confermyng hir . to that the Marqwise liked
¶ But at the last . to speke she bigan
And mekely she to the sgeaunt praide
So as he was . a worthy gentil man
That she myght kisse hir chield . or that it deyde
And on hir arm . this litil chield she laide
With ful sad face . and gan the chield to blisse
And lullid it . and after gan it kisse
¶ And thus she saide . in hir benyngne voyce
Fare wel my chield . I shal the neủer/re see
But sith I the have . markid with the croyce
Of thilke fadir . blissed mote thow be
That for vs deyde . vpon a cros of tree
Thi soule litil chield . I hym be take
For this nyght . shaltow for my sake
¶ I trowe that to a norice in this case
It had bien rowth . this for to se
Wele myght a modir . have cried alas
But natheles so sad . and stidefast was she
That she endured . al adủer/resite
And to the sgeaunt . mekely she saide
Have here ageyn . yowre litel yong mayde
Go now quod she . and do my lordis willewille heste
But othyng wil pray yow . of yowre grace
That but my lord . forbede it at the leste
Burieth this litel body . in som place
That bestis ne briddis . it to race
But he no word . wold to that purpos seie
But toke the chield . and went forth his weye
¶ This sgeaunt cam vnto . this lord agayn
And of Gresieldis wordis . and of hir chiere
He told hym from poynt to poynt . in short and playn
And hym presented . with his doughter dere
Som what this lord . had rowth in his manere
But nathelees his purpos . hield he stille
As lordis don . whan they wil han hir wille
¶ And bad this sgeaunt . that he prively
Shuld this chield . soft wynde and wrappe
With al circumstauncez . tendrely
And carie it in a Cofre . or in a lappe
But vpon peyne . his hed of to swappe
That noman shuld knowe of his entent
Ne whens he cam . ne whider he went
¶ But at Boloigne . to his sustir deere
That thilke tyme of Pavik was Countesse
He shuld it take . and shewe hir this matiere
Besechyng hir to do . hir busynesse
This chield to fostre . in al gentilesse
And whos chield it was . he bad hir hide
From eủer/rey wight . for aught that may betyde
¶ This sgeaunt goth . and hath fulfilled thys thyng
But to this Marquys . now retoᵘurne we
For now goth he ful fast . Imagyneng
If he bi his wifes chiere . myght aught see
Or bi hir word . aꝑper/parceyve that she
Were chaungid . but he neủer/re cowde fynde
But eủer/ree in oon . Ilike sad and kynde
As glad as humble . as besy / in ʆser/siruice
And eeke in love . as she was wont to be
Was she to hym . in eủer/rey mane wise
Ne of hir doughter . nat a word spak she
Non accident . for non aduersite
Was seen in hir . ne neủer/re hir doughter name
Ne nempned she . in ernest nor in game

l.hi: ¶ Explicit pars tercia / Incipit pars . qᵃ .

div.l: ¶ In this estate . ther passith thre yeere
Or she with chield was . as god wold
A man chield she bare . bi this Waltere
Ful gracious . and faire to bihold
And whan that folk . it to his fadir told
Nat only he . but al his countrey mirie
Was for this chield . and god they thanke and herie
¶ Whan it was two yeere old . and from the brest
Departith fro his norice . vpon a day
This marqwys . caught yit another lest
To tempt his wif . yit ofter if he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But weddid men . ne know no mesure
Whan they fynde . a pacient creature
Wif quod this marqwys . I have herd or this
My wwpeople sekly berith this mariage
And namly sith my sone born is
Now is it worse . than eủer/ree in al oure Age
The murmʳ sleeth myn hert . and my corage
For to myn eeris . comyth the word so smerte
That welnygh distroyed it hath myn herte
¶ Now sey they thus . whan walter is agon
Than shal the bloode . of Ianycle succede
And be oure lord . for other have we non
Suche wordes seyn my people out of drede
Wele ought I of suche murmʳ taken heede
Fo certeyn I drede suche sentence
Though they nat plainly speke to myn Audience
¶ I wold live in peas . if that I myght
Wherfor I am disposed vtterly
As I his suster ʆser/sirued . be nyght
Right so thynke I . to ʆser/sirue hym priuely
Thus warne I yow . that ye nat sodainly
Out of yowre self . for no wo shuld outray
Beth pacient . and therof I yow pray
¶ I have quod she . seyd thus and eủer/ree shal
I wil nothyng . ne nyl nothyng certayn
But as yow list . nat grevith me at al
Though that my dought̉er/re . and my sone be slayn
At yowre comaundement . this is to seyn
I have had no part . of chieldren tweyne
But first siknesse . and after and peyne
Ye beth oure lord . doth with yowre owne thyng
Right as yow list . askith no rede of me
For as I left at hom . almy clothyng
Whan I firste cam to yow . right so quod she
Left I my wil . and al my liberte
And toke yowre clothyng . wherfor I yow preye
Doth yowre plesaunce . I wil yowre lust obeye
¶ And certis . if I had prescience
Yowr lust to knowe . or ye yowre lust me told
I wold it don . without necligence
But now I wote yowre lust . and what ye wold
Al yowre plesaunce . ferme and stable I hold
For wist I that . my deth wold do yow ease
Right gladly wold I dey . yow to please
Deth may nat make . no comparisoun
Vnto yowre love . and whanne this marqwys saw
The constaunce of his wif . he caste adoun
His eyen two . and wondred that she may
In pacience soeffre . al this array
And forth he goth . with drery contenaunce
But to his hert . it was ful grete plesaunce
This vgly siaunt . in the same wise
That he hir doughter caught . right so he
Or worse if men can . worse divise
Hath hent hir soone . that ful was of beaute
And eủer/re in oon so pacient was she
That she no chiere made . of hevynesse
But kist hir sone . and after gan hym blesse
Save this she prayde hym . if that he myght
Hir litel sone . he wold in erth grave
His tendre lymes . delicate to sight
From fowlis and bestis . he wold it save
But she non annswer . of hym myghte have
He went his wey . as hym nothyng rought
But to Boloygne . he tendirly it brought
Thi marqwys woundred . eủer/re lengger the more
Vpon hir pacience . and if that he
Ne had sothly . knowen ther bifore
That ꝑper/parfitly hir chieldren . loued she
He wold have wend . þᵗatþᵗat of sum subtilite
And of malice . or of cruel corage
That she had soeffred this . with sad visage
¶ But wele he knewe . that next hym self certayn
She loved hir chieldren . best in any wise
But now of wymmen . wold I asken fayn
If thiese assaies . myght nat suffice
What cowde a sturdy . husbond more devise
To proven his wif . and hir stidfastnesse
And be contynuyng . eủer/re sturdynesse
But ther bien folk . of suche condicioun
That whan they have . acertayn purpos take
They can nat stynt . of theyr entencioun
But right as they were . bounden to astake
They wil nat of theyr firste purpos . aslake
Right so this Marqwys . fullich hath purosid
To tempte his wif . as he was first disposed
He waiteth if by word . or contenaunce
That she to hym . was chaungid of corage
But neủer/ree cowde he fynde . any variaunce
She was ay oon . in herte and visage
And ay the further . that she was of age
The more trewe . if it were possible
She was to hym in love . and more penyble
For whiche it semed thus . of hem two
Ther nas but oon wil . for as walter liste
The same list . was hir plesaunce also
And god bethanked . al fel for the best
She shewid wele . for no worldly vnrest
A wif as of hir self . nothyng ne shuldd
Wille in effect . but as hir husbond wold
¶ The sclaunder of walter . oft and wide spradde
That of a cruel herte . he wikkedly
For he a poore womman . Iweddid hadde
Hath murtherd both his chieldren pdvely
Suche murrmʳ was among hem comonly
No wonnder is . for to the peoplis eere
Ther cam no word . but that they murtherd were
¶ For whiche wher as his people . ther before
Had loved hym wele . the sclaundir of his defame
Made theym that they hatid hym . therfore
To bien a murtherer . it is an hateful name
But natheles for earnest . ne for game
He of his cruel purpos . nold nat stynte
To tempt his wif . was al his entente
¶ Whan that this doughter . xij . yeere was of Age
He to the Court of Rome in subtil wise
Enformed of his wil . sent his message
Comaundyng hem . suche bulles to devise
As to his cruel purpos . may suffice
How that the popepopeas for his peoples reste
Badde hym to wedde . another if hym leste
¶ I sey he badde they shuld countrefete
The popes bulles . makyng mencioun
That he hath leve . his firste wif to leete
As bi the popespopesdispensacioun
To stinte rancour and discencioun
Be twixt hym and his people . thus saide the bulle
The whiche he hath do publisshed . at the ful
¶ Theise rude people . as it no wonnder is
Wenden ful wele . that it had bien right so
But whan thiese tidynges com to Gresieldis
I deme that hir herte . was ful wo
But she I like sadde . for eủer/remo
Disposed was . this humble creature
The aduersite of fortune . al to endure
¶ Abidynge eủer/re his lust . and his plesaunce
To whom that she was yeven . herte and al
As to hir verray . wordly suffisaunce
But shortly if this story . I tel shal
This marqwys writen hath . in especial
A lettre in whiche . he shewith his entente
And secretely . he to boloyne it sent
¶ To the Erl of Pavik . which that had tho
Weddid his sustir . praied he specialy
To bryng hom ageyn . his chieldren two
In honurable estate . al opinly
But oothyng . he hym prayed vtterly
That he to no wight . though men wold enquyren
Shuld nat tellen . whos chieldren that they weren
¶ But sey the mayde . shuld Iwedded be
Vnto the marqwys . of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was praied . so dide he
For at day set . he on his wey is gon
Toward Saluce and lordis many on
In riche array . this mayden for to guyde
Hir yong brother . ridyng hir beside
Arraied was toward hir mariage
This fressh maide . ful of gemmys cliere
Hir brother . whiche vij yeere was of Age
Arraied eke ful fressh . in his manere
And thus in grete noblesse . and with glad chiere
Toward Saluce shapyng theyr Ioᵘurney
Fro day to day . they riden in theyr wey
¶ Explicit pars quarta Incipit pars . ᵃ .
Among althis after . his wikked vsage
This marqwys doth his wif . tempt more
To the vtt̉er/reest prief . of hir corage
Fully to have . exꝑper/parience and lore
If that she were . as stidefast as bifore
And on a day . in opyn Aidience
He boystously hath saide hir . this sentence
Certis Gresieldis . I had Inowgh plesaunce
To have yow to my wif . for yowre goodenesse
As for yowre trowth . and yowre obeisaunce
Nought for yowre lynage . ne for yowre richesse
But know I now . in verray sothfastnesse
That in grete lordship . if I me wel avise
Ther is grete auᵃntage . in sundry wise
I may nat doo as eủer/rey plowman doth and may
My people me constreyne . for to take
Another wif . and cryen day be day
And eke the Poke rancour for to slake
Concentith it that dar I vndirtake
And triewly . thus moche wil I sey
My newe wif is comyng bi the wey
¶ Be strong of herte . and voide anon hir place
In thilke dower . that ye brought to me
Takith it agayne . I graunt it yow of my grace
Retournyth to yowre fadirs house . quod he
Noman may alwey . han prosꝑper/parite
Withe evene herte . I rede yow to endure
The stroke of fortune . or of auenture
¶ And she agayn . annswerde in pacience
My lord quod she . I wote and wist alwey
How that be twixt . yowre magnificence
And my poủer/rete . no wight can ne may
Make comꝑper/parisoun . it is no nay
I ne hield my self . neủer/ree digne ne worthy
To be yowre wif . ne in yowre chambre ly
¶ And al in this hous . ther ye me lady made
The hie god . take I for my witnesse
And also wisly . he my sowle glade
I neủer/re hield me lady . ne maystresse
But humble suᵃnt to yowre worthynesse
And eủer/ree shal while my lif may endure
Above eủer/rey worldly . creature
¶ That ye so long . of yowre benyngnite
Han holden me . in honour and nobley
Wher as I was . nought worthy for to be
That thank I god and yow . to whom I prey
Foryield it yow . ther is nomore to sey
Vnto my fadir gladly . wil I wende
With hym to dwelle . vnto my lifes ende
¶ Ther I was fostred . a chield ful smal d
Til I be ded . my lif ther wil I leede
Widewe clene . in body hert and al
For sith I yave to yow . my maydenhed
And am yowre triewe wif . it is no drede
God shield suche a lordis wif to take
Another man to husbonde or to make
¶ And of yowre newe wif . god yeve yow grace
So graunte yow wele . and ꝓprosperite
For I wil gladly yielde hir my place
In whiche I was wont . blisful for to be
For sith it likith yow . my lord quod she
That whilom were . in myn hertis reste
That I shal gon . I go whan yow leste
¶ But there as ye ꝓprofre . suche dowaire
As I first brought . it is wele in my mynde
Were my wrecchid clothis . nothyng faire
The whiche to me . were hard now to fynde
O goode god . how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed bi yowre speche . and yowre visage
The day that maked was . oure mariage
¶ But soth is seide . algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect . it proved is on me
Love is nat old . as whan it is newe
But certis lord . for non adủer/resite
To dye in the case . it shal nat be
That eủer/ree in word and werk . I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte . in hole entente
¶ My lord ye wote . that in my fadirs place
They dide me stripe . out of my pore weede
And richely me clothed . of yowre grace
To yow brought I nat ellis . out of drede
But feith and nakidnesse and maidenhed
And here agayn . my clothyng I restore
And eke my weddyng ryng . for eủer/remore
¶ The remenᵃnt of yowre . Iewels redy bien
In yowre chambre . I dare saufly seyn
Naked out of my fadirs house quod she
I cam and naked . mote I toᵘurne agayn
Al yowre plesaunce . wold I folwe fayne
But that I hope . be nat yowre entente
That I smokles . oute of yowre paleys wente
¶ Ye cowde nat do . so dishonest a thyng
Thatilke wombe . in whiche yowre chieldren lay
Shuld before the people . in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare . wherfor I yow prey
Late me nat like a worme . go bi the way
Remembre yow . myn owne lord so deere
I was yowre wif . though I vnworthy were
¶ Wherfor in gwerdon . of my maydenhed
Whiche that I brought . and nat ageyn bere
As fowchesauf yeve me . to my mede
But suche asmok as Iwas wont to were
That I therwith . may wry the wombe of hir
That was yowre wif . and here I take my leve
Of yow myn owne lord . lest I yow greve
¶ The smok quod he . that thow hast on thy bak
Late it be stille . and bere it furth with the
But wele vnneth . that word he spak
And went forth his wey . for rowth and pite
Biforen the folke . hir self stripith she
And in hir smok . with hed and foote albare
Toward hir fadir hous . is she fare
¶ The folk hir folwen . wepyng in the way
And fortune ay they cursen . as they gon
And she fro wepyng . kepte hir eyen drey
Ne in this tyme word . ne spak she non
Hir fadir thiese tidynges herd anon
Cursed the day and tyme . that nature
Shope hym to be . a lives creature
¶ For oute of doute . this old poore man
Was eủer/re in suspect . of hir mariage
For he demed eủer/re . sith that it began
For whan the lord had fulfilled his corage
Hym wold thynke . it were adisꝑper/parage
To his estate so lowe for light
And voyden hir . as soone as he myghte
¶ Agayns his doughter . hastily goth he
For he bi noise of folk . knew hir comyng
And with hir old cote . as it myght be
He coủer/reed hir . ful sore wepyng
But on hir body . myght he it nat bryng
For rude was the cloth . and she more of age
Bi daies fele . than at hir mariage
¶ Thus was hir fadir . for a certeyn space
Dwellith this floure . of wifly pacience
That neither bi her word . ne bi hir face
Biforn the folk . ne eeke in theyr absence
Ne shewith she that hir was don offence
Ne of hir hie estate . no remembraunce
Ne had she . as bi hir countenaunce
¶ No wonder is . for hir grete estate
Hir gost was eủer/re . in playn humylite
No tendre mowth . no herte delicate
No pompe no semblaunt of roialte
But ful of pacience . and benyngnite
Discrete and prideles . ay honurable
And to hir husbonde . eủer/re meke and stable
¶ Men speke of Iob and most for his humblesse
As clerkis . whan theym list can wele endite
Namly of men . but as in sothfastnesse
Though clerkis preise . wymmen but a lite
Ther can noman . in humblesse hem acquyte
As wymmen can . ne can behalf so triewe
As wymmen bien . but it be falle of newe
¶ From Boloygne . is this erl of Pavik Icome
Of whiche the fame vp sprong . to more and lesse
And to the peoplis eris . al and some
Was cowthe eke . that a newe Marqwisesse
He with hym brought . in suche pompe and richesse
That neủer/re was theyr seyn . with mannes eye
So noble array . in alwest lumbardie
¶ The marqwys . whiche . that shope and knew althis
Er that this Erl was come in sent his message
For thilk pore cely Gresieldis
And she with humble hert . and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thought . in hir corage
Cam at his heste . and on hir knees hir sette
And reủer/reently and wisly . she hym grette
¶ Gresield quod he . my wil is vttirly
This mayde that weddid shal be to me
Receyved be to morowe . as roially
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eke that eủer/rey wight . in his degre
Have his estate . in sittyng and ʆser/sirvice
And hie plesaunce . as thow canst devise
¶ I have no womman . suffisaunt certayn
The chambres for array . in ordynaunce
After my lust . and therfor wold I fayn
That thyn were al man . suche goủer/renaunce
Thow knowest eke of old . al my plesaunce
Though thyn array be bad and albe seye
Do thow thy devour . at the lest wey
Nat only lord . that I am glad quod she
To don yowre lust . but I desire also
Yow for to ʆser/sirue and please in my degre
Without feyntyng . and shal eủer/remo
Ne neủer/re for no wele . ne wo
Ne shal the gost . withyn myn herte stynte
To love yow best . with al my trewe entente
¶ And with that word . she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette . and beddis make
And peyneth hir to don . al that she myght
Preyeng the chambreres . for goddis sake
To hasten hem . and fast swepe and shake
And she the most seruisable of alle
Hath eủer/rey chambre arraied . and his halle
¶ Aboute vndren . gan this Erl alight
That with hym brought . thiese noble chieldren tweye
For whiche the people . ran to see the sighte
Of theyr array . richely beseye
And than at erst among they seye
That Walter was no foole . though that hym list
To chaunge his wif . for it was for the best
¶ For she is fairer . as they demen al
Than is Gresield . and more tendre of age
And fairer fruyte . betwene hem shuld falle
And more plesaunt . for hir hie lynage
Hir brother eke so faire was his visage
That hem to seen . the people hath caught plesaunce
Comendyng thurgh . the Marqwys goủer/renaunce
¶ O stormy people . vnsad and eủer/remore vntrewe
Ay vndiscrete . and chaungyng as a vane
Delityng eủer/re . in rumbil that is newe
For lik the mone . ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of chappyng . deere Inow a Iane
Yowre dome is fals . yowre constaunce evil previth
A ful grete foole is he . that on yow levith
Thus seyn sad folk . in that cite
Whan that the people gasid vp and down
For they were glad . right for the nouelte
That han a newe lady . of theyr town
Nomore of this . make I now mencioun
But to Gresield . I wil ageyn me dresse
And telle hir constaunce . and hir busynesse
¶ Ful besy was Gresield . in eủer/rey thyng
That to the fest . was aꝑper/partynent
Right nought was she abasshd . of hir clothyng
Though it were rude . and sumdel eke to rent
But with glad chiere . to the gatis is she sentsentwent
With other folk to gydre . to grete the marqwisesse
And after that doth . forth hir besynesse
¶ With so glad chiere . his gestes she receyvith
And so konnyngly . eủer/reiche in his degre
That no defaute . noman can ꝑper/parceyve
But ay they woundren . what she myght be
That in so poủer/ree array . was for to see
And cowde suche honour . and reuerence
Al worthily they preise . hir prudence
¶ In al this meane while . she ne stynte
This mayde and eeke hir brother . to comende
With al hir herte . and ful benyngne entent
So wele that noman cowde hir preys amende
But at the last . whan thiese lordis wende
To sitte doun to mete . he gan to calle
Gresield as she was busy in the halle
¶ Gresield quod he . as it were in his pley
How likith the my wif . and hir beaute
Right wele quod she . my lord in goode fay
A fairer saw I neủer/re . momoremore than she
I preye to god . yeve hir prosꝑper/parite
And so hope I . he wil vnto yow sende
Plesaunce I nowgh . vnto yowre lives ende
¶ But oothyng I beseke yow . and yow werne also
That ye ne preve . with no turmentyng
This tendre maide . as ye han don mo
For she is fostrid . in hir norissyng
More tendrely and to my supposyng
She cowde nat adủer/resite endure
As can a poore . fostred creature
¶ And whan this walter . saw hir pacience
Hir glad chiere . and no malice at al
And he so ofte had don . to hir offence
And she ay sad . and constaunt as a wal
Contynueng eủer/ree hir Innocence oủer/re al
This sturdy Marqwys gan his hert dresse
To rewe vpon hir wifly . stidefastnesse
¶ This is I nowgh Gresield myn quod he
Be now nomore agast . ne evil apaied
I have thi feith . and thi benyngnite
Aswele as eủer/re womman . was assaied
In grete estate . and poủer/reliche arraied
Now know I dere wif . thi stidefastnesse
And hir in armes toke . and gan hir kisse
¶ And she for wondir of it . toke no kepe
She herd nat what thyng he to hir saide
She frerd as she had . stirt out of hir sleepe
Til she out of hir masidnesse abrayde
Gresield quod he . bigod that for vs deyde
Thow art my wif . nonother I have
Ne neủer/re Ihad . as god my soule save
¶ This is thi doughter . whiche thow hast supposid
To be my wif . that other feithfully
Shalbe myn heyre . as I have disposed
Thow bare in thi body triewly
At Boloigne have I kept hem prively
Tak hem agayne . for now maystow nat seye
That thow haste lorn . any of thi chieldren tweye
¶ And folke that other wise . han saide of me
I warne hem wele . that I have don this dede
For no malice . ne for no cruelte
But for to assay in the . thy wommanhede
But nat to slee my chieldren . god forbede
But for to kepe hem prively . and stille
Til I thi purpos . knew and thi wille
Whan she this . aswoune doun she fallith
For pitous Ioye . and after hir swounyng
She both hir yong chieldren . vnto hir she callith
And in hir armes . pitously wepyng
Embracid hem . and tendirly kissyng
Ful like amoder . with hir salt teeris
She bathith both . visage and heeris
¶ O whiche a pitous thyng . it was to see
Hir swounyng . and hir humble voice to here
Gramcy lord . god thank it yow quod she
Now rekke I neủer/re . to be did right here
b Sith that I stonde in yowre love . and in yowre grace
a That ye han saved me . my chieldren deere
No fors of Deth . ne whan my spirit pas
¶ O tendre o dere o yong chieldren myne
Yowre woful moder . wend stidefastly
That cruel houndis . or som fowle vermyne
Had eten yow . but god of his mercy
And yowre benyngne fadir . tendirly
Hath don yow kept . and in the same stounde
Al sodainly she swapt . adoun to grounde
¶ And in hir swough so sadly holdith she
Hir chieldren two . whan she gan hem embrace
That with grete sleight . and grete dificulte
The chieldren from hir armes . they gunne arace
O many a tere . o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem . that stoode hir beside
Vnneth about hir . myght they abide
¶Walter hir gladid . and hir sorwe slakith
She risith vp abasshed . from hir traunce
And eủer/rey wight hir Ioye . and feste makith
Til she hath caught agayn . hir contenaunce
Walter hir doeth . so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deynte . to see the thiere
Betwixt hem two . now they bien met in feere
¶ Thiese ladyes whan they . theyr tyme say
Han taken hir . and in to chambre gon
And strypen hir out . of hir symple array
And in a cloth of gold . that bright shon
With a Corowne . of many a riche ston
Vpon hir hed . they in to the halle hir brought
And there she was honoured . as she oughte
¶ Thus hath a pitous day . a blisful ende
For eủer/rey man and womman . doeth his myght
This day in myrth . and revel to dispende
Til on the welkyn . shon the sterris bright
For more solempne . in eủer/rey mannes sight
This feste was . and gretter of costage
Than was the revel . of theyr mariage
¶ Ful many ayeere . in high prosꝑper/parite
Liven thiese two . in concorde and in rest
And richely his doughter . maried he
Vnto a lord . on of the worthiest
Of al Italie . and than in pes and rest
His wifes fader . in his Court he kept
Til that the soule . out of his body crept
¶ His sone succedid . in his heritage
In rest and peas . after his fadirs day
And fortunat eke was . his mariage
Al put he nat his wif . in so grete assay
This world is nat so strong . it is no nay
As it hath bien . in old tyme yore
And herkenyth what this auctor seith therfore
¶ This storie is nat saide . for that wifes shuld
Folwe Gresield . as in humilite
For it were Importable . though that they wold
But that eủer/rey wight . in his degre
Shuld be constaunt . in aduersite
As was Gresield . therfor Petrak writith
This storie with hie stile enditith
¶ For suche a womman . was so pacient
Vnto a mortal man . wele more vs ought
Receyve al in gre . that god vs sent
For grete skile is . he preve that he wrought
But he ne tempted . noman that he bought
As seith seynt Iame . if ye his pistel reede
He previth folk al day . it is no drede
¶ And soeffrith vs . al for oure ex̉er/recise
With sharpe scourges . of adủer/resite
Ful oft to be bete . in sundry wise
Nat for to knowe owre wil . for certeyn he
Or we were born . knew al oure frealte
And for oure best . is al oure goủer/renaunce
Late vs lyve thanne . in vertuous suffraunce
¶ But oo worde lordis . herkenyth or I go
It were ful hard . to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Gresieldis thre or two
For if that they were . put to suche assaies
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras though the coigne . be faire at eye
It wil rather brest atwo . than plye
¶ For whiche therfor . for the wifes love of Bath
Whos lif and al hir secte . god mayntene
In high maistrie . or ellis were it scath
I wil with lusty hert . fressh and grene
Syng yow a song . to glad yow with I wene
And late vs stynt . of ernestful matiere
Herkenyth my song . that is in in this manere
¶ Explicit fabla
¶ Lenuoy de Chauncer
GResield is ded . and buried in Itaile eke hir pacience
And both atones . buried in Itaile
For whiche I crye . in opyn Audience
No weddid man . so hardy be to assaile
His wifes pacience . in trust to fynde
Gresieldes . for in certayn he shal faile
O noble wyfes . ful high of prudence
Late non humilite . yowre tong naile
Ne late no clerk . have cause ne diligence
To write of yow storie . of suche mvaile
As of Gresieldis . kynde and pacience
Lest Chicheuache . yow swolow . in hir entraile
Folwith Ekko . that holdyth no silence
But eủer/ree aunswerith . at the countretaile
Beth nat bidaffed . for yowre Innocence
But sharply take on yow . the goủer/renaile
Emprintith wele this lessoıı̄un in yoᵘur mynde
For comvne profite . sith it may availe
Ne drede hem nought . do hem no Reủer/reence
For though thyn husbond . armed be in maile
The armoᵘur . of thi crabbid eloquence
Shal ꝑper/parce his brest . and eke his aduentaile
In Ialousie I rede thow hym couse bynd
And thow shalt make hym couche . as doth a qwaile
If thow be faire . therfolk bien in presence
Shewe thow thy visage . and thyn apparaile
If thow be fowle . be fre of thi dispence
To gete the friendis . ay do thy trauaile
Be ay of chiere . as light as lef on lynd
And late hym care and wepe . wryng and waile
Ye Archewifes . stonde ye at defence
Syn ye be strong . as is a grete Camayle
Ne soeffre nat . that men don yow offence
And sclendre wyves . fieble as in bataile
Beth egre as a Tigier yonde in ynde
Ay clappyng as a Mille I yow counsaile
THis worthi Clerk . whan endid was his tale

Me were levere than a barel ale
My wif at hom . had herd this legend ones
This is a gentil tale . for the nones
As to my spouse . wist ye my wil
But thyng that wil nat be . late it be stille

div.l: LOrdynges quod he in chirches . whan I preche
I peyne me to have . an haunteyn speche
And ryng out Round . as doeth a Belle
For I can al by Rote . that I telle
My tyme is alwey oon . and eủer/re was
First I pronounce . whens that I come
And than my bullis . shew I al and some
Oure liege lordis seale . on my patent
That shewe I first . my body to warent
That no man be so bold . priest no clerk
Me to distrouble . of Cristes holy werk
And after that telle I . forth my tales
Bulles of . and Cardynales
Of patriarkes . and bisshoppes shewe
And in latin . I speke a wordis fewe
To saveren with . my pdicacioun
And for to stire theym . in deuocioun
Than shewe I forth . my long cristal stones
I crammed ful of clowtes and of bones
Reliques bien they . as they wene echon
Than have I in latin . a shulder bon
Whiche that was . an holy sheepis Iowe
And with that I make . many mowe
Oey if that this bone . be wassh in any welle
If Cow or Calf . Sheepe or Ox swelle
That any worme hath ete . or any worme hath stonge
Take water of that welle . and wassh his tonge
And it is hole anon . and furthermore
Of pokkes of scabbe . and eủer/rey sore
Shal eủer/rey sheepe . that of this welle
Drynk a draught take kepe eeke what I the telle
If that the goodeman . that the beste owith
Wil eủer/rey wyke . or the Cok hym crowith
Fastyng drynk . of this welle a draught
As thilke holy Iow . oure eldris taught
His bestis and his store . shal multiplie
And sith also . it helith Ialousie
For though a man be falle . in Ialous Rage
Lete make with this water . his potage
And neủer/ree shal he more . his wif mystriste
Though he the sooth . of hir defaute wiste
Al had she take . priestes two or thre
Here is a Mitayne eeke . that ye may see
He that his hand wil put . in this Mitayne
He shal have multiplieng . in his grayne
Whan he hath sowen . be it whete or otes
So that he offre . pens or grotes
Goode men and wymmen . oothyng warne I yow
If any wight . be in this chirche now
That hath don synne . horrible that he
Dare nat for shame of it . I shryven be
Or any womman . be she yong or old
That hath I made . hir husbond cokeold
Swiche folke shal . have no power nor no grace
To offren to my Reliques . in this place
And who so fyndith hym . out of suche blame
Come vp and offre . in goddis name
And I assoile hym . bi the auctorite
Whiche that bi bulle . gᵃuntid is to me
Be this gawd have I wonne . yere bi yeere
An hundred mark . sith I was pardonere
I stonde like a Clerk . in my pulpit
And whan the lewd people . is doun sett
I preche so as ye han . herd . bifore
And telle anhundred . fals Iapes more
Than peyne I me . to strecche forth the nekke
And Est and West . vpon the people I bekke
As doth a douf⁊andasp;sittyngswalue thithyngdouf⁊andasp;sittyng / on a brerne
Myn handes and my tunge gon so yerne
That it is Ioye . to see my busynesse
Of auarise and of suche cursidnesse
In al my prechyng . for to make hym fre
To yeue theyr pens . and namly vntome
For myn entent . is nat but for to wynne
And nothyng . for correcciou of synne
I rekke neủer/re . whan that they bien buried
Though that theyr soules . goon a blac buried
For certis many . a predicacioun
Cometh oft tyme of evil entencioun
Som for plesaunce . of folkes flaterie
To bien avaunced . bi Ipocresie
And som for veynglorie . and som for hate
For whan I dare nat . other wise debate
Than wil I styng hym . with my tunge smerte
I preche so . that he shal nat a sterte
To bien diffamed . falsly if that he
Hath trespased to my brethern and to me
For though I telle nat his ꝓpropre name
Men shal wele knowe . that it is the same
Bi signes . and other circumstances
Thus quite I folk. that don vs displesaunces
Thus spit I out my venym vndir hewe
Of holynesse to seeme . holy and trewe
But shortly myn entent. I wil devise
And preche of nothyng . but for covetise
Therfor my tyme is yit . and eủer/re was
Thus can I preche . agayn that synne auarice
Whiche that I vse . and morche more vice
But though my self . be gilty in that synne
Yit can I make . other folk to twynne
From Auarice . and sore to Repente
But that is nat . my principal entent
I preche nothyng . but for couetise
And yit am I most gilty . in that vise
Than tel I theym . ensamples manyon
Of old stories . long tyme agon
For lewde people leeven talis old
Suche thyng / konne they . wele Reporte and hold
What trowe ye whiles . that I may preche
And wynne gold . and silủer/re for to teche
That I wil liue . in poủer/rete wilfully
Nay nay I thoght it neủer/re triewly
For I wil preche and begge . in sundry landes
I wil nat do no labour . with myn handes
And make baskettis . and liue therby
Bicause I wil nat beggen ydelly
I wil non of thapostels . countrefete
I wil haue money . wulle chese and whete
Alwere it yeven . of the poorest page
Or of the porest . widewe in a village
Nay I wil drynk licour of the wyne
Al shuld ther chieldren st̉er/reue for famyne
And have a Ioly wenche . in eủer/rey towne
But herkenyth lordynges . in conclusioun
Youre likyng is . that I shal a tel a tale
Now I have dronk . a draught of corny Ale
Bi god I hope . I shal yow telle a thyng
That shalbe Reasou . be to yowre likyng
For though my self . be a vicious man
A moral tale . yit I yow telle can
Whiche I am wont to preche . for to wynne
Now holde yowre pʳpos . my tale wil I begynne
IN flaundris whilom . was a companye
Of yong folk . that hauntiden folie
As Riot hasard . Stywes and Taủer/renes
There as with harpes . lutes and gyternes
They daunce and pleyen . at dise both day and nyght
And ete also and drynke . oủer/re theyr myght
Thurgh whiche they don . the devil sacrifice
Withyn the devils temple . in cursed wise
By suꝓprofluite . abhomynable
Theyr othes grete . bien so dampnable
That it is grisly . for to here hem swere
Oure blissed lordis body . for to tere
Hem thought that Iewes . Rent hym neủer/re I nowgh
And eche of hem . at others synne lough and right
And Right anon . than comen Tombelesteers
Fetice and smale . and yong frutesterers
Syngers with harpes . bawdis wafrerers
Whiche bien the verray devils officers
To kyndle and blowe . the fuyre of lecherie
That is annext vnto glotonye
The holy writ take I . in to witnesse
That luxure is in wyne and dronkennesse

l.hi: Nolite inebriari vino . in quo est luxuria

div.l: Lo how that Loth . vnkyndely
Lay bi his doughtirs two . vnwityngly
So drunk he was . he nyst what he wroughte
And al he wited the wyne . that his doughtirs broug
Herodes whiche sowele in stories
Is write and Red in memories
Whan he of wyn was Replete at his feste
Right at his owne table . he made his heste
To sle the Baptist Iohn . giltles
Senec seith a goode word doutles
He seyth he can . no difference fynde
Betwixt a man . that is out of his mynde
And aman . whiche that is drunklew
But that wodenesse . fallith in a shrewe
ꝒProseuerith lengger . than doth drunkenesse
O glotonye . ful of cursidnesse
O cause first . of oure confusioun
O original . of oure dampnacioun
Til Crist had bought vs . with his bloode ageyn
Lo how diere . shortly for to seyn
Abought was . thilke cursed vilany
Corrupt was al this world . thurgh glotenye
Adam oure fadir . and his wif also
From paradice . to labour and to wo
Were dryven for that vice . it is no drede
For whil that Adam fasted as I rede

div.l: He was in ꝓproadise . and whan that he
Eete the fruyt . of the defendid tre
Anon he was out cast . to wo and to peyne
O glotenye on the . we ought vs to pleyne
O wist a man . how many maladies
Folen of excesse . and of glotonyes
He wold be . the more mesurable
Of any delicacies . standyng on the table
Alas the short throte . the tendir mowth
Makith that Est and west . north and Sowth
In erth in eyr . in water . men to swynke
To gete a gloton . deynte mete and drynke
Of this man people . Paule wele canstow trete
Mete vnto wombe . and wombe vnto mete
Shal god distroy . both as paule seyth
Alas a fowle thyng it is be my feith
To seyn this word . and fowler is the dede
Whan man so drynkith . of the white and rede
That of his throte . he makith his prive
Thurgh thilke cursid . suꝓprofluite
Thapostle wepyng . seith ful pitously
Ther walken many . of whiche yow told have I
I seye it now wepyng . with pitous voice
That bien enemyes . of Cristes Croys
Of whiche the end is deth . wombe is ther god
O wombe o bely . o stynkyng Cod
Fulfild of dunge . and of corrupcioun
At eyther end . fowle is the sown
How grete labour and cost . it is to fynde
Thiese cookis how they stampe . streyne and grynde
And turne substaunce . in to Accident
To fulfillen . al the licorous talent
Out of the hard bones . knocke they
The mary . for they cast nat awey
That may go thurgh the golet soft and soote
Of Spicerie of leef . of bark and Roote
Shal bien his sawce . made bi delite
To make hem yit . a newe appetite

l.hi: Qui autem in delicys est vmens . mortuus est

div.l: But certis . he that hauntith suche delices
Is ded while that he liveth in vices
A lecherous thyng . as wyne and drunkennesse
Is ful of stryveng . and wrecchidnesse
O drunken man . disfured is thi face
Sowre is thi breth . foule artow to embrace
And thurgh thy dronnken nose . semeth the sown
As though thow seydest ay . Sampson Sampsou
And yit god wote . Sampson drank neủer/re wyne
Thow fallist as it were . a stynkkyng swyne
Thy tunge is lost . and al thyn honest cure
For drunkennesse . is verray sepulture
Of mannys wit . and discrecioun
In whom that drynke . hath domynacioun
He can no counseil kepe . it is no drede
Now kepe yow . fro the white and the Rede
And namly from the white wyne of lepe
That is to selle . in fleetestrete or in Chepe
This wyne of Spayne . crepith more subtily
Than other wynes . growyng fastby
Of whiche ther risith . suche fumosite
That whan aman hath dronken draughtes thre
And wenyth that he be . at hom in chepe
He is in Spayne . right at the toun of lepe
Nat at the Rochel . ne at Burdeux toun
And than wil he say . Sampson Sampsou
And herkenyth lordynges . I yow prey
That al the soủer/reayn artes . dare I sey
Of victories . in the testament
Thurgh verray god . that is omnipotent
Were don in abstynence . and praiere
Looke the bible . and ther may ye leere
Looke Actilla . the grete conquerour
Deide in his sleepe . with shame and dishonour
Bledyng at his nose . in dronkennesse
A Capitayn . shuld lyve in sobrenesse
And oủer/re althis . advisith yow right wele
What was comaunded . to Lamuel
Nat Samuel . but Lamuel sey I
Redith the Bible . and fyndith it expressely
Of wyne yevyng . to hem that han Iustice
Nomore of this . for it may wele suffice
And now that I have spoken of glotenye
Now wil I yow defende . hasardrye
Hasard is verray moder . of lesyng
And of deceyt . and cursed forsweryng
Blasphemye of Crist manslaughtꝭes and wast also
Of catel and of tyme . and furthermo
It is Repreef and contrarie . to honour
To be holden . a comune hasardour
And eủer/re the hyer . he is of estate
The more is he holden desolate
If that a prince vse hasardrye
In allgoủer/renaunce . and policie
He is as bicomune oppynioun
Of his Realme . sclaundre and confusioun
Stillas that was . a wise Embassatour
Was sent to Corinthe . in ful grete honour
Fro lacedomye . to make theyr alliaunce
And whan he com hym happid ꝑper/par chaunce
That al the grettest lordis . that were of that lond
Pleyeng at the hasard . he theym fond
For whiche as soone . as it myght be
He stale hym hom . ageyn to his cuntre
And seide ther wil I nat leese my name
Ne wil nat take on me . so grete diffame
Yow for to allie . vnto hasardours
Sendith other wise . Embassatours
For be my trowth . me were lever dye
Than I yow shuld . to hasardours alye
For yow that bien . so glorious in honours
Shalt nat allye yow . with haserdours
And bi my wil . ne as bi my trowth
This wise philosopher . saide without slouth
Looke eeke to the kyng Demetrius
The kyng of Parthes . as the boke seith vs
Sent hym a paire of dise . of gold in scorn
For he had vsed hasard . ther biforn
For whiche he hield his glorie . and his Renoun
As no value . nor Reputacioun
Lordis may fynden . other man pley
Honest Inow . to dryve the day awey
Now wil I speke . of othes false grete
A word or two . as old bookes treche
Grete sweryng . is thyng abhomynable
And false sweryng . is the more reprouable
The high god forbad . sweryng at al
Witnesse of Mathew . but in especial
Of sweryng saith . the holy Ieremye
Thow shalt swere in sooth thyn oothes . and nat lye
And swere in doome and in Rightwisnesse
But Idel sweryng . is a cursidnesse
Bihold and see . that in the first table
Of hie goddis hestis honurable
How that the secunde hest . of hym is this
Take nat my name in Idel . nor amys
Lo rather he forbedith . suche sweryng
Than homycide . or many cursed thyng
I saie that as bi ordre . thus it standith
This knowen they . that his festis vndirsangith
How that the secunde hest . of god is that
And furthermore . I wil tel the alplat
That vengeaunce shal nat passe . from the hous
That of his othes . is toto outragious
Bi goddis precious hert and his nailes
And bi the bloode of crist . that in hailes
Seuene is my chaunce . and thyn is synk and trey
Bi goddis armes . if thow falsly pley
This dagger shal . thurgh thyn hert go
This fruyt cometh . of the bicched bones two
Forsweryng Ire . falsnesse homycide
Now for the love of Crist . that for vs diede
Late be yowre oothes bothes grete and smale
But ʆser/sirs now . wIl I tel furth my tale
These Riotours thre . of whiche I telle
Long erst or pʳme . Ronge had any belle
Werer sette . in a taủer/rene to drynke
And as they sat . they herd a belle klynke
Bifore a cors . was caried to his grave
That oon of hem . gan cal to his knave
Go bet quod he . and axe redily
What corps is this . that passith here for by
And looke that thow . Reporte his name wel
Sir quod this boy . it nedith neủer/readel
It was me told . or he cam here two houres
He was ꝑper/parde . anold felawe of yowres
And sodainly he was slayn to nyght
For drinke as he sat . vpon his benche vpright
Ther cam a pvy thief . men clepen deth
That in this cuntre . althe people sleeth
And with his spere . he smote his herte atwo
And went his wey . without wordis mo
He hath a thousand slayn . this pestilence
And maister or ye come . in his presence
Me thynkkith it were necessarie
For to bien ware . of suche an Adủer/resarie
Beth redy for to meete hym . eủer/remore
Thus taught me my dame . I sey nomore
Bi seynt Marie . seide this Taủer/rener
The chield seith sooth . for he hath slayn this yeere
Hens oủer/re amyle . withynne a grete village
Both man and womman . chield hyne and page
I trowe his habitacioun be there
To bien advised . grete wisdom it were
Er that he dide aman . adishonour
Ye goddis armes . quod this Riatour
It is suche ꝓprool . with hym for to mete
I shal hym seeke . be wey and bi streete
I make avow . bi goddis digne bones
Herkenyth felawes . we thre bien alones
Lete eche of vs hold vp his hand to other
And eche of vs . bi com others brother
And we wil slee this false traitour deth
He shalbe slayn . that so many sleeth
Bi goddis dignite . or that it be nyght
To gydres han thise thre . theyr trowthes plight
To live and dye . eche of hem with other
As though he were . his owne born brother
And vp they stirte . al drunke in this Rage
And furth they gon . toward that village
Of whiche the Taủer/rener . had I spoke before
And many a grisly oth . han they swore
And Cristes blissed body . they to Rent
Deth shalbe ded . if they may hym hent
Whan they hadde gon . but half a myle
Right as they wold . han troden oủer/re a stile
Anold man and a poore . with hem mette
This old man . ful mekely theym grette
And seide thus . now lordis god yow see
The prowdeste . of thiese Riotours thre
Aunswerd agayn . what carl with sory grace
Why artow al for wrapped . save thi face
Why livestow so long . in grete Age
This old man gan looke . in his visage
And seyde thus . for I can nat fynde
Aman though I walked in to ynde
Neither in Cite . ne in no village
That wold chaunge his yowth for myn age
And therfor mote I han . my Age stille
As long tyme . as it is goddis wille
And deth alas . wil nat have my lif
Thus walke I . like a Recheles caitif
And on the grounde . whiche is my moders gate
I knokke with my staf . both erly and late
I sey lief moder . lete me Inne
Loo how I vanyssh . body bloode and skyn
Alas whan shal my bones . bien at Reste
Moder with yow . wold I chaunge my cheste
That in my chambre . long tyme hath be
I for an hayre cloth . to wrappe in me
But yit to me . she wil nat do that grace
For whiche ful pale . and welked is my face
But sirs to yow . it is no curtesie
To speke to anold man . any vilanye
But he trespas . in worde or dede
In holy writ . ye may yowre silf wele rede
Ageyn anold man . hore vpon his hede
Ye shuld arise . wherfor I yeve yow rede
Ne doth vnto anold man . non harm now
Nomore than ye wold . men dide to yow
In age if that ye . so longe abide
And god be with yow . wher ye go or ride
I mote go thider . as I have to do
Nay bi god old cherol . thow shal nat so
Saide this haʆser/sirdour . to hym anon
Thow partist nat so lightly be seynt Iohn
Thow spakest right now . of thilke traitoᵘur deth
That in this cuntre . al oure frendis sleeth
Have here my trowth . thow art his espie
Tel where he is . or thow shalt it abie
By god and bi the holy sacrament
Forsoothly thow art oon of his assent
To slen vs yong folk . thow false thief
Now ʆser/sirs quod he . if ye be so lief
To fynd dethe . turne vp this crokid wey
For in that grove . I left hym bi my fey
Vndir a tree . ther wyl he hym self abide
Nat for yowre best . he wil hym nothyng hide
See ye that Oke . right ther ye shal hym fynde
God save yow . that bought almankynde
And yow amend . saide this old man
And eủer/reiche of thiese . Riotours ran
Til they come to that tre . ther they founde
Of florynes fyne of gold . y crowned rounde
Welnygh an . viij . busshels as hem thought
No lengger than . after deth they sought
But eche of theym . so glad was of the sight
For the floryns were so faire and bright
That doun they sette hem bi this precious hoord
The worst of hem . he spak the first word
Brethern quod he . take kepe what I sey
My wit is grete . thogh I bourd and pley
This tresour hath fortune . vnto vs yeven
In myrth and Iolite . oure lif to liven
And lightly as it comyth . we wil it spend
Ey goddis precious dignite . who wend
To day that we shuld han so faire a grace
But myght this gold be caried from this place
Hom to myn hous . or ellis to yowres
For wele ye Iwote . this gold is al owres
Than were we . in hie felicite
But trewly be day . it may nat be
Men wold seyn . we were thiefes strong
And for oure owne tresour . don vs hong
This tresour must be caried bi nyght
As wisely and as slily . as it myght
Therfor I rede yow . that cut amonges alle
Be drawe and late see . wher the cut wil falle
And he that hath the cut . with hert blith
Shal renne to towne . and that ful swith
And bryng vs brede . and wyne ful prively
And two of vs . shal kepe subtily
This tresour wele . and if he wil nat tarie
Whan it is nyghth . we wil this tresour carie
Bi on assent . where as vs thynkith best
That oon of hem . the cut brought on his fest
And bad hem drawe . and looke where it wold falle
And it fel on the yongest of hem alle
And furth toward the towne . he went anon
And al so soone . as he was goon
That oon of hem spak thus to that other
Thow knowest wele . thow art my sworn brother
Thy profite . wil I tel the anon
Thow wost wele . that oure felawe is agon
And here is gold . and that grete plente
That shalbe departed . among vs thre
But natheles . if I can shape it so
That it departid were . betwene vs two
Had I nat don . afrendis toᵘurne to the
That other aunswerde . I not how that may be
He wot that the gold . is with vs tweye
What shalbe don . what shal we seye
Shal it be counsaile . saide the first shrewe
And I shal tel the . in a wordis fewe
What we shal don . and bryng it wele aboute
I graunt quod that other out of doute
That be my trowth . I wil the nat bewreye
Now quod the first thow wost wele that we be twey
And two of vs . strengger shalbe than oon
Looke whan that he is set . and that anon
Arise as thow woldist . with hym pleye
And I shal Rive hym thurgh . the sides tweye
While that thow strogelist with his . as in game
And with thi dagger . looke thow do the same
And than shal al this gold . departed be
My diere friend . betwixt the and me
Than may we both . oure lustes both fulfille
And pley at dise . right at oure owne wille
And thus accordid . bien thiese shrewis tweye
To sleen the thride . as ye han herd me seye
This yongest . whiche went in to the toun
Ful oft in horte . he rollith vp and doun
The beaute of thiese floryns . newe and bright
O lord quod he . if so were that I myght
Have al this tresour . my self alone
Ther is noman . that livith vndir the throne
Of goode shuld live . so myrily as I
And at the last . the fiend oure enemy
Put in his thought . that he shuld poysoun by beye
With whiche he myght . sle his felawes tweye
For why the fiend . fond hym in suche liveng
That he had leve . hym to sorow bryng
For this was vttirly . his entente
To sle hem both . and neủer/re to repent
And furth he goth . no lengger wold he tarie
In to the towne . vnto apotecarie
And pᵃied hym . that he wold hym selle
Som poisou that he myght . his rattis quelle
And eke ther was . a polcat in his hawe
That as he saide . his capons had I slawe
And fayne he wold . wreke hym if he myght
On vermyn . that distroied hym be nyght
The potecarie aunswerd . and thow shalt have
A thyng . that also god me save
In al the world . ther nys no creature
That ete or drunke hath . of this confecture
Nat but the mountenaunce . of a corn of whete
That he ne shal anon . his lif forlete
Ye sterve he shal . in lasse while
That thow go apaas . but amyle
The poison is so strong . and violent
This cursed man . hath in his hand I hent
This poison in a Box . and sith he ran
In to the next strete . vnto aman
And borwed hym . large botels thre
And therto . his poison poured he
The thridde he kepte clene for his drynk
For al the nyght . he shoope hym forto swynk
In caryng of the gold . out of that place
And whan this Riotour . with sory grace
Had fild with wyne . his grete botels thre
To his felawes agayn repaired he
For right as they had cast . his deth before
What nedith it . to ʆser/sirmon of it more
And right so they han hym slayn anon
And whan this was don . thus spak that oon
Now late vs sitte and drynk . and make vs myrrye
And afterward we wil his body burie
And with that word . it happid hem ꝓprocas
To take the botel there the poisou was
And drank and yaf his felaw also
Fow whiche anon . they staruen both two
But certis I suppose . that avycen
Wrote neủer/re no Canon . ne in no fen
Mo wonder signes . of empoysyneng
That hadde these wrecchis two there theyr endyng
Thus endid be thiese homycides two
And eeke the false enpoysener also
O cursed synne . of al cursidnesse
O traitour homycide . o wikkydnesse
O glotony luxure . and hasardrie
Thow blasphemour of Crist with vilanye
Othes grete of vsage . and of pride
Allas mankynde . how may it be tide
That thi creature creator . whiche that the wrought
And with his precious herte bloode hath bought
Thow art so fals . and so vnkynde allas
Now goode men . foryeve ye yowre trespas
And ware yow from the synne of auarise
Myn holy pardon . may yow warise
If that ye offr nobles and st̉er/relynges
Or ellis silủer/re . broches spoones or Rynges
Bowyng yowre hedis . vndir thiese holy bulles
Comyth vp ye wyves . and offre vp yowre wulles
Youre name I entre here . in my rolle anon
In to the blisse of heuene . shul ye gon
I yow assoile be my hie power
Ye that wol offre . as clene and eke as clier
As ye were born . lo sirs thus I preche
And Ihu Crist . that is oure soules leche
So graunt yow this pardon to Receyve
For that is best . I wil yow nat disceyve
But sirs oo word . forgate I in my tale
I have Relignes and pardon in my male
As faire as any can in Inglond
Whiche were me yeven bi the pp hond
If any of yow . wil of deuosioun
Offren and have myn absolucioun
Com furth anon . and knelith here adoun
And mekely Receyve . my pardoun
Or ellis takith pardou as ye wende
Al newe and fressh . at eủer/rey myles ende
So that ye offren alway . newe and newe
Noblis or pens whiche that bien goode and trewe
It is anhonour . to eủer/reiche that is here
That ye mown have . a suffisiaunt ꝑper/pardonere
To assoilen yow . in cuntrey as ye ride
For aduenture . whiche that may be tide
Paruenture ther may falle . oon or twoo
Doun of his hors . and breke his nek atwoo
Looke suche a siuerte . it is to yow alle
That I am . in yowre felawship I falle
That may assoile yow both more and lasse
Whan that the soule . shal from the body passe
I Rede that oure host . shalbe gynne
For he is most . envolupid in synne
Com forth sir host . and offre first anon
And thow shalt kisse . these Relignes eủer/reichon
Ye for a grote . vnboile anon thi purs
Nay nay quod he . than have I cristes curs
Lat be quod he it shal nat be . so mote I theche
Thow woldest make me . kisse thyn old breche
And swere it were a Religne of a seynt
Though it were . with thy foundement Ipeynt
But bi the Croyse . that seynt heleyne fond
I wold I had thy colyons . in my hond
In stiede of Relignes . or of seyntwarie
Late cut hem of . I wil the hem carie
They shul be shryned . in a hogges tord
This pardoner answerd . nat a word
So wroth he was . noword wold he seye
Now quod oure host . I wil no lenger pleye
With the ne with . nonother angry man
But right anon . the worthy knyght began
Whan that he saugh . that al the people lough
Nomore of this . for it is right Inough
Sir pardoner be glad . and myrie of chier
And ʆser/sir host that be . to me so dere
I pray yow that ye kisse the Pardoner
And pardoner . I pray the drawe the nere
And as we dide . late vs laugh and pleye
Anon they kist . and riden furth theyr wey
Explicit Fabula
IN feith Squyer . thow hast the wele I quyt
And gentily . I praise wele thy wit
Quod the Marchaunt . consideryng thy yowth
So felyngly thow spekist . ʆser/sir I alowth
As to my dome . ther is non that is here
Of eloquence . that shalbe thy peere
If that thow lyve . god yeve the goode chaunce
And in vertu sende the contynuaunce
For of thi speche . I have grete deynte
I have a sone . and bi the Trynite
I hadde lever . than .xxᵗⁱ. pound worth land
Though it Right now . were falle in to myn hand
He were a man . of suche discrecioun
As that ye bien . fy on possessioun
But if aman be vertuous with al
I have my sone snybbed . and yit shal
For he to vertu list nat to entende
But for to pleyen at dise . and lust dispende
And leese althat he hath . is his vsage
And he had lever . talke with a page
Than to comune . with any gentil wight
Where he myght lierne . gentilesse aright
Straw for yowre gentilesse . quod oure host
What Marchaunt parde . wele thow wost
That eche of yow mote tellen at the lest
A tale or two . or breken his bihest
That know I wele ʆser/sir . quod the Marchaunt certayn

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth the Shipmannes tale
(base) Incipit fabula nante
(base) A Marchant whilom dwelled at Seint Denys
(base) That riche was for which men helde hym wys
(base) A wyf he hadde of excellent beautee
(base) And compaignable and reuelous was she
(base) Which is a thyng that causeth moore dispence
(base) Than worth is al the cheere and reuerence
(base) That men hem doon at festes and at daunces
(base) Swiche salutacions and contenances
(base) Passen as dooth a shadwe vpon the wal
(base) But wo is hym that payen moot for al
(base) The sely housbonde algate he moot paye
(base) He moot vs clothe and he moot vs arraye
(base) Al for his owene worship richely
(base) In which array we dauncen iolily
(base) And if that he noght may parauenture
(base) Or ellis list no swich dispense endure
(base) But thynketh it is wasted and ylost
(base) Thanne moot another payen for oure cost
(base) Or lene vs gold and that is perilous
(base) This noble Marchant heeld a worthy hous
(base) For which he hadde alday so greet repair
(base) For his largesse and for his wyf was fair

it were bettre for yow to lese so mychel good of youre owene than for to take of hire good in this manere

(base) for bettre it
is to lese good with worshipe than it is to wynne good with
vileynye and shame

(base) And euery man oghte do his diligence
and his bisynesse to geten hym a good name

(base) and yet shal
he nat oonly bisien hym in kepynge his goode name

(base) but
he shal also enforcen hym alwey to do som thyng by
which he may renouelle his goode name

(base) For it is writen
That the olde goode loos or good name of a man is soone
goon and passed whanne it is nat newed ne renoueled

(base) and
as touchynge that ye seyn ye wol exile youre
