Aduersaries
(base) that thynketh me muchel agayn resoun and out of mesure

(base) considered the power that they han yeuen yow vp on hem
self
(base) And it is writen that he is worthy to lesen his priuilege that mysvseth the mygh and the power that is yeuen him

(base) And I sette cas ye myghte enioyne hem that peyne by
right and by lawe
(base) which I trowe ye mowe nat do

(base) I seye
ye myghte nat putte it to execucioun par auenture

(base) and thanne
were it likly to retorne to the werre as it was biforn

(base) And ther fore if ye wole that men do yow obeisance yow
moste deme moore curteisly

(base) this is to seyn ye moste yeue moore
esy sentences and Iugementz

(base) For it is writen that he that moost
curteisly commandeth to hym men moste obeyen

(base) and therfore I
pray yow that in this necessitee and in this nede ye caste yow to ouercome youre herte

(base) For Senek seith that he that ouercometh his herte
ouercometh twies

(base) And Tullius seith ther is no thyng so commendable
in a greet lord

(base) as whan he is debonaire and meke and apeiseth hym
lightly
(base) And I pray yow that ye wol forbere now to do vengeance
(base) in swich a manere that youre good name may be kept and conserued

(base) and that men mowe haue cause and matere to preise yow of
pitee and of mercy

(base) and that ye haue no cause to repente yow of thyng
that ye doon

(base) For Senek seith he ouercometh in an yuel manere
that repenteth hym of his victorie

(base) Wherfore I prey yow lat mercy
be in youre herte

(base) to theffect and entente that god almyghty haue merci
on yow in his laste Iugement

(base) For Seint Iame seith in his epistle

Iugement with oute mercy shal be doon to hym that hath no mercy of
another wight

(base) Whanne Melibe hadde herd the grete skiles
and resons of dame Prudence and hir wise Informaciouns and techynges
(base) his herte gan enclyne to the wyl of his wyf considerynge hir trewe entente

(base) conformed hym anon and assented
fully to werken after hir conseil
(base) and thonked god of whom procedeth al vertu and al goodnesse that hym sente a wyf of so greet discrecoun

(base) And whanne the day cam that hise Aduersaries sholde appieren
in his presence
(base) he spak to hem ful goodly and seyde in this wise

(base) Al be it so that of youre pride and by presumpcioun and folie and of youre
necligence and vnkonnynge

(base) ye haue mysborn yow and trespased
vn to me
(base) yet for as muchel as I se and biholde youre grete humylitee
(base) and that ye been sory and repentant of youre giltes
(base) it constreyneth me to do yow grace and mercy

(base) Wherfore I receyue yow
to my grace
(base) and foryeue yow outrely alle the offenses Iniuries and wronges that ye haue doon ageyns me and myne

(base) to this
effect and to this ende that god of his endelees mercy

(base) wole atte
tyme of oure dyynge foryeuen vs oure giltes that we han
trespassed to hym in this wrecched world

(base) for doutelees if
we be sory and repentant of the synnes and giltes whiche we
han trespased in the sighte of oure lord god

(base) he is so free
and so merciable
(base) that he wole foryeuen vs oure giltes

(base) Here is endid Chaucers tale of Melibe

div.l: Whan endid was the tale . of Melibe
And of prudence and hir benyngnite
Oure host seide . as I am feithhful man
And bi that precious corpus Madrian
I had lever . than a barel of Ale
That goode lief my wyf . had herd this tale
She nys nothyng . of suche pacience
As was this Melibeus wif Prudence
Bi goddes bones . whan I bete my knaves
She brynggith me . the grete clombid staves
And crieth sle the dogges eủer/reychon
And breke hem . both bak and boone
And if that any . neyghburgh of myn
Wil nat in chirche . to my wif enclyn
Or be so hardy . hir to trespace
Whan she comyth hom . she rampith in my face
And crieth false coward . wreke thy wif
Bi corpus bones . I wil have thy knyf
And thow shalt have my distaf . and go spynne
Fro day to nyght . thus wil she begynne
Alas she seith . that eủer/ree I was shape
To wedde suche a mylksop . a coward or anape
That wil be oủer/relad . of eủer/rey wight
Thow darst nat stond . bi thy wyfes right
This is my lif . but if that I wil fight
Out at the doore . anon I must me dight
Or ellis I am but lost . but if that I
Be like a wield lyon . foole hardy
I wote wele she wil do me . sle som day
Som of my neygburghs . and than go my way
For I am ꝑper/parilous . with knyf in honde
Al be it I dar nat . with her stonde
For she is bigge in armes . bi my faith
That shal he fynd . that hyr mysdoeth or saith
But late vs passe a way . from this matier
My lord the Monk quod he . be myrry of chier
For ye shal telle . a tale triewly
Lo Rowchestre . stant here faste by
Ride furth my lord . breke nat oure game
But be my trowth . I know nat yowre name
Whether I shal calle yow . my lord Dan Iohn
Or Dan Thomas . or ellis Dan Albon
Of what hous be ye . bi yowre fadir kyn
I a vow to god thow hast a wol faire skyn
It is a gentil pasture . there thow gost
Thow art like . a penaunt or a gost
Vpon my feith . thow art som officer
Som worthy sextyn . or som celerer
For bi my fader soule . as to my dome
Thow art a maister . whan thow art at home
No poore cloyster . ne no novice
But a goủer/renour . wily and wise
And ther with al . of brawnes and of bones
A wele faryng ꝑper/parsone . for the nones
I pray to god . yive hym confusioun
That first the brought . vnto Religioun
Thow woldest have bien . a tredefoun aright
Hastow as grete licence . astow hast myght
To parforme al thy myght . in engendrure
Thow haddest bigeten . ful many a creature
Alas thy worestow . so wide a cope
God yeve me sorow . but and I were
Nat only thow . but eủer/rey myghty man
Though he were shoore . fulhie vpon the pan
Shuld have a wif . for al the world is lorn
Religioun hath take vp . al the corn
Of tredyng for we borel folk bien but shrympes
Of feble trees . com wrecched ympes
This makith that oure heyres . bien so sclendre
And fieble that they may nat / wele engendre
This makith that oure wifes . wil assay
Religious folk . for they may better pay
Of Venus paiementis . than may we
God wote no lushboᵘuris . payen ye
But be nat wroth my lord . though I pley
Ful oft in game . a sooth have I herd sey
This worthy Monk . toke al in pacience
And saide . I wil do al my diligence
As fer as sownyth . in to honeste
To telle yow a tale . two or thre
And if yow list . to herken hiderward
I wil seyn the lif . of seynt Edward
Or ellis tragedies . I wil yow telle
Of whiche I have . anhundred in my selle
Tragedie is to sayn . a certayn storie
As old bookes . maken memorie
Of them that stode . in grete prosꝑper/parite
And bien I fallen . out of high degre
In to myserie . and endid wrecchidly
As they bien vcified comonly
Of vj feete . whiche men clepen exametron
In proose bien eke . endited manyon
And eke in meetre . in many sundry wise
Lo this declaryng . ought I now suffice
Now herkenyth . if yow like for to here
But first I yow biseche . in this matere
Though I be ordir . tel nat thiese thynges
Be it of popes . Emꝑper/parours or kynges
After theyr Ages . as men writen fynde
But telle som before . and som behynde
As it now cometh . to remembraunce
Have me excused . of myn Ignoraunce
Incipit Fabula
I wil bewaile . in man of tragedie
The harm of theym . that stoode in hie degre
And fellen so . that ther was no remedie
To bryng hem out . of theyr adủer/resite
For certayne whan fortune . list to flee
Ther may noman the course . of hir witholde
Late noman trust . on blynde prosꝑper/parite
Beth ware bi thiese ensamples . triewe and old
// At lucifer . though he an aungel were
And nat a man . at hym wil I begynne
For though fortune . may non Aungel dere
From high degre . yit fil he for his synne
Doun to helle . where he yit is Inne
O lucifer brightest . of Aungels alle
Now artow Sathanas thow maist nat twynne
Out of myserie . in whiche thow art Inne
// Lo Adam in the field . of Gamastene
With goddis owne fynger . wrought was he
And nat bigeten . of mannes sꝑper/parme vnclene
And weldid al paradise . sauf oo tre
Had neủer/re worldly man . so high degre
As Adam til for mysgoủer/renaunce
Was dryve out . of his high prosꝑper/parite
To labour and travaile . and to myschaunce
// Lo Sampson . whiche that was annunciat
Bi thaungel long . or his natiuite
And was to god almyghti . consecrate
And stoode in noblesse . while he myght see
Was never suche another . as was he
To speke of strength . and therwith hardynesse
But to his wif . told he his secre
Thurgh whiche he slow hym . for wrecchidnesse
// Sampson this noble . and myghti Champioun
Withouten wepne . sauf his handis tweye
He slow . and alto rent the lyoun
Toward his weddyng . walkyng bi the wey
His false wif . cowde hym so please and prey
Til she his counsail knew . and she vntriew
Vnto his foes . his counsail bigan to wreye
And hym forsooke . and tooke another newe
// Thre hundred foxes . toke Sampson for Ire
And al theyr tailes . he to guyder bond
And sette the foxes tailes . al on fuyre
For he on eủer/rey taile . had knyt a brond
And they brent al the cornes . in that lond
And al they Olives . and vynes eke
A thousand men . he slow with his hond
And had no wepne . but an Asses cheke
// Whan they were slayn . so thursted hym that he
Was welnygh lorn . for whiche he gan to preye
That god wold on his peyne . have som pite
And sende hym drynk . or ellis must he deye
And of this Asses cheke . that was dreye
Out of a wangtoth . sprang anon a welle
Of whiche he drank I nowgh . shortly for to telle seye
Thus helpid hym god . as Iudicum can telle
// Bi Vray fors . at Gaza on a nyght
Mawgre Philastees of tha citee
The gatis of the towne . he hath vp plight
And on his bak . I caried hem hath he
Hie on an hill . where almen myght see
O noble almyghti Sampson lief and diere
Haddestow nat told . to wymmen thy secre
In al this world . ne hadde bien thi peere
// This Sampson neủer/re . sither drank ne wyne
Ne on his hed . com Rasour non ne shere
Bi precept of the messangier . devyne
For al his strength . in his heris were
And fully . xx . wynter . yeere bi yeere
He hadde of Israel the goủer/renaunce
But soone shal he wepe . many a tere
For wymmen shuln bryngen hym to myschaunce
// Vnto his lemman . Dalida he tolde
That in his heris . al his strength lay
And falsly to his foomen . she hym sold
And slepyng in hir arm . vpon a day
She clipped and share his her away
And made his foomen . al this craft espien
And whan that they hym fond . in suche array
They bonde hym fast . and put out his eyen
// But or his her . I clipped were or I shave
Ther was no bonde with whiche . men myght hym bynde
But now is he in prison . and in a cave
Where as they made hym . at the qwerne grynde
O noble Sampson . strenggest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge . in glorie and in Richesse
Now maistow wepe . with thyn eyen blynde
Sith thow from wele art falle in to wrecchidnesse
// Thend of this caitif . as I shal say
His foomen made a fest . vpon a day
And made hym as theyr foole before hem pley
And this was in a temple . of grete array
But at the last . he made a fowle affray
For he two pillers shooke . and made hem falle
And doun fel temple and al . and ther it lay
And slow hym self . and eke his foomen alle
// This is to seyn . the prynces eủer/reychon
And eeke thre thowsand bodyes were there slayn
With fallyng of the grete temple of ston
Of Sampson now wil I . nomore sayn
Beth ware . bi this ensample old and playn
That noman tel theyr counseil . to theyr wifes
Of suche thynges . as they wold have secre fayn
If that it towche . theyr lymmes or theyr lyves
// Of hercules . the soủer/reayn conquerour
Syngen his werkis . lawde and high renoun
For in his tyme of strength . he was the flour
He slow and raft . the skynne from the lyoun
He of Centaurus leyde the bost adoun
He Apies slow . the Cruel briddis felle
The golden Apples . he raft from the dragoun
He drow out Cerberus . the cruel hound of helle
//He slow the cruel tyraunt . Buserus
And made his hors . to frete hym flessh and bon
He slow the Vray spent . venemous
Of Achillis two Ribbis . he brak oon
And he slow Cacus in a cave of ston
He slow the gyaunt Antheus the strong
He slow the grisely bore . and that anon
And bar the heuene . on his nekke long
// Was neủer/re wight . sith that the world bigan
That slow so many monstres . as dide he
Thurghout this wide world . his name ran
What for his strength . and his hie bounte
And eủer/rey Realme . went he for to see
He was so strong . that noman myght hym lette
At both worldes endes . seith Trophee
In stide of boundes . he a piler sette
// A lemman hadde this noble Champioun
That hight Dianra . as fressh as May
And as thiese clerkis . make mencioun
She hath hym sent . a shert fressh and gay
Alas this sherte . alas this welaway
Envenemed was . so subtily with al
That er that he had werid it half a day
It made his flessh . al from his bones fal
// Thus starf this myghti hercules
Lo who may truste on fortune . any throwe
For hym that folwed . al this world of pres
Er he be ware . is oft I leyde ful lowe
Ful wise is he . that can hym self I knowe
Beth ware for whan that fortune . lift to glose
Than waiteth she hir man . for to oủer/rethrowe
Bi suche a wey . as he wold lest suppose
// The myghti throne . this precious tresor
The glorious ceptre . and Roial mageste
That had the kyng Nabugodonosor
With tunge vnneth . may discryved be
He twyes wan Ierusalem the Citee
The vessels of the temple he with hym ladde
At Babiloigne . was his soủer/reayne see
In whiche his glorie . and his delite he hadde
// The fairest chieldren . of the bloode Roial
Of Israel he dide do geld anon
And made eche of theym . to bien his thral
Amonges other . Danyel was oon
That was the wisest chield . of eủer/reychon
For he the dreames . of the kyng expowned
There as in Chalde . clerk was there non
That wist to what fyne . his dreames sowned
// This prowde kyng leete make . a statue of gold
Sixti cubites longe . and sevene in brede
To whiche Image . he both yong and old
Comaundid to lowte . and have in drede
Or in a furneys . ful of flawmes rede
He shuld be brent . that wold nat obey
But neủer/re wold assent . vnto that dede
Danyel . ne his felawes twey
// This kyng of kynges . prowde was and elate
He went that god . that sit in Trynite
Ne myght hym nat . bireve his hie estate
But sodainly he lost . his dignite
And like a beste . he semed for to be
And eete hay as anoxe . and lay theroute
In reyne with wield bestis walked he
Til certayn tyme . was come aboute
// And like an Eglis fetheres . was his heris
His nailes like . a briddes clawes were
Til god relesed hym . a certayne yeeris
And yaf hym wit . and than with many a tere
He thanked god . and eủer/re his lif in fere
Was he to don amys . or more trespace
And til the tyme . he layde was on his bere
He knew that god was . ful of myght and grace
// His sone whiche that hight Balthazar
That hield the Reigne . after his fadir day
Ful prowde he was . of herte and of Array
And eeke an Idolastre . he was ay
His hie estate . assured hym in pride
But fortune . cast hym doun and there he lay
And sodainly his reigne gan devide
// A fest he made . vnto his lordis all
Vpon a tyme . and made hem blith be
And than his officers . gan he call
Bryngeth furth . the vessels quod he
Whiche that my fadir . in his prosꝑper/parite
Out of the temple . of Ierusalem bi rafte
And to oure hie goddis . thank we
Of honour that oure elders . with vs laft
// His wif his lordes . and his concubynes
Ay dronken . while theyr appetite last
Out of thiese noble vessels . sundry wynes
And on a wal this kyng . his eyen cast
And saw anhand armles . that wrote ful fast
For fere of whiche he quoke and sighed sore
This hand that Balthasar so sore agast
Wrote Mane . Techel . Phares and nomore
// In al that lond . Magicien was thernon
That kowde expowne . what the lettir ment
But Danyel expowned it anon
And saide ʆser/sir kyng . god to thi fadir lent
Glorie . honour . Reigne . tresour . Rent
And he was prowd . and no thyng god dradde
And therfor god . grete wreche vpon hym sent
And hym biraft . the Reigne that he had
// He was out cast . of mannes company
With Asses . was his habitacioun
And ete hay as beestis . in wete and drye
Til that he knew : bi grace and bi reason
That god of hevene . hath domynacioun
Oủer/re eủer/rey Reigne . and eủer/rey creature
And than had god . of hym compassioun
And hym Restored . his Reigne and his figure
// Eke thow that art his sone . art prowde also
And knowest al thiese . thynges verily
And art Rebel to god . and art his foo
Thow drank eke . of the vessels boldly
Thy wif eke and thy wenchis synfully
Dronke of the sam vessels . sundry wynes
And heriest false goddis cursidly
Therfore to the I shapen . ful grete pyne is
// This hand sent from god . that on the wal
Wrote Mane . Techel . Phares trust me
Thi Reigne is don . thow weyest nought at al
Deuidid is thi Reigne . and it shalbe
To Medes and to ꝐPer/Parses . yeven quod he
And thilke same nyght . the kyng was slawe
And Darius occupied his degre
Though he therto ne had . right ne lawe
// Lordynges ensample herby may ye take
How that in lordship . is no sikernesse
For whan fortune . wil aman forsake
She berith a wey . his Reigne and his Richesse
And eke his friendis . both more and lesse
For what man that hath . friendis thurgh fortune
Mishap wil make hym . enemyes I gesse
This ꝓproủer/rebe is ful soth . and ful comune
// Cenobia . of Palerne qwene
As writen ꝐPer/Parciens . of hir noblesse
So worthy was . in armes and so kene
That no wight passid hir . of hardynesse
Ne in lynage . ne other gentilesse
Of kynges bloode of ꝐPer/Parse . was she descendid
I say that she had . nat most fairenesse
But of hir shap . she myght nat bien amendid
// From hir chieldhod . I fynd that she fled
Office of womman . and to woode she went
And many a wield hertis bloode she shedde
With arowes brode . that she toke and hent
She was so swift . that she to hem sent
And whan she was elder . she wolde kille
Lions and leopardes . and beres alto rent
And in hir armes . weld hem at hir wille
// But at the last hir friendis han hir maried
To Conedale a prince . of that contre
Al be it so . that she hym long taried
And ye shal vndirstond . how that she he
Hadde suche fantasies . as had she
But natheles . whan they were knyt in fere
They live in Ioy . and felicite
For eche of theym had other lief and dere
//Save othyng . that she wold neủer/re assent
Bi no weye that he shuld . be hir lye
But ones . for it was plainly hir entent
To have a chield . the world to multiplie
And also soone . as she myght espie
That she was nat with chield . with that deede
Than wold she sweffre hym . don his fantasie
Eftsones and nat but oones out of drede
And if she were with chield . at thilke cast
Nomore shuld . he pley . thilke game
Til that fourty wikes . wy were fully past
Than wold she ones . suffre hym do the same
Al were this Onedal wield or tame
He gate nomore of hir . for thus she saide
It was to wifes . lecherye and shame
In other cas . if men with hem pleyde
// Two sones bi this Onedale had she
The whiche she kept . in Vtu and lettrure
But now vnto oure tale . toᵘurne we
I say so worshipful a creature
And wise therwith . and large in mesure
So penyble in the werre . and curteys eke
Ne neủer/re myght bettꝭes . labour endure
Was non in al this world . though men shuld seke
// Hir riche array . ne myght nat be told
As wele in vessel . as in clothyng
She was cloth . in Roial cloth of gold
And eke she left nat . for no huntyng
To have of sundry tunges . knowlachyng
Whan that she leiser had . for to entende
To lierne bookes was al hir likyng
How she in Vtu . myght hir lif dispende
// And shortly of this story . for to trete
So doughti was hir husbond . and eke she
That they conquered . many Reignes grete
In thorient . with many a faire citee
Apportenaunt . vn to the mageste
Of Rome . and with strong hand hield hym fast
Ne neủer/re ne myght . hir foomen don hir fle
Ay while . that Onedales daies last
// Hir batailes . who so list hym for to rede
Agay Sapor the kyng . and othermo
And how that this proces fel in dede
Whi she conquerid . and what title therto
How that she was bisegid and I take
Late hym vnto my mayster . Petrak go
That writith I now of this . I vndirtake
Both of hir myschief . and eke hir wo
// Whan Onedak was ded . she myghtily
The Reignes hield . al with hir ꝓpropir hand
Ageyn hir fooes . she faught so cruelly
That ther nas kyng ne prince in al that land
That he nas glad . if he that grace fand
That she nold . vpon his lond werreye
With hir they made . Aliaunce bi bond
To bien in peas . and lete hir Ride and pleye
// Themꝑper/parour of Rome . Claudius
Ne hym before . the Romayn galyen
Ne durst neủer/ree be so corageous
Ne non Ermyn . ne non Egipcien
Ne Surryen ne non Arabien
Withyn the field . that durst with hir fight
Lest that she wold . hym with hir armes sleen
Or with hir meyne . put hem to flight
// In kynges habite . went hir sones two
As heyres of theyr fadirs Reignes all
And hermanno . and Thymalio
Theyr names were . as ꝐPer/Parcians hem calle
But ay fortune hath . in hir hany galle
This myghti qwene . may no while endure
Fortune out of hir Reigne . made hir falle
To wrecchidnesse . and to mysaduenture
// Aurelian . whan that the goủer/renaunce
Of Rome cam . in to his handis tweye
He shoope vpon this qwene . to do vengeaunce
And with his legions . he toke his wey
Toward Cenobie . and shortly for to sey
He made hir flee . and at the last hir hent

// The people cryed . and Rumbled vp and doun

// And in this gardyn . fond he cherolis tweye

// And for that Nichamore . and Thymothe

// God for his manace . hym sore smote

// The wreche of god smote hym so cruelly

// Comparisoun myght neủer/re yit be makid

HO quod the knyght . goode ʆser/sir nomore of this

And mochel more . for litel hevynesse

Wherfor ʆser/sir monke O Daun piers bi yoᵘur name

Now late another . tel as I have told

And saide vnto this . Nonnes prist anon
Com nere thow priest . com neere thow ʆser/sir Iohn
Tel vs suche thyng . as may oure hertis glade

If he wil ʆser/sirve the . Rekke nat a beene
Looke that thyn hert . be myrry eủer/remoo
Yis ʆser/sir quod he . yis host so mote I go

And thus he saide . vnto vs eủer/reichon
This swete Priest . this goodely man ʆser/sir Iohn
A Poore widew . sumdel stope in aage
Was whilom dwellyng . in a narow cotage
Beside a grove . stondyng in a dale
This widew of whiche . I telle yow my tale
Syth that ilke day . that she was last awif
In pacience . lad a full symple lyf
For litel was hir catel . and hir Rente
By husbondrye . of suche as god hir sente
She fond hir self and hir doughtren two
Thre large sowes had she and nomo
Thre kyne and eeke a sheepe . that hight malle
Ful slutty was hir boure . and eke hir halle
In whiche she eete . ful many a sclendre mele
Of poynaunt sawce . hir nedid neủer/re a dele
No deynte morsel . passed thurgh hir throte
Hir diete was . accordyng to hir cote
Repleccioun ne made hir neủer/re sike
Attempre diete . was al hir phisike
And excercise . and hertis suffisaunce
The gowt letted hir . nothyng to daunce
Ne appoplexie . shent nat hir hede
No wyne drank she . neither white ne Rede
Hir boord was ʆser/sirved most . with white and blac
Milke and browne brede . in whiche she fond na lak
Seynd bacon . and sumtyme aney or tweye
For she was . as in a man deye
A yerd she had . enclosed al aboute
With stikkes . and a dry diche withoute
In whiche she had a Cok . hight chauntcliere
In al the towne . of crowyng nas his peere
His voice was myrier . than the myrrie orgon
That on masse dayes . in the chirche gon
Wel sikerer was his crowyng in his logge
Than any clokke . or any Abbey orlogge
Bi nature he kriew . eche ascencioun
Of equynoxial in thilke toun
For whan degres . xv . were ascendid
Than kriew he . that it myght nat bien amended
His comb was Redder . than the fyne coral
And embatailed . as a castel wal
His bil was blac . and as the geete it shone
Like azure were his leggis . and his toone
His nailes whitter . than the lilye floure
And like the boorned gold . was his coloure
This gentil cok had . in his goủer/renaunce
Sevene hennes . for to do hym plesaunce
Whiche were his sustres . and his ꝑper/paramours
And wondir like to hym . as of coloures
Of whiche the fairest . hewed in hir throte
Was clepid faire . damysel ꝐPer/Partilote

And companable . and bare hir self so faire
That sith thilke day . that she was seven nyght old
That triewly she hath . the hert in hold
Of chauntcliere loken . in eủer/rey lith
He lovid hir so . that wele was hym therwith
But suche a Ioy it was . to here hym syng
Whan that the bright sonne . bigan to spryng
In swete accorde . my lief as fare in lond
For thilke tyme . as I vndirstonde
Bestes and briddes cowde speke and synge
And so bifel . that in a dawenyng
As Chauntclier . among his wives all
Sat on the ꝑper/parche . that was in the hall
And next hym sat . this faire ꝐPer/Partilote
Than Chauntclier gan groone in his throte
As man that in his dreame . drecchith sore
And whan that ꝐPer/Partilote . thus herd hym rore
She was a gast . and seyde hert diere
What eyleth yow . to grone in this manere
Ye be a vray sleper . fy for shame
And he aunswerd . and seide thus madame
I pray yow . take it nat agrief
Bi god me mette . I was in suche myschief
Right now that yit myn hert is sore a fright
Now god quod he . my sweuene Rede a right
And kepe my body . out of fowle prisoun
Me thought how . I romed vp and doun
Withyn oure yerd . where as I saw a best
Was like anhound . and wold han made arest
Vpon my body . and han had me dede
His colour was . betwixt yalow and Rede
And tipped was his taile . and both his eris
With blac vnlik . the remenᵃnt of his heris
His snowt smal . with glowyng eyen tweye
Yit for his looke . for fere almost I deye
This caused me . my gronyng doutles
Avoy quod she . fy on yow hertles
Alas quod she . for bi that god above
Now han ye lost . myn hert and al my love
I can nat love a coward bi my feith
For certis what so any womman seith
We al desire . if it myght be
To han husbondis . hardy wise and fre
And secrete and no nygard . ne no foole
Ne hym that is a gast of eủer/rey toole
Ne non avauntour . bi that god above

Bi god I had lever . than my sherte
